Really solid place. The waiter we had reminded me of an Italian Antonio Banderas. He was attentive and helpful with picking out choices, he didn't get snotty about having a Groupon for the meal, and he was just overall charming.

The building is a little much; giant replica statues of famous sculptures make it interesting and a little comical (people walking by pointed and laughed through the glass), and a TV keeps your attention if your dinner guest is boring (IE, my roommate who I'd been stuck with for our fun vacation thought I was the boring one. -sniff-sniff-)

The desert was delicious. Tira misu that my roomie threatened me with bodily harm if I cut onto "her" side, and comped gummy bears and almond cookies. We were still pretty full, so we didn't try the beautiful bread or the olives, but I'm honestly surprised this place doesn't get more foot traffic. The staff is very attentive and the food pretty delicious.
author: Cronut C.

description:
Went to Tony's in North Beach on an early Saturday night.  An hour and 45 minute wait.    So off we went to find another restaurant.  Didn't want to ruin the good vibe we had with free street parking at Washington Square.  Went past Michelangelo Caffe and the hostess invited us in.  Plenty of room.  Why not?

They start you with bread and bruschetta.  Nice touch.  I thought the bruschetta was very tasty.  We had the marinated calamari and butter lettuce salad, caprese salad, and beef carpaccio.  Enjoyed all of it.  Very tasty spaghetti alla carbonara.  Lots of seafood and shellfish in their pasta with tomato sauce.  Basically the same dish as their cioppino, but with pasta.  Enjoyed this dish as well.  

Service was ok.  The brought us almond cookies and gummy bears.  I asked about the cream puffs.  Only three per order.  The four of us ordered it anyway, and they brought us four cream puffs.  Bonanza!  (Tony's called us about our reservation while we were waiting for the dessert!)  

Kind of an odd decor with colorful glass lights and enormous fiberglass reproductions of famous Italian frescos and statutes on the walls.  

Restaurant got a lot busier later in the evening on Saturday night.  

Beats the absolute hell out of a 105 minute wait for Tony's Pizza in North Beach.  I'd eat here again.
author: Doctor G.

description:
My lady and I shared the spaghetti with meatball dish (the main entrée portions are big enough to share - keep that in mind when ordering from here), and each got separate salads. Honestly, the food was so-so... While the spaghetti sauce was good, everything else was just "okay." But to be honest, what bothered me more than the quality of the food was their service.

Over the course of the meal, we felt overlooked by the team of people serving us. I was given a fork to eat with that had dried food on it and when I brought it to the attention of our server, he forgot to bring me a new fork. After waiting about 5 minutes I had to ask the man working the door to get one for me instead. The thing that upset me the most was when we finished our meals and received our bill. Before finishing our food, I noticed that servers handed out gummy bears and a small treat (I'm not really sure what it was) to other customers when dropping off their bills. I saw it happen with the couple sitting behind us, and shortly after with the couple sitting next to us, but when we received our bill it was quickly dropped off with no post-meal treat. After hearing how one customer raved about the treats she received, I was really looking forward to us getting ours. Needless to say, I was disappointed that we were snubbed.

It also took them forever to present us our bill to begin with, and forever to return the paid receipt... I definitely don't plan on eating here again.
author: David S.

description: House Chianti was pretty good. Free bruschetta and gummy bear and little cookies with the bill! We ordered the spaghetti bolognese, which was just so-so, and spinach and cheese ravioli in a tomato cream sauce which was pretty tasty. The restaurant itself was cute and in a good location.
author: Amber W.

description:
HUGE fan of Michelangelo's! Been here a couple times, once for a date and the other with my family. It's the poster-child of San Francisco restaurants - small place, close seating to other table - a great little place. We were seated right away which is rare for a quaint little SF restaurant. 

I loved that they greeted your table with hot bread and a piece of bruschetta before taking your order. Both are delicious. Their wine selection was vast and the waiter made suggestions for food pairings. I had the lasagna which was an authentic recipe. Unlike the 'Americanized' version of lasagna including ricotta cheese, this dish was made with only mozzarella which was a completely different texture and taste - creamy and light. It was delicious and it will be hard to go back.

We didn't order desert as we were stuffed, but were served a plate of amaretto cookies and gummy bears. It was a great little surprise and a great way to set Michelangelo's apart.

Highly recommend!
author: Drew B.

description: Really mediocre food with bland presentation, as well.  Not much else to say except 'disappointed.'
author: Jeanne R.

description:
Both meals were bland and the free glass of wine, gummie bears and almond cookies weren't very good. Another interesting bit of info was their markets plan besides all the free bits was "our cooks are italian". But we noticed they were Mexican. 

At this point we hope we don't get sick as many of their pitchers and containers were dirty. Check yelp and go to one of the many 4 stars! Sadly we forgot to do that.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
My friend and I were searching the streets for some good Italian food at a reasonable price and wandered by Michaelangelo's. After a warm invitation from the manager Tony, we ventured in and had a delicious meal, served with yummy bread, and a taste of their bruschetta. I would definetely come back for their authentic food and good service.
At a reasonable price. This is where the pretty people are !  LOL.
author: Rich H.

description: Owner is a crazy and rude person! Food was descent, staffs friendly, but when in the end of our visit we gave our 160$ worth Groupon ( paid 100$), the owner started playing drama, shouting on us and insisting on paying extra 70$.  It was not mentioned in Groupon terms, that only several dishes out of the menu can be chosen for the deal, so we didn't expect such attitude in the end of the diner. I would not recommend visiting this place!
author: Anna P.

description:
Came here for a friends birthday dinner w/ a Groupon last Saturday. Everything seemed to go smoothly using the Groupon and the 6 of us enjoyed the range of food we got to sample since we got to choose 3 apps and each had our own entree. 

Everyone seemed to enjoy their food, The steak from my boyfriends plate (forget the name, but it had a peppery sauce) was pretty good. The gnocchi that I ordered w/ the creamy pesto sauce was to die for!! On par with the gnocchi my auntie makes from scratch :-P I would come back here again and again just for that gnocchi- 5 stars just for that.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night with a friend. It was really dead, us being the 3rd table. The waitress was attentive, again being it slow and all. Ordered the calamari  salad, some type of seafood spagetthi, veal with ham, chocolate truffle, and basically a creme brulee. I have never been to an Italian resturant that actually offers spaghetti.. wait I lied, the spaghetti factory (but I don't think that qualifies as actual Italian). So that should tell you something. The calamari salad was bland, Veal was flavorless, And apparently chocolate truffle means round ball of ice cream covered in cocoa powder. Again I'm not a picky person, but I at least expected to have good tasting food for the price they were charging. Not cheap, mediocre, feels like a frozen dinner type of a meal. The only highlight was the creme brulee and the complementary bruchette. If it wasn't for the gift certificate I wouldn't even bother with this place let alone eat in it.

SKIP.....
author: Lena T.

description: Food was solid and the service was excelent (especially considering we sat outside and the line was out the door).  The best part was we ordered 2 glasses of port for dessert and the brought a plate of cookies and the best gummy bears I have ever had. (yes gummy bears!). So cute!
author: Daniel A.

description: Very friendly and attentive staff. Food was great and reasonably priced. Their music system was spotty often cutting out which was a bit distracting. Definitely will come back if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Woodrow P.

description: Worst food I had in SF so far. They catch people on the street for a reason. The starters were okay but main dishes tasted bad and it did not tasted fresh at all.
author: György M.

description:
Walking through San Fran on a Friday night with a large party (13 adults and 1 child in a stroller) we were wooed by Tony at the door of this smallish restaurant. He said he could accommodate our group immediately AND HE DID! We were in and sitting in 5 minutes. 

The food was ok, some people liked their food better than others. I ordered the penne arrabbiata (spicy marinara). It was spicy. 

The kicker was the yummy complementary cookies and GUMMY BEARS that you get at the end of the meal. 

I would go back!
author: Karen R.

description: We really liked this restaurant. I can't believe the place was virtually empty based on the quality of the food. Our very picky daughter ate every last bite of the spaghetti with marinara, which is saying something. Service was quick and friendly, prices were what you would expect in SF. If back in the area, would definitely return.
author: Claude C.

description: Gross! Food was cold and when asked to have it heated it came back semi warm. Would not recommend this place!!!
author: Denise M.

description:
With so many outstanding Italian restaurants in the Bay Area, there are without a doubt some tough decisions to make when you're craving a carb filled dinner. Having worked in an Italian restaurant myself, I often find myself critiquing a restaurant's Penne Puttanesca or their pepperoni, always remembering from my early days as a server in an Italian restaurant, that if it doesn't curl up when it cooks, it isn't real pepperoni.  
Being new to the San Francisco Italian cuisine scene, my boyfriends's mom had bought me a Groupon to Michaelangelo's. With two appetizers, four entrees and two deserts included, I decided to take some friends and family to the joint for my boyfriend's birthday.
Once we got there, we were greeted with the warmest of Italian welcomes from Salvatore, who expressed that he had been there for 20 years. Not only that, once we sat down we immediately received bread and bruschetta to start off. The menu consisted with traditional Italian dishes, like Spaghetti and Meatballs and also Veal Piccata. After our delicious Antipasto and Calamari appetizers, I decided to order their Spaghetti and Meatballs with Bolognese sauce. 
For me, it's always a gamble to order meatballs at any restaurant, because sometimes the ground beef can be too heavy and the spaghetti ends up being more greasy than anything else. However, when I tasted their dish, I was pleasantly surprised to taste that not only was the meatball flavorful, but it was not too greasy at at. The spaghetti was cooked perfectly (not overlooked like how many restaurants today cook pasta) and the Bolognese sauce was light and meaty which was exactly what I wanted.  
We finished off our meals with their Tiramisu and Creme Brûlée, both of which melted in your mouth when you took a bite. 
Needless to say, I will definitely be going back there, they offered a superb menu and has impeccable service!
author: Vanessa J.

description: Excellent. I was last here 19 years ago.  I was excited to bring my wife and daughter while in town but was a little nervous after reading the recent reviews.  I was happy to learn it was still great.  Great staff, great food, great atmosphere. The complimentary bruschetta was superb as was the gnocchi, pizza and seafood pasta   Can't go wrong, great value.
author: Matt S.

description: Went to this place for a good Italian pizza.  Being from NJ/NY area I have high standards for pizza. What I paid for was what you get from box pizza at grocery store frozen food section. The pie was small and wafer thin.  I'm giving them 3 since the guys are nice and friendly. Seems like nice atmosphere. But the pizza needs more work.
author: J S.

description:
Horrible. 

Service was ok. Food was ok... until I got food poisoning from their seafood. Don't order their Spaghetti Scoglio or fish. Another friend of ours ordered fish and got sick as well. Unless you want to throw up all night and have diarrhea... I would be cautious. 

Bon appetite!
author: Anida B.

description:
After reading the previous Yelp reviews, I was scared to go here but Vicky L., my trusted partner in (food) crime, suggested we have a date here because she had a groupon deal that was expiring. 

She arrived before me to find a completely full restaurant. This was odd because it was a Tuesday night and none of the other Italian restaurants on the block were busy . I'm still baffled why it was so busy! But who knows, I do not usually venture into the touristy NB spots. 

I went in with extremely low expectations and was happily surprised that they were exceeded.
Calamari was nothing special. It was bland but the dipping sauce fixed that.
Chicken with sausage and mushrooms: semi-healthy since there was no butter or cream. I liked the wine sauce but it needed salt.
As for the desserts, I loved the gummy bears. The rum almond cookies were great too. We also ordered cassata. I was hoping it would be like the gelato I had in Sicily. It wasn't the same but it was still good. Probably the highlight of the meal.

I survived the experience and there was soccer on the telly. 1 star for that!
author: Sara P.

description: A pretty decent Italian ristorante that gives off a home cooked feeling from the food. The interior is small, but nice with all of those Italian sculptures. It can get pretty busy and packed since being located in a prime food area of San Francisco.
author: Nam B.

description:
I really have to stop wondering into places in North Beach and stick with places that are tried and true OR up and coming with a lot of buzz. No more trying places that have been around forever that no one I know has been to in the last 3 years...

I recently had a conversation about restaurant dining with a friend. We discussed whether awesome food but bad service would keep you away from an establishment or whether ok to bad food but great service would be more likely to keep you away. Ironically, she is the friend that I went to the Corner with and Michelangelo's with in the same week. We decided, as most food-centric people would, that good food, bad service was definitely the lesser of the two evils. Too bad for Michelangelo's...

We were supposed to go to one of her favorite NB restaurants but she forgot that they're one of the restaurants that aren't open on Tuesdays. So we decide to try Michelangelo's since she hasn't been there in years. The staff is super friendly and attentive. Really, they get five stars for the service.

Then we tried to the food... Calamari painfully in need of salt, but perfectly cooked and not at all rubbery. Pasta with clams and red sauce, pretty good with a tad too much salt. My friend''s Carbonara not so much. Now I have dined with this friend many times. I have never seen her leave food on her plate without taking it home.... EVER. She left half of the Carbonara on her plate and did not ask for a doggie bag. 

I did like the gummy bears and cookies, but they give way too much. Really a small cup holding a handful of each for a table would be plenty.

There are literally hundreds of places in North Beach, some of them very good. Unfortunately this is not one of them.
author: Dani D.

description: Worst service ever. Waiters were rude, way too expensive for something that Was not so great . Completely forgot to give us water and had to ask the waiter 3 times for the check. Wouldn't recommend this place at all.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Came here pretty much because of the guy in front offering free wine, free bruschetta, and then there were free gummy bears and cookies at the end.  BUT don't fall for it!

I could barely eat the Carbonara... and usually I eat everything (it's my Asian-ness... I don't like to waste food).  BUT seriously, I couldn't take this down.  It was sooo thick -- too much egg?  Or too much cream?  Too much something!  Maybe if there were more pieces of bacon it would have made up for it, but there weren't.  

My friend didn't like his ravioli either.

And I saw the owner yell at our waitress for something right in front of the restaurant!  Not okay.
author: Anh D.

description:
Food: Had the crab cannelloni in a tomato sauce and the lobster ravioli, also in a tomato vodka sauce. Sauce was buttery and very good. Both ravioli and cannelloni were excellent (I liked the crab better). They look small at first, but I promise you they are filling. I would recommend either and both! They had what looked like some great dessert selections as well, we were just too full to partake.

Price: Each dish we got was $17. First glasses of wine and bruschetta appetizer were on the house, as well as cookies at the end of the meal.

Location: Right in North Beach, on Columbus Ave. Really close to Fisherman's Wharf.

Ambience: Cute little Italian place, not too big and not too small. Quiet, lots of seating available. Could be good for groups celebrating (there was one of these while we were there), couples (also lots of these), or just a simple dinner (like for us!). 

Service: This is really where this place shines. Owner ushered us in and treated us to bruschetta and wine on the house. Waitress and busboy were very accommodating and always with smiles on their faces. Service was quick. The owner was really having fun talking to a lot of the other patrons.
author: Farheen Q.

description:
I was walking down Columbus with my wife and another couple and the "barker" outside offered us a free appetizer if we sat down.   We got sucked in for that reason. Grrrrr, should have known. 

The app was "bruscetta", basically chopped tomatoes and basil with toasted bread.   It was OK but my wife makes better. 

I had  seafood pasta dish that was very mediocre and my wife had a pesto dish that was decent. I don't remember what the other couple had but they thought it was pretty average as well.

Caesar salad was uhhhh, just OK. 

On the plus side, the service was very good and the decor is Italian/cool. 

If you want a free app... and an OK meal its fine. I will skip it next time though.
author: Ken W.

description:
This place sucks! Went for my birthday biggest mistake of my life! Food was not tasty at all and major over priced!!
Cookies were stale! Sodas are not bottomless so we HAD to order a few cans so we could wash down the food. If I could I would give this place a negative star!
Waiter is rude and in attentive!
author: Jess H.

description:
The worst restaurant I've ever been to hands down. 

The food was awful. 
The service. Awful. 

I could not in good form recommend this place to any one.

San Francisco has many great places to chose from. This isn't one of them.
author: Citizen S.

description: very friendly...the gent on the street lured us in with his charming promises.  Our favorite item was their free bruschetta... good balance of olive oil, tomato, and touch of garlic... yum.  I was excited to try other things, so we ordered the antipasti plate, cioppino, and a chicken alfredo.  The soup was thin and the seafood was overcooked or frozen too long b/c it was tough...and appetizer was uninspired and tasted like your average grocery store deli meats, and the pasta dish was totally bland.  It was nice they brought a bowl of olives as well as gummy bears and baby biscottis at the end... kids would like it here... simple, no fuss, nice guys, and basic food.  I would have given them 2 stars, but the service here especially for a Saturday night was very nice, so 3...
author: Jane S.

description: Great view. Ok food. Terrible service. Our drinks were not refilled and the little I had left was sprinkled with Parmesan, nice touch from our waiter who seemed bothered by our presence. I had to ask four times for extra bread before he decided to bring us some. Excuse me if the pregnant lady is craving some carbs  No wonder why they have someone outside luring people in. FYI - There are better ways to get more people inside your restaurant and make them loyal customers.. It all starts with good service!
author: I K.

description: Pizza not so good, service is good. Maybe their other dishes are better. Big disappointment after went in due to ad on street. Plenty of other places down the street. Pizza is not their specialty.
author: AL P.

description:
Free bread, sample of bruchetta, free gummy bears and amaretto cookies for dessert , free side of pasta. Now here is what I did  pay for: I had a very generous serving of choppino, ice cold glass of perseco. The chocolate profitteros were 3 to an order. We were a party of 4. The waiter gave us an extra one.  

Not the most fancy place. We got seated right away.
author: Mocha G.

description:
We came across Michaelangelo Saturday evening, and since I had a really good meal there about 5-6 years ago, I was excited to eat there again...

The waiter quickly brought us water and bread, but it was odd that there were vinegar and oil bottles on the table, but no plate to pour them in, and there was no butter with the bread. They brought bruschetta, so we moved that onto a bigger plate and used that one for the oil & vinegar.

I ordered a salad, a glass of chianti & the spinach & cheese raviolis in creamy tomato sauce, and it was quite good. The pasta was cooked perfectly. The salad was a kind of boring lettuce and shredded carrot thing, and the chianti was ok.

At the end of our meal, the waiter brought a rather large plate of gummi bears and another rather large plate of some kind of biscotti spice cookies, and told us this was a tradition at the restaurant, which again, seemed kind of odd. My wife munched on some gummi bears and I ate one cookie, but didn't care for the taste.

Next time, we'll walk around the area for something else, because although I liked my pasta here, there are other places around North Beach that are better.
author: Brian L.

description:
When Capp's Corner closed, we walked the neighborhood trying to find a new authentic Italian restaurant to replace it. The host here was standing outside and tempted us in with his promise that if we didn't love the food, he would pay for our meal. Too bad he didn't make the same offer for the service. We returned two months later for one of our worst dining experiences.

I don't know if it's always this bad, but the service we received was the WORST I've ever experienced. We were seated right away (at a table awkwardly situated against a step-up near the corner), but that was all that went well. A basket of bread and bowl of olives were literally dumped on our table 15 minutes after we sat down, but it took 35 minutes before anyone came to take our order -- even for just drinks. My husband literally had to flag someone down. Three tables seated after us were served first. And the initial server who took our order then repeated it to our actual server.

We got our salads in about 15 minutes but those came 10 minutes before our drinks. In one of his fly-by passes of our table, the server said, "Oh yeah, you wanted drinks" and asked us to remind him what we ordered. Dinner took another half hour to arrive and the server failed to put the right plate in front of the right person. On another fly-by, he unceremoniously dumped a huge bowl of Parmesan cheese on our table and virtually ignored us the rest of the night.

Maybe the service wouldn't have been so troublesome if the food at least had been good. It wasn't. I ordered the Pollo alla Milanese that has received rave reviews here. Apparently, the kitchen was asleep at the wheel tonight, too. There was absolutely no white wine, lemon sauce on my chicken. Some had sunk into the chicken, but not enough to keep it from tasting dried out. The mixed vegetables consisted of two flavorless pieces of broccoli and one half white potato sliced. My husband's lasagne didn't even fill three-quarters of the dish and was drowning in sauce. My daughter's spaghetti and meatballs were cold.

Our server never asked once if we needed anything. I had to ask a second server to refill by daughter's water glass (her only drink) and bring us ketchup for my other daughter's fries. At one point, I tried to stop our server to ask for an additional glass of wine. "OK, OK, OK," he said over his shoulder. We never got the wine. This dinner took 90 minutes start to finish -- with only salads and the entrees, no desserts or even second drinks. After waiting 15 minutes for the check, I finally walked up to our server and asked him to bring it to us so I could get my 4 year old home to bed. "OK, OK, OK," he told me, again. Then he spent the next 5 minutes waiting on everyone else. I finally asked the hostess to please get it for us. Never once did the server even bother with a "sorry it's so busy" apology.

I've never left a penny tip. Tonight, I did. This restaurant sends its host or hostess out to recruit diners -- even when it can't handle the customers it already has. I suggest they train their host or hostess to backup as a server. Clearly, that's needed. Because I can guarantee that even if the owner paid for my meal next time, I still wouldn't come back here.
author: Ann P.

description: I shouldn't even give this place a 1 star but the waiter came out and apologized. We waited over an hour for a bowl of gnocchi that was cold and tasted like it just came out the freezer!! During our wait we were not offered another glass of water or even checked on to see if we needed anything.  I would not choose this place if looking for authentic Italian food in San Fran!
author: Heidi S.

description: Great date spot. Right in the center of North Beach and excellent italian/seafood. The owner speaks perfect italian and is from Rome. If you speak italian with him, he'll entertain you with some great stories. I never go here without ordering the lobster ravioli - highly recommended.
author: Erik D.

description: Awesome atmosphere and wonderful desserts (all that we had to eat).  The creme brulee could easily be the best I've ever had. The people working here are friendly and entertaining. I highly recommend coming to this gem if you're in North Beach! And don't pass up the dessert!
author: Jenny J.

description: Ugh. Not another bad experience! The fried calamari appetizer was lukewarm. The Caesar salad was bland, how do you screw up Caesar salad?! I need to know.. The gnocchi was undercooked and the sauce in which it was drowned was supposed to be pesto? It didn't taste like it at all. I noticed the guy next to us took a few bites of his and didn't seem to like it either. I hate to admit but I was suckered in by the guy in the ponytail too, I should have known better. I need to know.. Don't order the steak! Omg. I can't even put words together. I will say that the waiter was nice and sweet, I took a liking to him maybe because he looked like  a homeless Marc Anthony. I need to know...tell me baby girl cuz I need to know...
author: Comelona D.

description:
It's rare that I find myself frustrated enough with a negative experience that I'm willing to sit down and actually write a review.  I haven't written many.  It usually takes exceptionally poor service or unusually poor food.  Honestly, at times I've found myself willing to overlook one or the other, but certainly not at the same time.  Couple that with feeling gouged and you've earned yourself some personal time.  Honestly, how do you guys stay in business?  It must be the tourists, because frankly, I can't believe anyone would visit more than once.  

Like most of their customers, I imagine, my family and I found ourselves drawn in by the gentleman at the front door who asked if we "wanted to come in and try some his dad's cooking?"  Sure, a family owned restaurant?  We'd love to support that.  What followed was quite possibly the worst Italian food we've had in our lives.  Even our kids thought the food was cheap, bland and tasteless.  One after the other we each tried each other's meals, wondering if it was just us that ordered poorly.  Nope, disappointing across the board.  

Now it's quite possible that we just don't know what true Italian food tastes like, or that our standards are unreasonably high, but I don't think so.  I think we're very reasonable and a pretty fair judge of character.  As a matter of fact, we were all so bothered when we left that we followed a recommendation from a friend and walked up to the Nob Hill Café where we had some very good Italian, and great service too.  From our perspective, we certainly don't mind paying for quality food (or quality service) but get frustrated quickly when we feel like we're being "taken" and that's just how we felt while eating here.  

Honestly though, I would spare the review if it were just due to the food.  It looks like this place has earned mediocre reviews from other customers, which is probably in line with what you'll experience if you choose to eat here.  What truly earned the review was the response from the shill at the door as we walked by later, on our way home.  Not realizing that we had just eaten there earlier (and weren't particularly happy about it) he continued,  "Hey, want to try the best Italian in San Francisco?" "I grew up in this neighborhood."  "I'll put my reputation on it."

"No thanks," we replied.  "Honestly... we weren't that happy with it."  "Really," he replied.  "Well, too bad, we don't want you here anyway."  

Nice... very professional.  

Look, there are so many other choices available I'm just not sure why anyone would choose this one.  Don't take my word for it, just read the other reviews (like I should have done) before you commit.  The truth is probably somewhere in the middle.   

If this prompts some better service, or effort, then it's served its purpose.  If not, then consider your reputation established.
author: Yuri S.

description:
People who wrote bad reviews ordered the wrong thing - whamp whaahh.  I'll make it quick: 

(1) Tiramisu 
 comparable to favorite at Rulli's in Marin - outstanding!  Large portions for sharing, homemade, fresh European butter and cream you can feel from your lips to hips- 
*boom chicka-smack.*  Ladyfingers very spongy, just the right amount of chocolate, espresso and liquor.  

(2) Sambuca 
tender veal you can cut with a fork, covered in some pig, sage, European butter, lemon - goodness.  I left the Italian ham for pops but the veal was good.  Dad orders sambuca whenever he can and claims this is "one of the better," though not the best.  The best apparently is at some 5 star in Tahoe - I will take his word for it.  

(3) Vodka cream sauce
I like this here! I had it with the lobster ravioli- again.  

Note: homemade fresh pasta is the standard in little Italy - haven't had a pasta I didn't like here yet.  Everything is a bit above average here for a good price - sometimes that's what you want.  I wanted to share a quick meal with my pops, in sweats, in my neighborhood, without cooking.  My Dining Dough certificate was about to expire so we came here - good time and savings.  

TIP: even after tiramisu - skip two block up the street for a chocolate covered nutter butter - sure to impress.  Best to bring a friend and buy one when you're already full, so you don't lose control.
author: Rayna A.

description:
Probably one of the worst restaurants I've eaten at in a long time. Came here for a farewell dinner for a friend and knowing that it had 3 stars on yelp I had zero expectations. I also came on a night after the City view at the Metreon Yelp event so I was already satiated. I had no appetite for their complimentary bread so I used that time to digest. 

I ordered the penne with eggplant and it was not good. The eggplant tasted burnt and the penne and tomato sauce tastes like chef boyardi... 

My friend ordered a chicken dish that looked like fake chicken with an unappetizing white sauce. 

I can't believe the waiter asked us to write them a good review on Yelp as we were heading out, especially if he saw that some of our dishes were barely touched. 

Would not recommend this place at all!
author: Cindy L.

description:
As per Yelp's description of a 1-star rating: Eek! Methinks not.

Came here for an early dinner with friend. We were the 2nd table to be seated. First impression when I walked in: Why does it smell like a dirty foot? And I'm talking a nasty, dirty, smelly, old foot (would've walked out if it weren't for my friend's coupon she got on Restaurant.com).

Decor was a bit creepy...cherubs, weird face sculptures...everything looked like it had a good layer of dust on it.

I had seen on Yelp that they were offering a "Happy Hour" which included either a complimentary glass of wine or an appetizer. Neither my friend nor myself wanted either but at the same time, we were never offered. This normally wouldn't have bothered me except for the fact that after we were seated, they were HANDING glasses of wine to people as they were walking in AND giving them the free app.

We had the mussels for an app...meh. Then I had the carbonara which was flavorless. How can something with bacon be so bland? I mean, it's BACON! Well, they managed to do the impossible.

Slow service, unfriendly (where was the Italian charm that North Beach is so known for?), dismissive when we raised any questions or concerns. All around a poor experience.
author: Jasmyn M.

description: Great food., the staff is really nice.  A little crowded and the service is a little slow but that's probably because the food is so good and there's so much of it.
author: Shea K.

description: OK, this place is cool. The guy outside is the owner and his dad  makes all the pasta homemade. I'lf you're looking for old school, toe curlingly good Italian food, come here. Incredible service, food served quickly, priced well. Ask for Stefano!
author: Ally H.

description: Does not earn a single star but required to post. Tried this restaurant with a groupon so we were mot sure what we get but... Italian restaurant with the obligatory olive oil for dipping, however, as I was dipping and eating my bread I noted that the bottomed the olive oil container looked cloudy. Picked up the bottle looked at it from the bottom then tipped it but could not get a clear view so used a piece of bread and gross-  mold in the oil. The table next to us. .. same.  Disgusting!  We told one if the wait staff who took the bottle and never came back, we told our waiter and he did not seem to understand English suddenly.  All I'm dying is IF you are dirty enough to leave something like that in plain view then I am super concerned about other issues that may be worse or even dangerous. Stay away.
author: Charlene B.

description: The salmon pasta special was wonderful.  However, the pizza is worth skipping.  Very friendly staff and appreciative of your business.  Nice touch with the free cookies and gummy bears for dessert!
author: Jared F.

description:
We were walking up to US Restaurant when this man outside Michelangelo's said - "Beautiful ladies come inside, give you free glass of wine"  Um, ok!  

The staff, which was a lot for a small restuarant, was excellent!  Food kept coming and dishes were cleared and water was filled !  Our waiter was such a trip!  He was from Sicily and was very serious about their food and its peperation.  He was great and a bit scarry, lol! But he took very good care of us!  

The owner/man who offered us wine also gave us appetizers for free!
We had a lot of food and it was SO GOOD!

Pancetta w/Cantalope - Excellent!
Bruchetta - Tasty but I added more balsamic and it was perfect.  Plus the bread was still warm/toasty!

We also ordered Fried Calamari - YUM!  Their red sauce was amazing!  Not to heavily coated and HOT!

I ordered: Spaghetti and meatballs.  Holy Canoli!  It was the best I have ever had!  2 huge meatballs and perfectly cook pasta!  Oh and that red tomato sauce was just SO YUMMY!  I ate it all and I told DH he had to try the meatballs.  he said it was very good.  Friend #2 saw them and he ordered a side of meatballs and he agreed!

DH: Chicken Malese: He said it was prefectly cook chicken, the breading wasn't took thick and almost panko like.  He said it could of used more veggies as it came with a small portion of broccoli and roasted potatoes.  He also said he wished it came with some pasta.

Friend #1:  Spaghetti w.Clams in white sauce.  SO Many clams (in shell) she was so happy with it that she wanted to sop up the sauce with her bread.  

Friend #2:  Chicken Parmasan and a side of Meatballs.  He loved it!  Said it was such a great meal.  Love the crispy breading and the cheesey topping with every bite.  

We were so full from the food there was no way we were going to eat dessert!  BUT they brought out a plate of Amaretti cookies and a plate of Gummi Bears!  LOVE IT!!!  The cookies were great and fresh and the Gummi bears were delish!  I ate all the green ones! :)

We were so happy with our dinner we couldn't stop talking about it after we left.  We had happy full tummy's.  And I can't wait to go back to order the same thing!!!!

The bill came out to just over $100!  And that is with 2 sodas, since two of us had wine - that was REFILLED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I KNOW!
author: Erika G.

description: If only the food was as half good as the sales person getting you through the front door...
author: Marie B.

description: the serving was really bad but the food it's ok but so small portion. veal alla parmigiana tasted  like a banana and ravioli just six pieces and a lot sauce. the waiter didn't tell me the kitchen was closed.
author: Celia A.

description:
Michelangelo is one of the places in San Francisco where I am continually drawn to.  It might have to do with the fact that it is one of my first meals in San Francisco.

The food has been continually changing from ten years ago.  When I first I had their food, they were known for their mountains of seafood with their seafood pasta.  They changed it to be more regular portions during my second meal and the last time I have been there the portions are somewhere in between.

Yes, they now give you complimentary bruschetta, which is awesome.  No free wine for us though.  Gone are the giant bowls of gummi bears.  They now serve a little in a tiny plate.  Maybe too many people complained about the unsanitary situation.

In any case, good food in a familiar setting is always good.  Although it seems they have hired new waiters.  Service was a bit slow and one of the waiters just left a bowl of parmesan cheese on our table.  A little foible for an otherwise staple of the North Beach scene.
author: John H.

description: Wow. Worst meal I've ever had in San Francisco. They gave us a plate of gummy bears for dessert. The food was bland and terrible. Least I saved money on the tip.
author: Ben G.

description:
Went with a Groupon- waiter was rude (probably because of the groupon)


Food was bland with the exception of the seafood. Very strange sides- they served sliced potatoes and broccoli with pasta dishes! Veal parm taste like rubber. Probably the worst italian dinner I have ever had. 

The bill came out wrong as well and the waiter stood over us - rude.
author: Jesse T.

description:
Worst experience! the food is OK， maybe 3 stars，but the service is the worst I ever had. We went there with a groupon worth $67, but the owner told us that we need to pay $7 extra for any lamb/beef entree, which is not mentioned in the groupon at all. The owner is kind of rude and say he can't do the groupon deal says, but that is the deal he listed. Isn't this typical "bait and switch"? In the end, I paid the $7 extra but only tip them $0.49, even though I usually tip 20-25% of original price for an OK groupon deal.
Forget to mention the tiramisu is battered and there is a hair inside! :(
author: Mike W.

description: I was craving for rigatoni and passed 2 restaurant that made their own pasta but to me it was a little pricey.  So my friend and I walked by this restaurant and the hostess flagged us down and told us they had the best Italian food in there and is not expensive.  I told him I wanted rigatoni and he said they don't have it in their menu but they can make it.  So we decided to give it a try since the hostess was so encouraging.  I wasn't sure cause it didn't look or smelled  that good inside so I just decided to just order spaghetti and meatball..I so so regretted I ever went in there.  I have never tasted anything so bad worst than bland very unappealing I took one bite of noodle and meatball and pushed my plate aside.;The waiter never once asked if everything was ok and they were not busy.  Even the gummy bear was hard and the cookie was stale and hard.  I left and was very upset for the rest of the week cause I hat wasting money especially it makes me not want to eat at any italian restaurant anymore.  I dont want to break anyone rice bowl but do not do not eat there even if that was your last resource cause you will regret it and come out feeling like someone just got over you.
author: Lena S.

description:
These people that put this restaurant at a 1 star are fucking stupid.excuse my language .im full blooded Sicilian and I know good food when it comes to Italian food.

I'm reading these people saying after they ate here they threw up .dont Blame the food...STOP DRINK BEER AND HARD LIQORE.YOU DRUNK.THE PRICE AND FOOD AND PEOPLE ARE GREAT.I DRIVE ALL THE WAY FROM SAN JOSE WITCH IS 1 hour drive to have a great dinner there.
author: Fred M.

description: We came for lunch. The lovely hostess recommended the Cioppino which was an Italian seafood dish. Amazing quality. Service was leisurely. Pricing was very reasonable.
author: Bob K.

description:
We came here after discovering that Pasta Pomodor had closed down...Would have walked further to a more familar place but my shoes didn't allow the hike.

The people here were extremly friendly..but the food is mediocre at best. It fits the tourist trap profie...

The veal tasted a bit leathery..and lacked flavor..
The pasta was just okay...

p.s. I question the cleanliness of th place..the table, windows, and their menus look as if they haven't been washed for years...
author: Mimi T.

description: Terrible restaurant. The food was incredibly bland and looked disgusting. The service was incredibly rushed, and the decor inside was very dated and looked filthy. The waiters bashed our chairs multiple times without apology. Definitely would not recommend.
author: Ben C.

description:
I've been here a few times, the place is nice, has a view of the park and great glass lampshades all over the ceiling. The waiters are Italian and have accents, but that hasn't been a problem any of the times I've been there. One particularly slow lunch my friend and I overheard an English lesson going on between the staff at a back table. 

The portions are pretty spot-on, and the sauces are great. When I've been there they've been offering a free appetizer for the table and glasses of wine with entree order, which is fantastic for three working college kids looking for dinner in Little Italy.

The service has been good, the staff welcoming, and the food tasty.
author: Lee S.

description:
Had a card for a complimentary glass of wine and apply. Did not want the house wine so passed on that and was offered a free soda, which I took them up on. They then brought olives, bruschetta, and my Sprite to the table- free of charge before we even ordered our meal. Very kind of them. My friend had the Chicken Alla Valdostana: breast of chicken topped with fontina cheese and ham in a rosemary and white wine sauce. It was decent. I had the  fettuccine pasta with homemade meat sauce. It was decent as well, but a little bland. The service was good, the prices were average, and the atmosphere was nice. The best part of dinning at Michelangelo's is what is delivered with the bill- cookies & gummy bears! Who doesn't like gummy bears?  

For a more detailed review visit:
http://consumingcolumbus.blogspot.com/2013/03/michelangelos-ristorante-caffe.html
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Food was medicore-service was quite UNattentive. Not worthy of recommending other than the complimentary brischetta.
author: Lee P.

description: Wonderful service and food. My fiancé and I wandered into this restaurant 30 minutes to close, and the staff were all so warm and accommodating. We both had salads to start, and the food was obviously fresh and the dressings are made from scratch, even so close to closing time. The bread was also fresh and perfectly warm and cooked. We would HIGHLY recommend the crab and lobster ravioli and the tortellini. The pasta was made from scratch and the portions we perfect. All the staff are originally from Italy, and the chef Salvatore himself came to the table after we finished our meal to thank us for our patronage and to ensure we enjoyed all of our food. Massimo was our server, and personally made sure we knew a good way to walk to our hotel from the restaurant so that we would be safe. Best Italian food I've ever eaten.
author: Stephanie E.

description:
First of all, i would not have ever came here. But i had a 50 dollar certificate and needed to use it. I might be a 19 years old tiny asian girl but i know what good food tastes like. and believe me this restaurant didn't impressed me one bit.  The only thing i liked about the food there was their complimentary appetizer.  which was the marinated diced tomatoes on top of toasted bread. than they gave you this plain bread in a basket. I went there dinner time, around 8pm. and gosh that bread was stale. very hard to bite into. 

As an appetizer we ordered the calamari dish. it was lightly battered deep fried calamari with marinara sauce. The calamari was very tender and chewy, but it didn't have that crispy bite to it. and it sure didn't taste that fresh.

As a main course, I got the clam shrimp scallop mushroom fettuccine in some garlic tomato sauce. The sauce was way too creamy. It just made me feel like I gained 100 lbs. The scallops tasted like they've been frozen for years! the shrimp was pretty good and i didn't see or taste any clam. o.0 where the hell were my clams?!?! 

My boyfriend ordered the secondi veal dish with potato and broccoli.  oh yuck the broccoli tasted like it was just thawed or like boiled in sink water or something. the veal didn't have much taste to it, it was moist tho. the potatoes were pretty good. and the sauce isn't bad, it just felt cheap for a 19$ meal. 

So overall, this place is overpriced for the crappy food it serves. It's a no no in my book.  not to mention their portions are pretty damn small.
author: Winne L.

description:
One day a friend and I decided to walk around North Beath and check it out (we were actually checking out all the hot euro guys LOL) since the day was beautiful and sunny.  Then we ran in to Michelangelo, he was a pretty intense and it actually was around noonish.

So after talking to him we ended up sitting down grabbed a glass a wine and had a chit-chat, brushetta came out with some olives.  A second glass on the house came out so we look at each other and figure, I guess we're having lunch here.  Spaghetti bolognese and fetticini came along and another glass of wine.  The food wasn't absolutely amazing but the atmosphere was great. Next thing we know the sun was coming down as we polished down a few more glasses of wine.  

The bill came and $60... WOW. THANKS MICHELANGELO!!!!  A $20 Tip and we're off.

Lunch/Dinner with a whole lot of wine and good company...I heart North Beach (and the beautiful Euro guys).
author: Edrian D.

description: Went to Michelangelo's on a Groupon and it was great.  Waitress was wonderful, and she did know I had the Groupon from the get-go.  I had a fish dish that included clams, mussels, calamari, shrimp and scallops over spaghetti in a light tomato sauce.  It was delicious.  My girlfriend had chicken dish that was topped with a marsala sauce.  Also very good.  The appetizer and bread that we had were both tasty and well prepared.....  and the tiramasu, not too shabby !!  All in all, a great meal for the price....  And please, if you want to be treated well by the wait staff,,, tip on the full amount, not the Groupon amount...... That's only fair .....
author: Patrick C.

description:
This place was not what I expected it to be at all (not in a bad way.)  I just thought this was a really big and loud restaurant, like Buca, but it wasn't at all.  It's a fairly small and quiet restaurant.  The art displayed on the walls are great too.  All the employees are Italian, with Italian accents; it was pretty amusing.

The food was decent.  I ordered the Eggplant Parm, which wasn't terrible.  It wasn't amazing either, but I finished it all so you can say I enjoyed it.  The eggplant was sliced thin and layered with cheese in between each slice of eggplant, breaded and fried with a generous amount of tomato sauce on top.  I also got to try the tortellini, and two of the specials: lamb chops and flank steak.  The tortellini was my favorite dish.  It came in a delicious cream sauce, which was heavy but I didn't mind at all.  The lamb and steak were decent too.  Both were very tender, but they came in a wine sauce that I'm not too fond of.

At the end of the meal they served us cookies and gummy bears.  They also make fresh coffee to order.  If the food was a little better, this would be a great place.
author: Anthony N.

description:
If you are the kind of person who expects to be waited on hand and foot and is hella picky about service from an American point of view (i.e. a waiter at your table every ten minutes interrupting your conversation to make sure "everything is fine"), this is not your kind of restaurant. If you are looking for a hole in the wall Italian restaurant with great food, bread on the table, and an overall warm, delicious culinary experience at a reasonable price for the quality of the food, do yourself a favor and come here for dinner on a weekday. The place is not packed, the food will make you happy, and you will leave with a smile on your face. Also, complimentary marinated olives, red wine, and gummi bears. Can't wait to go back!


P.S. Their potato gnocchi in creamy pesto sauce are heavenly.
author: Ignacio I.

description: The service was great and one of the reasons we went in. The free bread was great and had a good taste. However the ravioli tasted like they were bought in a supermarket and not even fully cooked. Very disappointing. The sauce was fantastic but couldn't make up for what was missing. The pizza my friends ordered looked very small for the prize but didn't taste too bad. The place itself was nice and had the World Cup on which u enjoyed. They did seem weirded out that we didn't order anything but the pizza and ravioli. Maybe they are not used to poor college students? Not my first choice but it was fine that one time.
author: Annika W.

description: Tourist trap ...What do you expect if they hustle you in. .. followed test of por group against better instinct and had all my fears materialize: cheap may house wine, old bread, tasteless pata with cold scallops, mini portion for the milanese chicken. We had been promised no-pay if we didn't like the food but had eaten too much of it, basically because I didn't believe in that drivel anyhow. Lesión learned and confirmed. ... There are so many other great looking places around where we could have spent les money for better food.
author: C. V.

description:
My daughter & I were only in town for one day and power walked around town and wound up at Michaelangelos. The service was outstanding. My Pasta del Mar was perfect & actually way too much with scallops, shrimp, muscles, clams & fish. My daughter who eats like a bird not only finished her ravioli but wiped all of the sauce with the bread. The very handsome young man, part of the owners family, welcomed us in & offered us a complimentary app which was delicious bruschetta & black olives.
We also loved the almond cookies & candies that arrived with our check.

very good value not overpriced or stuffy. Will go back!
author: Joanna L.

description:
The owner stands outside trying to lure people in with the free wine, free bruschetta, and handing out his business card. I was told when I was in Italy, don't go into the restaurants that have an employee standing outside luring you in, a truly good restaurant would never need this and just spreads by word of mouth, its a sign of a tourist trap. This is no different.

Free wine? Free headache! They should have handed out aspirin with that house wine...I couldn't even finish half the glass. Food? Cold salmon and fairly flavorless. This is North Beach, and San Francisco!! Dont waste your time there is so much better food out there.
author: Faina G.

description:
In the sea of Italian restaurants in beautiful North Beach, Michelangelo fares pretty average yet it's solid. The menu is smaller and simpler than its competitors --- but their free bruschetta when you sit down is a major perk. As are the small bowls of gummy bears and amaretto cookies they send out with your check, if sweet's your thing.

I have eaten here many times over the years. Never a disappointment but never a wow either. I am still happy to come back and wait for it one day...
author: Meredith R.

description:
I'm noticing that really nice days on weekends are a bit of a rarity in San Francisco proper (especially having grown up and lived in Florida for most of my life), so I took advantage of the good weather this past Saturday and walked from Powell through Union Square and Chinatown over to North Beach in the mood for some pasta. 

Let me preface this by saying that I don't exactly have a refined palate; one of my favorite restaurants is The Olive Garden, and macaroni and cheese is my favorite food ever, in the history of ever, but I was lured in by the friendly Russian hostess with free bruschetta and a drink. Just so you know, if you don't want wine (I knew it would be cheap table wine), you can also get a free soda instead.

I asked the waiter for his recommendation on whether I should go with the spaghetti with homemade meatballs, the fettucini bolognese, or the lasagna. He advised the lasagna was the best option as it was homemade. 

The bruschetta came first on what appeared to be stale crostini, and there was just no flavor to it at all. It didn't appear as though the tomatoes were tossed with olive oil at all, there were barely any chiffonades of basil to be had, and I had to use the balsamic vinegar on the table to make it edible. He also brought bread (the crust was hard enough to cut the inside of my cheek), and marinated olives. All of this was free, so I wasn't really disappointed, but the lasagna took care of that.

When it arrived, it looked like it might be decent, but any "lasagna" that was there was buried in a bland tomato sauce and not at all aided by the powdery grated parmesan that topped it. In fact, Lean Cuisine (hell, even Michelina's) makes better lasagna, and that's saying something. I had to fish around for any meat, and it appeared to be all sauce, no substance. It didn't even feel like there were layers, just a few square noodles swimming in sauce with a dab of ricotta and a piece or two of bland meat. If this was the waiter's recommendation, I'd hate to see how bad the spaghetti or fettucini bolognese would have turned out.

I needed to see if dessert could redeem this meal and at least end it on a good note, and fortunately it did. The tiramisu is excellent, and that's exactly why this place gets a second star. The portion was generous, and I find that the best tiramisus always leave a finish of amaretto at the end of the bite, and this one did. If only the lasagna could hold up as well as the mascarpone and lady fingers in this dish!

At the end of the meal, the waiter brought out almond cookies and gummy bears, and I was still hungry enough to eat the gummy bears, which were pretty good.

1 star for the server, 1 star for the tiramisu. Even with the free appetizer and drink, I still ended up with a bill of 22 dollars before tip for a delicious tiramisu and a lasagna so bad that Chef Boyardee would have thrown his hands up in disgust. 

In an area that prides itself on good Italian food as much as North Beach does, I've surmised the only reason this place stays open is because of unsuspecting tourists and first-timing locals enticed by freebies. Don't make the same mistake.
author: Josh J.

description: Omg I really loved this place! Great people, they convinced us with a free glass of wine, for four people, food was amazing! I ordered the lobster ravioli and so yummy! Kids loved their spaghetti. When they didn't finish it, we asked for a box. They tossed it on accident, but then they made us a new batch to go! Got two rounds of gummy bears and cookies at the end! If we come to Frisco again, we will come by here for sure! Great staff!
author: Connie V.

description:
It's my first Italian restaurant in San Francisco, North Beach, and i like the small space. I like the service. I had the 'Gnocchi di patate' I like the bread and the Italian olives at the begging. Also the gummy bears and cookies. I wanted to taste the Gnocchi because as I an Italian wanted to try Gnocchi from a restaurant and I believe they were good. i enjoyed the atmosphere and the Italian music and art of the place. I left $2 of tips.
But there are better places that i've experienced  like È tutto Qua!
author: Nadav M.

description:
Italian food couldn't be any worse.... And the service was no different.

THE FOOD
--French bread- Cold, stale, and tough as cardboard
--Complimentarty Bruschetta- A flavorless tomato topping served on a     
   rock hard version of the same stale bread. 
--Fettucine- Bland
--Cioppino- Bland!
--Veal Portobello- Bland!!
--Salmon- Bland!!!
--Complimentary dessert- Really now, gummy bears and commercially 
   prepared amaretto cookies? As IF you could be any tackier!

THE SERVICE
Racist, condescending assholes. The owner/greeter asked us if we bought the discount gift certificates just because we're asian and our waiter mocked my parents for having mispronounced their orders.

Never again, Michelangelo. NEVER AGAIN.
author: Colleen W.

description: I was visiting on SF & became very I'll with the stomach flu. My traveling companions came upon this place. They were looking for chicken soup for me. The owner made me a care package of chicken broth, noodles & wonderful bread while they had a marvellous meal. My friend had the salmon which she described as perfect. The food and personalized service was awesome.
author: Teri S.

description: Food was good, but the chef was a little rude when we asked if we could basically get another mug for sharing a cup of coffee.  He also seemed in a hurry to hand us the check.
author: Ankit C.

description: I was there on Saturday afternoon (Jan 31 '15) I only stopped to have a dessert and a glass of prosecco. I ordered a dessert of two chocolates, like a mousse. I can't look up the menu online so I can't write down what it was called but it was so good. There was a topping of creamy white chocolate and the remainder of the dessert was milk chocolate in a beautiful glass bowl. Inside the chocolate was crumbled cookie. Delicate flavor of chocolate with not too much sweet. Perfect texture too. Outstanding!!!  I'm glad we ordered one to share because I could have eaten the whole thing to myself. What a darling little place and I was even able to practice my Italian with the waiter - just a little.
author: Valeri P.

description:
Had a really nice Sunday lunch at Michelangelo's after spending a weekend in the city with the family.  Our original plan was to go to Cinecitta around the corner but when we showed up, the owner explained she had the restaurant fully booked for a party.  Lucky for us, Michelangelo's was happy to have us.  Solid Italian fare and family-friendly service.

Food:
I started with the carpaccio, because I am unable to pass it up whenever I see it on a menu.  Served with crust bread and a drizzle of olive oil, it was very good.  My next course was the papardelle with meat ragu, which is my favorite pasta.  Hearty and filling but not heavy, and the ragu was well-balanced (not too acidic).  Pasta was made fresh (and I know so because I saw the cook portioning and rolling the dough as I walked back past he kitchen to use the mens room).  
The missus ordered the orrechiette, which is one of her faves, and she was quite happy.  She didn't offer me a tatse, so it must have been good! The kids enjoyed their cheese pizza (shocker).  I think it would be challenging to find a bad dish on the menu. We enjoyed a bottle of the house Sangiovese as well, which was a nice treat. And gummy bears and amaretti cookies are complimentary at the end of the meal.  Really nice touch.

Service:
Extremely accommodating, especially when my kids wanted their own little two-top table rather than sit with us adults.  Our server was a sweetheart and took great care of us. Maybe it's cliche, but I really did feel like part of the family here.

Vibe:
Like visiting your Italian aunt's house - you know, the aunt who is the same age as your parents, but she's so cool that you always introduced your girlfriend to her first.  Well, now imagine that aunt was a rockstar cook.  Being here is comfortable and great, just like that. 

Family-friendly:
Definitely was for lunch.  Probably would be for dinner, too, but it would be more fun to enjoy Michelangelo's sans rugrats.  

Summary:
The only thing keeping me from giving this place five stars is that I have only been here once and I've eaten a lot of Italian food.  Go to Michelangelo's, choose your favorite pasta, and enjoy how well they prepare it for you.  It will make your belly happy.
author: Aneesh B.

description: The homemade gnocchi tasted good, caesar salad had good lemon flavor, clam pasta was average, staff were friendly, decoration was interesting, but we were shocked at the end to witness that they recycled bread (moving one piece left in a basket into another basket to be served again), and the almond cookies and gummy bears that came with the check (dumped back into separate containers). Maybe because these are free items but it is simply unsanitary! They also stacked the plates for the gummy and cookies collected from customers to be reused again. My husband and I left feeling disgusted and hoping that we wouldn't get sick from other people's germs. Luckily we didn't get sick but we wouldn't go back. At least we were able to see what happened this time. It's scary to think about what goes on behind closed doors at any restaurant!
author: K. S.

description: This place makes me so happy! Anyone who has a negative opinion couldn't possibly have spent time in Italy. This restaurant is no frills, incredible food, and authentic ambience. If I close my eyes? I'm back in Firenze! Ciao!
author: Brittany M.

description:
I don't usually like to write bad reviews but this one simply I have to.
I was actually scared. The guy was rude, scary looking with missing teeth, got angry when we asked to taste the wine, spilled sauce on my jacket then didn't apologize. The only decent food we had was the free desert, second hand gummy bears that I'm sure are full of germs.
More than a tourist trap it could be your life at stake.
author: Marcel C.

description:
So last week (Tuesday) my sister and I walked from her apartment in Nob Hill to North Beach for dinner.

It was late (for Tuesday, 8pm), we were tired, and we had no idea what we wanted, except we are eating meat-free for Lent.

We had passed on nearly every menu on Columbus st when we reached Michelangelo's at the end. It was literally empty. The gentleman at the door promised us a glass of free wine, and that if we hated it he would buy our dinner. I was tired, he was giving me wine, I WAS SOLD.

We were apprehensive but decided we'd make the best of it.

Bottom line: an hour later, we'd had bruschetta, olives, amazing garlic bread, wine, THE BEST EGGPLANT PARMIGIANA IN THE WHOLE WORLD, amazing gnocchi in pesto, and delicious little ameretti cookies. We were literally waving down potential patrons if they paused at the door and promising them that they would not regret their decision to eat here. 

I would come here again and again. It was perfect. Great service, perfect portion size, food was fresh and flavorful, tasted like I had suddenly found a long-lost Italian grandma.
author: Liz L.

description:
We had a late meal here after enjoying Beach Blanket Babylon. The complimentary bruschetta, bread and olives were tasty. Service was friendly and quick. The gnocchi pesto was cooked perfectly...not mushy. The penne alla Norma was also quite tasty. Tiramisu and chocolate truffle desserts provided a sweet end to the meal. Also enjoyed the amaretto cookies. 

Enjoyed talking with the owner, who brings a wonderful authenticity to the restaurant. You really feel the Italian heritage here.

Molto bene!
author: Jeff H.

description:
I hardly write reviews but I was so upset by my experience here that I felt inclined to say something. One star for food that was mediocre, at best, and terrible service. 

I was here with my boyfriend during the North Beach Festival because the lines for food were insane and this place wasn't crowded and seemed decent. One of the waiters was outside promoting the restaurant and promised a free bruschetta appetizer. We never got it. My boyfriend ordered the spaghetti and meatballs, the portion was a nice size. I ordered the cheese ravioli and when it came out I stared at it for a good 2 minutes before poking at it. I hardly call what I got a portion, the 7 small pieces of ravioli wear spread out on the plate to make it look like there was more and the sauce was sparse. I decided to be nice and just eat since I was starving. I couldn't even enjoy it since the pasta was still hard, I'm a fan of al-dente but this stuff needed to be cooked for at least another 5 minutes. 

Two girls sat next to us and ordered the ravioli. They received bruschetta and a full plate of ravioli, with over flowing sauce. 

I didn't want to be negative so I never complained. I noticed that everyone got gummy bears and cookies when the check came. We AGAIN never got any. Was it because we were Asian? 

I have never been so disappointed in my life. Least to say, I'll never be back and I'm making damn sure none of my friends eat there.
author: Krystle A.

description: We were visiting San Francisco and wanted Italian, so walked up Columbus looking for a good place. We were lured into Michaelangelos from a guy outside, and though we had our doubts due to this and due to it being really empty, we went here for dinner. Although the waiter tried to make it seem that he was giving us special appetizers "on the house", it was very obvious that they gave the same free appetizers to everyone. However, free bruschetta, olives, and a bigass bread basket is still totally worth it! Our meals were delicious too - amazing tortellini and spaghetti with seafood. One of the servers was the owner, which was impressive, everyone was very attentive. Then, we ordered a tortufo that was HUGE and also got free cookies and gummy bears. Delicious! And for an amazingly low price!! We loved the food, service, free apps, and ambiance. Would come back again!
author: Martha S.

description:
We walked in out of the rain on Christmas day and literally within seconds we were seated with glasses of water, a plate of Italian biscuits, and a bowl of candy. 

The brulle' and the profireroles were hand made and absolutely delicious. The coffee was strong and syruppy, with a good crema, a fruity body, and good aftertaste -  little hotter than it should have been but nice nonetheless. The decor was very... well... Italian

If you are looking for a true Italian experience, this is it.

Good find...
author: Andrew V.

description:
My friends and I were walking along North Beach looking for a good, not super expensive Italian restaurant to dine at. After passing several fancy restaurants we noticed Michelangelo's-- mainly because there was a guy standing out front (presumably the owner) telling us to come inside to enjoy some wine on the house and grab a bite to eat. We shrugged our shoulders, and walked right on in. Who can say no to free vino? The server brought us each a glass of wine and some bruschetta, bread, and dipping oil with balsamic. Yum! That's a way to start a meal! I really enjoyed the complimentary appetizers.

I ordered the gnocchi with bolognese sauce (~$14 or so). I also tried some of my friend's appetizer, the carpaccio which was rather delicious. Our food came out pretty quickly which was nice. My gnocchi was pretty good, but I kind of wished I had ordered something a bit lighter. It was very heavy, and not particularly amazing. The sauce was very good though. During the meal the server accidentally spilled red wine all over myself, and my new shirt. It was an accident, of course, and he was incredibly sorry. I seriously didn't care, and the wine came out of my shirt after a good wash, but the server made up for it anyways but bringing us a complimentary tiramasu, a plate of cookies, and some gummy bears.

I enjoyed eating here because the staff was so lovely and accommodating. I'd come back here again and probably order something else.
author: Ashley D.

description:
I cant believe this place has anything higher than 3 stars. 

We were pulled in on the street by the owner with a sirens lure of a free entree and glass of wine. 
I was cursing my natural cheapskate tendencies when I discovered that our free entree ONLY included bruschetta. BAD bruschetta, it was 2 crusty pieces of baguette with unripe tomatoes and one shred of wilted basil. NOT good, we didnt eat it. 

The olives they served at the beginning of the meal were good, and the bread and olive oil was standard, but completely passable. 
That's about where the good things ended for us. 

The pumpkin ravioli was disgusting ($15), it had almost raw pumpkin in it. 
The pesto gnocchi was bland and boring. 

Service was bad, they never once refilled my iced tea and wouldnt look at me when I tried catching their eye to ask.
author: Jessica B.

description: It was late we just caught the showing of "Beach Blanket Babylon" enticed off the street to come in.  What amazing people that work/own this place. It was late we were the last people there and were treated like royalty!!! We shared a dinner of Pasta bolonese that was so fresh and tasted amazing!  The view of the beautiful Catholic Church all lite up in the back ground was breath taking! We had the opportunity to talk extensively with the staff who were so warm and easy going. Not at any point did we feel rushed even though they were closed! Luv luv loved this place!  Go check it out!
author: Joanna H.

description:
We tried their bruscetta and decided to go in after walking past countless Italian restaurants. Needless to say, we settled. We ordered the Sicilia and some other dish pasta dish where I forgot the name. When we asked for recommendations, it was one of those, "Oh, everything is good here" suggestions and pointed to the most expensive dish in that section. Seriously? We also ordered a side of Mediterranean salad. They brought out bread which was super hard. Hurt my teeth to chew. We received our pastas which was mediocre, but the waitress completely forgot about our salad. When it came out, I might as well have made it at home. They used the same dressing that you can buy at grocery store's, Litehouse's Pear Gorgonzola dressing; thus, the cheese is from the bottle. The serving was really small for 8 dollars. 
   
 A group came in for dinner and our waitress was hastily trying to pack our food after we asked for the check. The hospitality definitely ended there and she rudely tried to get us out of there with her body language. 
  
 The pasta dishes ranges for about 15 dollars average. 

 
After reading the previous reviews, what is all this talk about free wine, gummi bears, and amarettos?! WE DID NOT GET SUCH!!  After that experience, I would like some complimentary items.
author: Becky Q.

description: YUMMM.. you must order the homemade lasagna and gnocchi! It was absolutely wonderful. The owner was so thoughtful and we immediately felt very welcome! I have never left a restaurant so happy. I will DEFINITELY be coming back soon to get my Italian fix :)
author: Danielle G.

description:
Another one of those nostalgic places I was introduced to because of my handing over power to arrange my birthday party to someone else.

Back in 2007, it was my birthday at some point. At that point, I came to this place. We drank a lot of wine, and I look around me at all forms of Italian gargoyles seeming to infest the walls like gold in a Vatican City chapel.

Then they brought me tiramisu and sang happy birthday to me in Italian.

Last night, I went again. It was somebody else's birthday. A 21 year old girl. I thought to myself: "Is there a birthday party here every night?" There very well could be.

So, someone other than me thinks/thought it was a good idea to have a birthday party here. I mean, the photo ops, if you can get just the right lighting at night, will be well-received on facebook for their originality.

The wait staff is pretty much on your side. You will probably see every piece of wait staff come by your table to make sure everything is copasetic. The owner will even come by. And you'll get quite a handful of stuff "on the house" here.

Though you won't be underfed, I'm simply just not impressed by the food itself. I had a Fettucini Bolognese and my dining partner the breaded chicken. Hers was better, very lean, hammer-flattened chicken with lemon. Mine kind of tasted like "starving college Chef Boyardee" sustenance. It's not that that's bad, but just not very flavorful.

It's hard to believe that a restaurant can get 4 stars with 2 star food. But it's just how I *felt* here. With the room packed, and plenty of flamboyant wall pieces to look at and have staring contests with, you don't feel like you're missing the action in North Beach but that you *are* it. Worth trying. I'd like to know if anyone had a dish here that they'd consider amazing, however, because I could have just gotten the wrong thing.
author: Davey R.

description: The food was pretty decent. Not delicious though. The guy who runs this place is such a sweet man. The service was really good. There is just one waiter and it is him. Yet he some how manages to attend to every guest. Hes really kind and got us everything we needed. He might need to hire some help though because he was running around like crazy! The food was pretty plain nothing special.
author: Ano M.

description:
The waiter made the huge mistake of saying their lasagna was "guaranteed, best in the city"

Ugh. Anytime someone says they're the best, it's like you've set yourself up for a royal fail.

Plus he really didn't need to spend the entire time reading the specials off a menu that we were facing head on from our window seat. After reciting 15 menu specials, which he needed to keep glancing over my shoulder to read off to us, it got awkward.

Also another culprit of bad wine selection. My lasagna was truly terrible.

The gummi bears at the end is the only thing that saves them, aside from being open late and easy-going. But not sure I'd come back after that not so promising dish embellishment.
author: Alita M.

description: I have my favorite Italian Restaurant (Enzo's) here at home in Portland, Oregon and I would have to say that Michelangelo's is my favorite in San Francisco.  Granted, I have not tried any others, but I like to go where I know the food will be delicious.  This was our second time in a span of about 7 months. The Tiramisu is divine and the complementary Amaretto Cookies and Gummy Bears are a plus.
author: Michele C.

description:
We had gift certificates from Costco and read the Yelp reviews so weren't really sure what to expect. Came with a group of 6 and had a really great time.

The food was solid - everyone enjoyed themselves and I had no complaints. Lots of freebies came out which was nice - bruschetta, olives, cheese at the beginning and amaretto cookies and gummy bears for dessert. 

Service was friendly and attentive. Atmosphere was busy since we came on a Friday. All the colorful glass lamps on the ceiling were neat to look at. 

Prices seem in the middle for what you'd see around North Beach. Would go again.
author: Allison R.

description: This place is the pits. We have been living in the area for 6 years and thought we'd finally give it a try. Well what a waste of money!!!! The guy outside sold us with the promise of free bruschetta and a guarantee of good food but what a lie cause we got neither. Go to Franchino instead and get a good meal. I got the chicken Milanese and it was horrible. Never again. I wish there was a zero star rating.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
I've been trying out all the restaurants in little Italy and came across a no restrictions listed $25 for $40 groupon for this one. 

Pros: 

the food had medium portion sizes and was decent. Nothing noteworthy and nothing to make it stand out from other restaurants in the area 

Cons: 

First thing I noticed were all the gnats flying around. 

No soap in the bathrooms--which I find disgusting 

Finally for the reason for my one star review--when we showed what appeared to be the owner or maybe a manager the groupon we had he told us we should have showed the groupon when we first came in. We apologized. He could have said he couldn't honor it or if he could he should just leave it at that. But before we could say anything else the man started yelling at us (which was embarassing to say the least) what he had to say was relatively unintelligible--apparently he jacks up the price of the menu items for groupon users and repetitively ranted about how he's losing money but he won't  redo the check because he had already rung it up. He slammed the check down on the table and told us we were NEVER to do it again. We sat there open mouthed and shocked as we watched him storm away. Oh. Don't worry. We won't be back. I'm used to poor service but it is never excusable to yell at a customer like that. And if a groupon makes you lose money why offer it? 

There are better restaurants in the area. I'd avoid this one, but if you do still go make sure you don't use a groupon (which from the man's rant doesn't seem like you'll get much of a discount from anyway)
author: Sylvia W.

description:
Ahhhhhh, where do I begin? So we're trolling North Beach for some pizza, and we stop to look at the menu in the window.
