Like a bird of prey, Michelangelo swoops down (literally since he's like 12 feet tall) and makes us an "offer we can't refuse." Free wine. Diabolical. I can't refuse free alcohol anything. Free appetizer too? "Do you have pizza?" 

"Yeah, yeah, we have pizza. It's so amazing, it's not on the menu."

Really? Ok, why not? We go in and are served our free glasses of wine. Michelangelo comes out and declares, "Two glasses of Italian wine!" Well, that's nice, but most cheap table wine comes from Italy, and that's exactly what this was. I looked around and noticed a lot of tourists. (Like us) Then with the free wine in front of us, shit, we were trapped! Snared in this tourist trap like fish in a net.

Funny sculptures. I suppose they were Michelangelo-like. Then the lights started to change colors and the Happy Birthday song came on in Italian. Suddenly we are transported into an Italian disco, then Michelangelo comes out with a little cake in his mafia coat. He really is the king of this kingdom. I looked at my girlfriend. She looked back, and her eyes said "Are we in the Twilight Zone?"

Turns out they only had one kind of pizza. A 12 dollar, 12 inch margarita, and it was small. We also ordered the beef carpaccio. Unsatisfying. Plus it was expensive. We left feeling hungry and if it weren't for the free wine, ripped off. As we left we there was Michelangelo out front, catching more tourists. Like a bear catching salmon. I guess we all gotta make a living.
author: Brian C.

description:
I went to this place in North Beach with my Auncle Sammy when he came for his annual SF visit. He told me he comes every year knowing that he must get there Gnocchi.

It feels like this is family owned and you feel like someone's grandma is making you dinner versus some of the bigger places that Columbus has to offer.The Gnocchi that my uncle ordered was so light. I'll make homemade gnocchi at home for special occasions. I thought mine were pretty good but this place kills it! Their like little potato cheese clouds. I got the Lobster Ravioli in Pink Cream Sauce. It was really yum. Not all that heavy either. My Auncle's step-son (well not yet but pretty much) got the Veal Parmigiana I think. Gotta love the Veal. No one left disappointed and the staff even helped us out with a photo op.
author: Amanda R.

description: My husband and I went out to the city to get away from the little town I live in. Naturally when I chose I place i check out yelp and the do a little drive by. They were busy when we went so we figured it would be good since there were a lot of customers. My husband got a lasagna and I got a pepperoni pizza, the pizza was just outright disgusting. The sauce lacked flavor and spice the pepperoni wasn't cooked all the way and was cold and greasy. The lasagna had the same sauce as the pizza and it was flavorless and came out cold. Honestly I don't go out to bash restaurants bc I own one myself and I cook and have a 5 star yelp but this place was just unacceptable. Like who doesn't taste their food before sending it out of a kitchen. I know I won't be coming back here ever again. Not to mention those stale gummy bears and the nasty ginger snaps they serve to "cleanse" your pallet. Ummmm,.. No
author: Victoria H.

description:
I loved this restaurant's vibe. Service was fantastic, and I was comped a glass of wine, little plate of olives, and bruschetta appetizer. This is not a place to go if you want to be a food snob or a critic, it's where you go to feel happy, smile at the friendly staff, and eat delicious food.

With the bill, they brought out a plate of gummy bears and amaretto cookies, which I think sums up the restaurant perfectly; Michelangelo's is a casual restaurant with a relaxed atmosphere, thin forks, great service and warming, tasty food. Your seafood might come out slightly overcooked, but what the hell the sauce was great, it's not very expensive, the service fantastic, and it was a nice meal overall.
author: Jen N.

description: I haven't been back here for years and the last time I remembered the food it was yummy. Many many years later, I can say the quality went down. The flavor wasn't as bold or great as before. We had the bruscetta for it was so basic that I can do a better job at home!
author: Nhung T.

description: While certainly not the best Italian around, I had a rather decent meal here. The menu looked good (very classic Italian) so we decided to eat here on the sidewalk. The decor and feel is certainly old school Italian. Yes, the Bruschetta was not the best, bland just like everyone says (I mean come on, salt & garlic at least?) and the wait staff was rather brusque Italian, but otherwise it was a pleasant meal. I had lobster ravioli that were pretty good and the Caesar was very good. I think my date had Veal and it wasn't the greatest but not too bad. Overall not the best restaurant in North Beach, but decent in my experience.
author: Jeff S.

description: Pappardelle Alla Boscaiola was hot and fresh. Cioppino was HUGE
author: A A.

description:
Fantastic Lobster Ravioli 

I was with a friend at the North Beach Farmers market on Sunday. When we started making our way to Union Square, We passed this quaint little place. 

We where offered a free glass of wine if we had lunch. I'm not one to turn down free anything, so we decided to give it a try. It was fantastic. 

My friend had the shrimp, and Asparagus past it was grate too. 

Highly recommend.
author: Carmen H.

description: Got lured in as well...even being on expenses. The house wine was very drinkable.  Service friendly and good.  Had the lamb chop special- nice quality on the meat...I'm from the midwest and pretty particular about the chewiness.  All in all a very enjoyable meal.
author: Andrea M.

description: Amazing place!  Food was awesome!  We had the lamb and a pasta they made special for us!  The lamb was perfectly cooked and the pasta was dreamy!  Wonderful wine and. Tiramisu as well!
author: Joy D.

description: The worst restaurant in town . If you want to get sick eat here . Vomited all night after eating in this garbage dump !
author: ST F.

description:
Michelangelo, appears in the front in his mafia-resembling get-up and talks to passersby on the street inviting them to eat at his restaurant--thats how we got hooked. He swears his tiramisu is "The BEST in the World!" (apparently both my friend and partner agreed with this statement after eating it).

4 Stars because the customer service is excellent, you get a rose on Sundays, and a free glass of wine with your meal. However, the waitress sort of forgot about us around dessert--but otherwise the service was most excellent. 

I'd say the food was somewhere between 3 and 4 stars, some stuff being 4 (squid salad, deserts, appetizers) and other stuff being 3 (butternut squash raviolis and lasagna).

They get minus one star because the price is not worth the experience. The food and freebies are still not worth the total price of what it cost us to eat there. If the food was a consistent 4-5 stars, I'd agree it was worth it, but the food isn't quite there (But you must know I am an Italian food snob). 

Overall, I'd go back there but probably not if I found a restaurant that was one up in North Beach....I'll continue on my exploration of amazing Italian food...
author: Jen C.

description:
Absolutely loved this place! My friends were walking around searching for good eats when a nice lady offered us a free appetizer and each a free glass of wine.... How could we say no? 

The food was great, the wine was great, the atmosphere was amazing, the waiter seemed rushed/stressed.

I wish that more place enticed foodies in the way that they do!

Definitely would go here again!
author: Adam K.

description: The food was over priced and horrible. service was horrible the waiter was rude and would not check on us . Restaurant is small. If you have.a group on they don't appreciate it and will find ways to charge fees .
author: Omar M.

description: The host is a very nice man that persuaded us to eat there and he made our night. The food was excellent. My grandmother was from Italy and my mom uses her recipes to make dinner every night so I know real Italian food and this place has it. The service was even better than the food and the owner it's the chef who was born and raised in Italy. This place is defiantly a must try and you will want to come back.
author: Katelynn D.

description:
We went back here a couple of times since the last review and I just remembered to finish this.

The feel of this place is completely different than when we first started going. I don't know if it's different owners or what, but they always want to seat everyone right in the little odd shaped corner near the window. Seriously, I would have preferred to sit further back in the restaurant but they told us it wasn't open. Sure, you have 5 or 6 tables all squeezed into the size of walk-in closet and everyone gets jostled around, why open up more?

The service was pretty sucky. It took them literally F-O-R-E-V-E-R to get us food. I was reaching that point when I wanted to leave, when they brought out bread for us. Followed by a longer period where we got a appetizer. One. (1). Single. It took 10-years for one dish? WTF?! No one else had come in the restaurant yet and it felt like they were taking their time. We even asked to get whatever my daughter ordered first before appetizers or anything. Of course, her food came with everyone else's later on, but by then, she was hella pissed and getting to be handful who just wanted to leave. The food came and it wasn't anything to write home about. The price? SOOOOOOO much more than you ever need to spend on lunch for 3 people and a toddler.

Go over to Bocce's for a much better experience. My previous post said we first went 6 years ago and still go back. Not anymore.
author: Chris B.

description:
This place was absolutely PERFECT for what my out-of-town friend and I were looking for last night.

I work downtown and live in the East Bay so I am not too familiar with other areas of the city, but I had heard North Beach has amazing Italian food.  We wandered around and checked out different menus, but this place seemed perfectly quaint and the prices were great.  Two people outside were passing out cards for a free appetizer and wine, so that just sealed the deal!  The atmosphere was great, the people were incredibly courteous and welcoming, and not to mention the food was delicious.

I ordered the Lobster Ravioli with a creamy tomato sauce.  Yum!   My friend ordered the Gnocchi.  We were both incredibly happy with our choices.  The free bruschetta appetizer was also just perfect.  The bread wasn't too crunchy and it was just very tasty.  The wine was great too!  Although I have never met a wine I didn't like.

The final little touch that we both appreciated was the complimentary gummy bears and cookies at the end of our meal.  What a fun way to end the experience!

I would most definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a cute and not to mention delicious pasta place in the city.
author: Alissa A.

description: Best food in Little Italy and phenomenal service. I was wandering looking for a place for dinner and the greeter invited me in offering a free glass of wine (red or white). When I sat down he decided to give me the best bruschetta I've ever had, on the house. I had the pappardelle which was phenomenal. All the staff have Italian accents, adding to the authenticity. One of my best dining experiences in San Francisco.
author: Drew S.

description: I've been here multiple times. I'm always a little disappointed to see the owner(?) outside the door trying to herd people to come in, because I'm not sure they need it - they are a good place on their own and it's always packed when I'm there. I love the atmosphere and decor, unusual and beautiful. The food is so-so. We keep getting the carpaccio appetizer and it keeps coming out half frozen. The pasta dishes are cooked to perfection! but the sauces are a little bland. The best thing on the menu is the tiramisu - it's fantastic and I've never had another this good! We have tried several of the wines off the list, and they're all delicious. The gummy bears at the end of the meal are unexpected and a treat. I enjoy the wait staff and have not had any negative experiences with them - they're amicable, know the food, and are fast. Overall, certainly not the best place in town for Italian, but reliable for a nice meal.
author: Convict T.

description: Best Italian food I have ever had in my entire life and probably one of the best restraints I've ever been too. The waiters are extremely nice. I even learned that Fettuccine Alfredo is not Italian but American.
author: Callum M.

description: Had the gnocchi bolognese and it was amazing, my boyfriend had the fettuccini and it was also very good. Service was outstanding, I don't understand 3 stars at all.
author: Ann J.

description: Came here for a quick lunch and was pleasantly surprised. The hostess was friendly and attentive. Olives, bread and oil were served as I waited for my meal. I had the special carbonara which was a delicious, generous serve. I would definitely recommend.
author: Amalia C.

description:
Although we were having a hard time finding ANYONE to give us a table for 6 on a Saturday night, Michelangelo was empty enough to seat us.

This should have been our first warning sign.

The fact that it took them 30 minutes to serve us ANYTHING was time wasted where we could have stood in line somewhere else.

The service was extremely lackluster, and unapologetic.  The food quality was very poor.  I think it's hard to mess up calimari, but they managed to create the most ineffective appetizer in the world.  My friend's pasta was still crunchy.....my salad was limp.....and the free almond cookies and gummy bears for desert is insulting.
author: L L.

description:
This is my goto Italian restaurant. After years and years of eating here the prices remain reasonable and the food is consistently excellent. Just solid simple food. The Scampi in my eyes, are unbeaten.  The shrimp, scallop, and  fettucine in a tomato cream sauce and pesto pastas are also excellent. They pass around a full wheel of Parmigiano while you're waiting (or even while you're eating) and at the end of your meal they produce a huge bowl of Gummy Bears and a plate of amaretto cookies.

Anyone who walks in is treated as if they were a long time customer and the wait staff are friendly and lively. Sure this place can get overrun with people, local and tourists alike, but the wait is rarely very long and it keeps the place bustling. The ambiance is like an Italian art gallery gone mad which is amplified by the wedged shape corner space that it occupies. Intimate enough for a date (if you can get a corner table), relaxed enough for a few friends, or boisterous enough for a huge party.
author: Kim N.

description:
Phenomenal! We were lured in by the friendly owner...Michelangelo and yes, he had me with his description of the Gorgonzola gnocchi. 

My high maintenance sister and a few friends took up Michelangelo's offer for free wine and bruschetta. My sister ordered our special dish with the owner went back to over see....Pappardel pasta, arrabiata sauce with sauteed mushrooms and eggplant topped with mozzarella. The dish far exceeded our expectations as did the friendly staff and personal service. Definitely a vegetarian's delight! We also ordered the gnocchi which they served as appetizers...one with the Gorgonzola pesto sauce and the other (of course) arrabiata! Our friends ordered pasta with shrimp and the veal which they said was exceptional! 

I highly recommend trying Michelangelo and don't be afraid to mix it up and go off the menu!
author: Gita P.

description: Bad food, tight place where you'll more than likely get bumped, had a Costco deal for 50% off and still not worth my time.
author: Minh H.

description:
A gluten-free friend and I were lured into this tourist trap on Columbus by a kind young gentleman who promised us complimentary red wine.  Nothing gets my attention like free alcohol.  And candy.

Michelangelo offered no gluten-free options pasta-wise, but the fettuccine mari e monti met my dietary needs and my friend tells me the lamb special was pretty tasty (the waiter was even thoughtful enough to replace the potatoes with broccoli).  

Bonuses:
-- Complimentary bruschetta
-- Complimentary digestifs included gummi bears and amaretto cookies

Bottom line: it's Italian, not rocket science.  Unless you're Olive Garden or Pasta Pomodoro, you're probably some kind of yummy.
author: Michelle W.

description: This place serves Real Italian Food.  There's no BS about it.  It's a family owned restaurant, and the whole family does the cooking and serving.  Very friendly service plus the food is really good.  They will keep on feeding you until you say "Check Please".  They gave us 2 glasses of Red Wine and Bruschetta for FREE with bread, olives, cookies & gummy bears!  We ordered 2 dishes - spaghetti with meatballs which I could not stop eating, and my daughter ordered the carbonara....Delicious!!!
author: M C.

description: U can make this pasta exactly same at home. Or better. They put too much white wine into Vogole. Ask 4times to get a check. Nice one. In short: if you're desperately hungry, not bad; if you want to go out and eat good food, go somewhere else
author: Sujeong L.

description: Friendly, attentive service, authentic and tasty food! Complimentary antipasti and dessert!
author: Jr D.

description: This place is amazing. I came here for my Birthday with my partner on a groupon and couldn't have had a better night. We got the best service I have seen yet in San Francisco (I have been living here for 7months). The staff were welcoming and the food was delicious, not to mention the portions are huge, great value for money and plenty of little treats throughout the dinner....5 stars I will be back!!!!
author: Lynne B.

description: Food was ok.....The Gnocchi alla pesto needed more basil in the Pesto...our waiter seemed annoyed with our party of 6....seemed more interested in being elsewhere as opposed to recommending any entrees or describing a particular dish...was not attentive to our table even though the place was not busy....we got more attention from the bus boy than from the waiter.
author: Ricky C.

description:
For the number of Italian restaurants in the North Beach district (approximately...millions), this one wouldn't make the cut for me. It's really close to where I live, so me and my roommate tried it when we first moved in because it was nice and close (and didn't have a wait at 7pm on a Saturday night! That should have been a fore-warning...).

I had their seafood pasta in marinara sauce, it was just mediocre. It had shrimp, clams, mussels, and calamari. Nothing bad about it, but nothing memorable either, I took half of it home. Had it been REALLY good, there definitely would not have been leftovers. When I think about it, I think I actually might prefer Buca di Beppo's Frutti de Mare pasta over this one, and considering the fact that Buca is a chain restaurant...well, that says something right there.

A few highlights:
- They serve their bread with olives, which I think is pretty standard for Italian restaurants in NB, but it was something I enjoyed.
- They serve cookies and gummy bears to every table at the end of their meal. We saw the gummy bears as we were being seated and figured the family had brought them for their kids. Slightly sad, but those gummy bears were probably the highlight of my meal.
author: Nicole W.

description:
I'm conflicted here. Because on one hand, the pasta itself was subpar, and there are about a bagillion similarly priced restaurants within a one-block radius with excellent pasta. HOWEVER, the meal also came with so many complimentary items that it was hard not to be charmed -- free glass of wine, delicious bread and olives, bruschetta, and cookies/gummy bears for dessert -- all free!

I'm a sucker for free. But don't go if you're craving good pasta.
author: Sarah B.

description:
My friends and I were looking for some italian food in North Beach. We walked past Michelangelo's and they lured us in with the free "appetizers" and wine. The place is super tiny and we were sat at a long table with another party. I ended up sitting in the wash area and had waiters bump into me every five seconds. Since I was on the end of the table near the wash room, they kept putting dirty dishes right next to me and leaving them there. It was disgusting. 

The food quality was fairly poor. I order the lobster ravioli and it was nothing special. Then they brought us dry cookies and a plate of gummy bears with the check. 

Overall: Terrible experience and will not be returning.
author: Rosie G.

description: Wonderful owner, true Italian waiters, it is the real deal!
author: Lori F.

description: Food was ok. Not bad but not much flavor on the veal. Service was good. Place was dirty especially the bathroom.  Lots of very good places around there they need to step it up.  Pasta dishes are best here. Cookies and gummy bears nice touch and had the most flavor
author: Steve N.

description: Got pasta carbonara. Food was ok. Service was good. I'm fact it's the first restaurant in North Beach where owner wasn't rude  :-)
author: Vladimir P.

description:
"Darling!! I love your dress! Come inside - have a glass of wine!"
Please and thank you! How can a girl turn that down? Boost my ego AND add alcohol in the equation? yes!

Owner and staff is EXTREMELY friendly. So happy and funny. The bread is BOMB. Love the fettucini and I am such a fan of their lasagna- soooo yummy! Great salad as well. 

At the end of lunch/dinner you're given a ton of gummy bears! My weakness. LOVE IT!
author: Amanda S.

description: I have been here several times over the last few years and this place has been consistently excellent. I have had many pasta dishes, all great. The veal piccata is really yummy! My personal favorite. I have taken my son and daughter here on different occasions. Once, hundreds of Santas walked down the street past the restaurant and waved at us. Surreal. My husband and I dined here about a month ago and had the best desserts! Very friendly service and the place is beautiful. The wine is also fabulous. We will definitely return soon!
author: Candace K.

description:
So food wise, it's just ok. But the service is nice and they are open LATE which is a huge plus, especially when you're exhausted and need a bowl of pasta to warm you.

Bonus points for gummy bears.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Disclaimer, I'm going to steal some of my thoughts from another review I wrote on Caesar's (down the road, very similar)

If you are not a tourist and can even remotely call yourself a foodie, please do not consider visiting this place. If you have never traveled in your life, enjoy places like Friday's, Red Lobster, and Olive Garden, then you will enjoy this place.

It is touristy over-priced "Italian" at it's most classic.

I moved to North Beach over a year ago, and am on a quest to sift through all the touristy crap in the area. I had a personal disdain for restaurants that call themselves Italian just to make a quick buck by charging $20 for pasta and a plain tomato sauce.

One thing that should have scared me away from the beginning was the sketchy man outside, "Hey free glass of wine with dinner". So... wtf mate.

Gummy bears at the end of the meal? No that is not a nice touch. I'll head to Walgreens when I want gummy bears.

I don't even remember what I had as it likely isn't worth critiquing. Suffice to say this is a touristy "Italian" restaurant that does not even remotely serve gourmet food.
author: Alex L.

description: The worst restaurant in all of San Francisco. They offer you a free glass of wine with dinner which should be the first alarming sign. The food is bland and looks like its from the frozen aisle of your grocery store. I had never been more disappointed from a restaurant from the service, to the bread, the watered down wine, oh yeah and the food. If you need someone to stand outside your restaurant and lure you in, you know your food lacks. This restaurant is a tourist trap, you're better off going to Olive Garden or some other Italian chain. Save your money.
author: Taylor S.

description: Well, I don't even know where to begin with this review. While standing at the door outside waiting for a party to walk out, there was a waiter standing next to me also waiting. Once the doorway was finally open for us to walk in I was expecting the waiter to allow me, the customer and the lady, to walk in first but no he didn't, he simply walked directly in front of me as if I was just a wall. Then we were seated and had water slammed down onto our table, not to mention the cup was only half full. So, after about ten-fifteen minutes of waiting and watching other tables next to us get served, I finally spoke up and asked the original waiter from the door to please serve us, of course he politely did. I ordered the lasagna, it was horrendous. To say the least, this place is in a dark corner and that's exactly where it should stay, if not go out of business.
author: Hayley A.

description: Hmmm.  The best meal we had in 2012 was here but things have changed since then.  Our meal the other night (Feb 2013) was really hit and miss.  Some things were great and some things should not have been put on the table, such as the small bowl of mostly rotted olives.  Scant portions of the gnocchi dishes; not worth the price tag!  The deserts were good.  The server was attentive.  The bill was an expensive pain for what we actually received.  I am sorry to write this about a neighborhood restaurant.
author: D G.

description: On a slow Monday evening, the doorway hawker here painted a rosy picture of this place: everything fresh and homemade, the owner himself is cooking tonight, free glass of wine. So we eventually returned and were seated. Our waiter--perhaps the owner, judging by his slightly pompous air and authentic accent--seemed impatient with our questions, but lightened up later. I had the chicken marsala with potatoes and broccoli. It was good, not great. Others in my group had ravioli, which they commented might have been made by the owner--last week. So overall, it wasn't great, but I'm not sure any of these tourist-oriented places on this stretch of Columbus are what you'd call "great." But I didn't feel ripped off, if that accounts for anything.
author: Bob N.

description: The food was very bland.  My husband penne had very little sauce. My ravioli was okay. The service was not good. Our server never came back to see how our food was. After serving us he asked if we wanted Parmesan cheese and we said yes and left the bowl on the table next to us so we served ourselves, strange. So disappointed!
author: Connie J.

description:
Old-fashioned decor with compelling plaster-of-Paris copies of traditional Italian sculpture. Sculpture is nice looking, but too large for the small space. 

We started with a Cesare salad -- worst I've ever had. This disgracefully sad dish, with nearly brown iceberg lettuce, used mostly the white part, rather than the green leaves. 

My friend's raviolis, covered with an otherworldly bright red-orange sauce, were filed with cheese. I tried one and could only eat half -- the taste was very off. My dish was spaghetti with a generous serving of clams. The clams were good, but the spaghetti was unremarkable -- just okay.

The Chianti was nondescript. The chocolate dessert was pretty good. 

On a positive note, the service was very good, but there appears to be an overall lack of pride in the product put on the table.
author: Dave J.

description: Michelangelo is our favorite Italian restaurant in North Beach.  Cozy with the best Italian food!  We ride the motorcycle from the East Bay all the way there just for their seafood pasta!
author: Linda C.

description: Rude and pushy service, seems desperate!  Been here a few times bc I live in the neighborhood and hates it every time.  The food is over priced and lacks flavor.  My sister-in-law got sick once from there.  Never agin!
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Great food, excellent service, super nice staff.

I went to Little Italy with some friends, looking for some lunch. We were checking at the menu at Michelangelo's when the owner came out and started talking to us about his food, so we decided to check it out. Now, as a vegan I couldn't find anything I could eat on the menu besides one salad, but the owner was so nice and accommodating, and he offered to make a special vegan sandwich just for me, even adding asparagus though it wasn't really supposed to be offered. The food was great, and the complimentary bruscetta and italian soda were superb. Definitely going back.
author: Paige L.

description:
finally used the Groupon.  I bought it because I've always loved the place and as usual, it didn't disappoint.  

Food:  I like everything on the menu.  The Exotic Bomba is my favorite.

View:  The Coit Tower and the Chapel where Marilyn Monroe and Joe DiMaggio got married.
author: Mari C.

description: Either this place as changed or I've changed, but I remember really liking the place. The pasta tasted like dried boxed pasta and the sauce was bland. Service was good. Not worth the price.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Unfortunately, we must have caught this one at a bad time.  A teenager, not the owner, was outside with the aforementioned get a free glass of wine and appetizer for eating with us.  We had scanned a few streets for some Italian on our Little Italy visit and thought this was a good deal.  We should have known better. 

I had to ask for the wine.  They brought out fresh bread and olives, which was great, but we asked four times for the appetizer between the busboy and the waiter.  They kept having to "go ask" if it would be ok.  Finally, they told us that the deal was only for dinner.  When we pointed out to them that we ate there because of the deal AND showed them right on their printed card that it said "lunch or dinner", the waiter went to "ask" again.  He then told us they can't make bruschetta, the appetizer, for lunch.  Really????  Bread, tomato and basil?  You can't do that?  We said, "ok, what's the substitute?"  Again, he pushed back!  Finally, he came back 15 minutes later with bruschetta after we had our meals.  

Ugh.  I had spaghetti and meatballs, and it was truly forgettable, but I ate it all as I was on a vacation budget.  My wife had a ravioli with mushrooms that she didn't like, and she loves mushrooms.  Also, we didn't get the gummi bears.  

Fail.
author: Eric S.

description:
Great Customer Service!
Got greeted by a lovely staff and a handshake by the owner.
Complementary glass of wine with bruschetta and olives.
Good food, homemade gnocchi and lasagna.
Reasonable priced, cookies and gummy bears give the final touch!
Will definitely go again.
author: Coni F.

description: I really enjoyed dinner there. I don't consider this restaurant pricey. It is average price in the north beach area. Attentive service was a plus.
author: Lu G.

description:
I was with a group of friends when I walked past this joint and we were, apparently, mistaken for tourists. The owner offered a free glass of wine and bruschetta and, essentially, manipulated the group into dining at his not-so-fine establishment against my better judgment.

Let's start with the free wine. It was jug wine. It had to be. Four dollar wine from Target is better than this. Box wine is better than this. I tried my own white and my wife's red. The white was bland and watery while the red was bitter and vinegary. I've had better wine out of a paper bag during a frat party. Despite the fact that it must have cost the house a dollar per gallon, we only got a half glass of free wine. One of my group ordered another glass (again, a half-glass) for SIX DOLLARS. Six dollars a glass for jug wine. No thanks.

The bread was day-old supermarket bread: chewy and stale. The oil and vinegar were average and contained in tacky ikea-style containers. The appetizer olives were soggy (downright mushy, actually) and bland. I didn't touch the bruschetta, it didn't look appetizing at all and tomatoes were not in season. 

I was immediately shocked at the prices. When I pay 13-15 dollars for pasta, I expect to be in a pretty nice place. This was not a nice place. It was tacky, decorated without rhyme or reason. We were obviously not paying for the atmosphere, so I assumed the food had to be amazing to justify the price. You know what they say happens when you assume...

I ordered the spaghetti carbonara (which the waiter, who was likely the owner's son, quaintly described as spaghetti with cream sauce and italian bacon) and my wife ordered the ravioli. I don't know how else to put this: the carbonara was Pasta Roni. You know, the San Francisco treat? This was not a treat. The noodles were obviously out of a box and the sauce was runny and had very little flavor. Instead of fresh pancetta, the carbonara was filled with sliced grocery story bacon. It wasn't even crispy! Don't get me wrong, I ate it. I was hungry. If it WAS pasta roni, I'd have eaten that too. However, I wouldn't have paid THIRTEEN DOLLARS for it.

According to my wife, the sauce on her ravioli was good, but the raviolis were not fresh or hand stuffed. She got the distinct impression that they were the same as the ones you get in a large bag in the frozen foods section of Costco. Seriously. She was also pretty sure the sauce on the ravioli was so good because she'd had it before: as the Trader Joe's brand Vodka Sauce. 

I'd like to take a moment to mention the salad my friends ordered. It was butter lettuce, sliced tomato, sliced cucumber and balsamic vinegar. It was the kind of salad I got with a school lunch when I was a kid, minus the ranch dressing. Gag-worthy.

At the end, we were given cookies and gummy bears on a plate. I like gummy bears. Gummy bears are great. At any other restaurant, the gummy bears would have been adorable. At a restaurant that clearly doesn't care about the quality, flavor or preparation of their food, they are clearly a cheap gimmick to amuse tourists. 

On the bright side, the owner and waiters were friendly and pleasant enough. Considering the fact that we were conned into entering the restaurant in the first place, I'm more inclined to believe that the friendliness was equally insincere.

I'm no snob, but in a city where you can find cheap and/or gourmet food on the cheap almost anywhere you go, there is no excuse to have a restaurant this bad. Fast food chains have food better than this. Taco trucks have food WAY better than this. I'd have been happier with a burrito or a slice of pizza and paid 1/5 of the price. I can make bad food at home, I don't need to empty my wallet for it. If I could give this place 0 stars, I would. This is as bad as it gets; the worst italian restaurant I've ever been to, in any city.
author: Benny B.

description: I was super excited to eat some Italian food in the North Beach district as I am from New Jersey and miss the restaurants in Little Italy in New York that I grew up eating in.  The service and atmosphere was fantastic, the food tasted delicious. Overall we had a wonderful, romantic meal.  Then the next day I spent 15 hours throwing up every 10 minutes from food poisoning from the shrimp and clam pasta that we had. Since I was so sick and couldn't be moved we had to stay an extra night in town and pay $200 extra for the room we had on a Friday night and weren't able to finish visiting with our friends from out of state that we had come down to see. That meal completely ruined our trip and had me feeling like I was going to die for the day.  Horrible experience. Do not eat there, and if you do, definitely don't have the seafood.
author: Jessica M.

description: A disgusting spot in SF I have ever had. Horrible, bland and expensive food with a terrible staff that are yelling over your head and while they are serving you. And when you see the chefs, you will get even more disgusted. Restaurant is unsanitary, a big bowl of cheese is passed around the entire store for customers to add on their food. Everyone breathing on it and touching the same spoon and it sits on the side without being covered. This place needs to be shut down.
author: G H.

description:
Typical of Little Italy, this tiny Columbus Avenue restaurant was packed with as many tables as one could possibly fit. Charming, actually.  My friend and I got lured in by their hard-selling immigrant hostess, who offered a free appetizer and glass of wine (perhaps a promotion during North Beach Festival? Maybe a regular thing?)

We ordered one but got TWO small glasses of wine (decided to just keep them), the appetizer, split an entree and finished off with complimentary plate of gummy bears (not kidding). 

There was a hair in our calamari, for which the waiter profusely apologized, shaking his head in embarrassment every time he came by the table. It became funny and made up for their lacking English [They had some trouble understanding my order for ONE glass of wine, and later for packaging both items in one box (they tossed one of them), etc] 

Without asking, the server charged us what I expected, considering the situation: 2 free glasses of wine to fulfill their promotion, comp the appetizer because of the hair, and full price on the dinner. So we paid 13bux (justice? above and beyond!) and tipped on what should've been a $37's bill (already inexpensive for the level of quality/service).

So the food was excellent. I've worked in this industry for 5yrs and can overlook a hair (which got fried and just as decontaminated as the seafood, so who cares?)  BTW, the thorough bussing (more like server's assistants here) and quick food running were top notch.  Impressively on point, unlike most amateurs I encounter while dining out.

The experience was more than pretty good. Things weren't perfect, but were handled perfect-ly.  I will have to come back sometime for a full dinner and probably update my rating to a deserving 5 stars.
author: David D.

description:
Friendly place that appears to be family owned and has gluten free pasta.

Prices were very reasonable for the quality of food in San Francisco. The house salad was a nice mix of bib lettuce and the bread was as good as it gets. Everyone at our table of 7 enjoyed their meal and we would go back. Not touristy like down by the pier.
author: darren l.

description: My wife and I live in the neighborhood, so we try and dine at all of the local restaurants.  We were sorely disappointed in this place.  There are so many good, authentic Italian restaurants in the area, so this one seemed out of place.  The staff was friendly, they offered us a card for a free glass of wine & bruschetta upon entry, but the wine was cheap, the bruschetta was below average, and the overpriced dinner were nothing more than a grocery store frozen dinner.  Walk south another block, spend another $10, and get a delicious meal and great glass of wine elsewhere.
author: Chad G.

description:
I had friend visiting and being from the East Bay had no idea where to go.  My friend asked the limo driver  at Union Square (who solicited us off the street and overcharged us ) for a good non touristy restaurant in North Beach.  This is where he took us.

The wine list was very small and not good.  The bruschetta appetizer was good and the the tomatoes were tasty. The house salad was not great. 

The entrees were decent.   I had a pasta  dish with red sauce, sausage, olives and mushrooms that was really good.  Friends did not finish their ravioli... I don't think it was good.   The food was really hot (temperature wise). 
They do bring desert ( amaretto cookies and gummie bears).  We also ordered a desert to share and coffee .   The price was good.... $180 plus tax  for dinner for 8 (4 moms and their daughters )  with a bottle of inexpensive but ok  wine. 

It was solid  but not super fancy.
author: anne l.

description: Nice atmosphere! The service was very friendly, fast and swift! Worth checking out this place, the free bruschetta, bread, olives, cookies and gummy bears were a nice bonus. Definitely try the calamari and the caprese salad and tiramisu. They are delicious.
author: Tom T.

description: I wish I could have enjoyed my experience here better. The pasta (I ordered the seafood) was something I could have made better hungover. The tomato sauce was super watered down and the portions were tiny for the price. Sadface.
author: Alex M.

description: I ate here on a Groupon and had a great time. I'd go back without the Groupon.  If you are looking for white linen fine dining then go elsewhere. For a clean, tasty and  reasonably priced ($15-$19 per plate) Italian dinner I really enjoyed this place. The restaurant is located right across from the park in the center of North Beach.   I called for reservations and Tony said to just come by and ask for him. I showed up a few minutes late and Tony was there to greet me on the sidewalk by name. He got me a good seat and even though I was on the Groupon he asked the chef to send out some Bruschetta for me while I waited for my fiance. This was in addition to the olives and endless bread. He then kept an eye out for her as she was arriving by bike and greeted her by name as she pulled up. We had an enjoyable bottle of Sangiovese, Ceasar, eggplant parm and a chicken dish with fontina and ham that was very good.  The white chocolate/dark chocolate dessert cup is fantastic and I'd call it a must order dessert.  At the end of the meal we were surprised with gummy bears and cookies on the house. Throughout the meal we chatted with Tony and the staff, learned about the history of the place and North Beach.  It was a very personal dining experience. If you want to be  left alone and dine in solitude I'm sure that's an option but where Michelangelo's shined was good priced, good tasting food with a fun bit of socializing with the crew.  Some have commented on the idea of someone working the sidewalk as pushy.  I like that there is someone who wants to bring you in and while you are eating wants to make sure it lives up to the billing he gave it. I like that the owner is there and the people working feel a sense of ownership and pride in the place.  I'll take that over a restaurant the staff just shows up to work at and goes home with nothing personally invested but time.
author: Sean R.

description: My sister was visiting me from out of the country and ate here while in the city.  When she told me about her experience I was very upset.  Aside from the food being served cold when they were leaving they asked the Maitre D for directions to Union Square.  He told them to walk straight up Union St and it would take them to Union Square.  Well anyone who knows the city knows that this is not true.  They got extremely lost.  They were on foot and had to hire a cab to take them back to their hotel.  I thought that this was not very nice at all.  This may be due to the fact that they complained about the food being served cold. Anyways we would not recommend this restaurant at all.
author: Mari M.

description:
We were walking around, looking for a delicious but not expensive Italian restaurant for dinner one night. We walked by MIchelangelo Caffe, and a girl outside offered us a free glass of wine with our dinner. That should have already tipped us off....

The food was awful and the furthest thing from authentic Italian we have ever had. The wine was even worse, and was most likely from a jug of Carlo Rossi in the back.

We will never eat here again. It was a sad, sad meal....
author: Emm P.

description:
A friend and I just stopped by here for espresso at about 4:30 on a Friday.  The espresso was actually quite good, but everything else about this place just kind of rubbed me the wrong way.  Yes, the owner was standing outside the door could be seen as charming and personal, but trying to drag people in off the street for dinner at 4:30 struck me as a bit over-aggressive.  Because of the hard sell, his offer of a free glass of wine and an appetizer with your meal seemed less like a deal and more like an act of desperation.

Sure, I could be wrong, and the food could be outstanding.  However, I'll leave that for someone else to prove.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
I remembered i came to this place last year. A gentleman is standing outside, and i looked around at the menu and he offered me a glass of wine for free.. Cool. Little did I know, He is the owner.
I don't even remember the name of this restaurant until last night. This place is pack last night.and price is reasonable too,
This restaurant for sure will come back for more.. Their pasta is great and server are friendly.
author: Thomas L.

description: During my last visit here, the menus smelled really gross, like they were wiped down with a dirty, wet cloth. Yea, a little bit of an appetite killer. For what it's worth, the first time I came here I didn't have that problem, but then again that was almost 3 years ago. The restaurant is pretty inside! had the spinach ravioli and our attentive waiter let me have it in pesto sauce instead. The bf had the Spaghetti alla Carbonara. That night they were giving tables bruschetta on the house, and they give you a complimentary plate of gummi bears and almond cookies at the end of your meal, which is a pleasant surprise. Nothing stand out about the food though; when you're in North Beach surrounded by Italian eateries the standards are higher so Michelangelo just falls in the middle range for me.
author: Caralisa L.

description:
Came here for some dessert and espresso after E Tutto Qua. 

They give you a plate of gummy bears to start off. Hahaha. Having such a sweet tooth, I love this concept. I'll always remember them for that. 

We had a chocolate cake thing and I think creme brulee. Just what I needed :)
Oh and they were nice enough to plug my dying phone in
author: Lola D.

description: Great food and service. I've been to all of the Italian restaurants in North Beach and this was wonderful. Bruschetta was perfectly tasty, eggplant parmesan was perfectly prepared with wonderful sauce. Tortellini was also very tasty. I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I dinned here 7 years ago with 6 people.  We were walking around North Beach looking for an authentic goo italian restaurant and were reeled in by the chef.  My sister in law thought the chef was funny and the food was ok.

Fast forward 4 years and I wandered in there again with my sister's family and mine, again for 6 people.  Im not sure if it was the same chef but the food was one step above a pizza place.

Fast forward another 3 years and I accidentally fall in here again.  This time the worst and I will never be back.  Aside from food being average the portions are the smallest I have ever seen in my life.  Even my 10 year old nephew who ate spaghetti and clam sauce asked if we ordered him a child's portion.  I had the same and the amount of pasta was about 3 fork fulls.

The waiter was a complete ass.  Stay well clear of here.

P.S. I worked in Italian restaurants and was in the business for 20 plus years.
author: Marc H.

description: Service was fast and friendly.  Prices are moderate.  Food was pretty good (spaghetti alla carbonara, spaghetti with meat balls, pasta with shrimp and clams) except the croutons in my Caesar salad were more squishy than crunchy.  The cappuccino looked good but they used coffee that seemed a bit stale.  Honestly, while other restaurants nearby in North Beach may have better reviews, we were just too hungry to wait in line, with some restaurants completely packed.  At Michelangelo's, we were seated immediately and immediately were able to order drinks and then quickly got our food as well.  The restaurant was about half full, at about 6 PM on a Sunday.  Looking at the other reviews, I can see there is a lot of variability in what people experienced, but we really got the feeling they were trying hard to please.
author: James B.

description:
My teacher-dar should have rung when I saw the owner approached me on Columbus Ave and offered me a free glass of wine and a good meal here. Alright, if you're willing to put the effort to get customers, I'll give it a try especially when I'm hungry at around 8pm on a Thursday. 

First, the bread. It was plenty but it was cold! What is with restaurants and their cold bread...throw it in the oven for a few minutes at least! 

The wine was just disappointing...I should have just stuck with the water. 

Almost everything on the menu was overpriced. My veal parmigiana was something that I make at home. The dish was $15.95, while the rest of the menu was at least around $17-19. The presentation wasn't even that good! 

After taking my order, my waitress was never to be seen again. I asked for the bill and it came by itself, without the cookies and gummy bears that I saw another couple had. Only because the lady in that couples had said it was the best cookie ever did I stay to see if they offered me some. After about $5 minutes of waiting, it did came. Errr....it was okay cookies. 

$20 including tax and tip out the door...and let that door close completely for me!
author: Kenny L.

description: I love this place! Everything that I tried I loved. Best Italian food I've had since my favorite Italian restaurant in Dallas, Tx closed 15 years ago! Hospitality was great. Perfect package of good food, good wine, and friendly staff. This will be my go to place for fantastic Italian food in San Francisco from now on.
author: Xaviera S.

description:
Hey, how come I didn't get a free glass of wine?

After reading all these reviews post-dinner, I think we missed out on a little treat.  But no big deal.

The waiters are all very nice and for once, I actually think everyone working there, including the bus boys, were Italians.  California is such a melting pot that it is not unusual to see a Mexican working in a Chinese restaurant.  Anyways, I'm getting off track here.

We only had entrees and both were good.  Portions are not super large, nor are they tiny.  If you're hungry+, order more up front.  

This place is very well lit, so please don't come here if you're looking for a romantic dinner.

In terms of Italian restaurants in North Beach, this is okay, but nothing to go out of your way for.
author: Darren C.

description: Do not go to this place if you have a groupon!!!  They do not tell you the specials, and only give you two options for dessert . Only two of the three people in our group were using the groupon. They did not give the addition person any extra options.  The table next to ours that came in as we were fixing to leave got the full wam bam...   The food was ok not fantastic but ok.
author: Krista K.

description:
I'd give them 2.5 stARRRs, but I'll round up for the free glass of wine.  Our friends took us here for a long overdue catch-up dinner, mainly because they love getting free wine and gummi bears and not having to fight for a table.  Check.  Service was OK.  Check.

The decor is a bit over the top and the food was underwhelming.  Not just for North Beach, or San Francisco as a whole, but even in comparison to somewhere like the Olive Garden.  (And I will very rarely say to myself, "We should've gone to the Olive Garden.")  It didn't kill me, and it was only a dinner, but you could still do better.
author: Andi T.

description: My new favorite place to eat in San Fran!! I was there performing at Cobbs Comedy club, we brought the entire cast 2 nights in a row that's all anyone wanted! Homemade pasta, bolognaise, vodka sauce, bruschetta, and tirramasu were the best I've ever had! And they really took care of us treated us like royalty, felt like family, just didn't want to leave:) can't wait to go back!
author: Priscilla T.

description: Yummy food! Great service! The free wine was ok, but it was free! We had calamari, caesar salad, spaghetti and meatballs and pizza.... All of it was good!
author: chris n.

description:
Went to To Michelangelo Caffe to have dinner last week and I had the worst experience ever. They offered me a free glass of wine which tasted like vinagar, the waiter ignored us and the place was half empty. Ordered the lazania and as I walked to the restroom I had to pass by the kitchen and seen the cook smoking over the stove, and thought , isn't that a health hazard? So when I got out of the restroom I Peeked back in the kitchen again and seen the cook taking the Lazania out of the microwave, and I was saying to myself ,that better not be mine. right after I sat down the waiter brought me my lazania and I asked him did that just come out of the microwave, I got my order way to fast and he said they don't use a microwave oven, this is an athentic italian restaurant. So I played it off rather than make a big deal out of it. The Lazania was hard on the outside and lukewarm in the middle in the middle,
It was the worst lazania I have ever eaten, mater a fact I took 2 bites and didn't eat any more. The waiter didn't even ask me if everything was ok he just took my plate and said nothing, because he knew that I knew he lied to me, So because I found out about them nuking the Lazania they tried to rush me out of the restaraunt and didn't even offer if I wanted to order desert. My date just ordered a salad and it was like eating pure oil that was just pored over the top. She didn't eat that as well.

It seamed they were upset about me questioning what I saw in the kitchen.

I can tell you this, I will never eat there again and people should really be aware of ashes in the food from the cook whos is the owner, smoking over the stove.
This place should be reviewed by the health department.

This restaurant used to be good but has seriouslly went down hill.

I will not ever be back and was so embarrased for my date to bring her to a such a place were they use a microwave to heat their food!
author: Keith B.

description:
They lured my momma and me in with the free rose. They got my dad with the complimentary bread and the vinegar/oil.

All in all, we were thoroughly pleased with the place. We probably would have kept walking if the guy hadn't jumped at us with menu's.

The food is cheap but delicious and in large portions. My momma had the salmon and spinach and I had the pasta.
author: Victoria Y.

description:
I came here with some friends for my birthday dinner. i made reservations earlier in the day so when we got there we were immediately seated.  however, they did one of those things where you share a long table with different parties and on the side we were sitting on, there was a party of like 6 college kids drinking wine and being super rowdy.  they were really bugging me but it was alright because they left midway between our meal.  so they give you complementary appetizer things like a marinated tomatoes on crunchy bread. really good. and their pastas are like reallllly good haha i got the Fettuccine Mari E Monti with no mushrooms and it was amazing good but really filling so i asked them to box up the rest of it to-go. later when i went to eat the leftovers, i saw that they didnt even put all of it in the box, especially the seafood.. 
so my friends told the waitress it was my birthday as we got seated. after dinner, the lights dimmed all of the sudden and they started playing happy birthday music over the whole restaurant and they brought out a tiramisu cake with a candle for me. it was honestly so surprising and cute! i loved it!
plus they give you gummy bears and cookies with the bill!
author: Ariel C.

description:
Great location across from Washington Park, good for the tourists.

Went with a friend and his wife while in town on a business trip.  

I got the spaghetti with clams in red sauce.  It was very good food. Prior to the dinner we were provided kalamata olives, bruschetta and bread as normal fare, no extra cost.  And it was excellent too!

While it is a small restaurant, nothing special with regard to decor, the atmosphere is good, the food great, and the location is a winner as well.  

Give it a try.
author: Bill B.

description:
We have eaten here before, the food is never great, but the location is convenient and the prices are low.   However we will never come here again after the way we were treated on our last visit. They don't take reservations so when we arrived we asked how long the wait was, and the girl at the front told us 5 min - which sounded right as we could see the table they were setting up. When we told her we had a baby she checked with the manager and then told us she had been mistaken and the wait would now be 30 min. Then the manager told us it would be 1.5 hours. Clearly with that attitude they don't welcome families, which is obnoxious as this isn't a quiet place.

I would take my business elsewhere - there are plenty of great places that are in the same price range but feature family friendly service including Capps and some of the other places on Columbus.
author: Boris G.

description:
Michaelangelo Ristorante & Caffe
579 Columbus
San Francisco, CA 94133
"Good North Beach Value"
We were passing by the restaurant and a nice, young person offered us a free glass of wine (and bruschetta) if we stopped in for lunch
We were game.
Super-delicious olives with nice house bread.
Nice house wine.
Fresh seafood. We had the halibut served with pasta and spinach ($14!). Ample portions.
Server was super friendly as was the other restaurant staff.
Would come here again. Good value.
author: Rosquete B.

description: This place is amazing! I went here the first weekend in october walking around san francisco and there was a man outside who offered my husband and I a free glass of wine accompanied by a long stemmed red rose for coming in. So we decided to try it. I had the tortelini michelangelo. The portions looked small but it was sooo delicious and perfect size portion too! You have to try this place!
author: Jenee' S.

description: Tourist trap! It was a cold and windy day, and we basically settled on this place. The guy outside was working the door trying to entice people to come in by offering a free appetizer. That should of been red flag number one. Any great place wouldn't need to push so hard. It reminded me how the people push things when your vacationing in Mexico. But as I said, it was cold and windy. We are seated and soon after he takes our order. The food arrives, but we never receive a table check the entire time we are there, not one! My wife's salmon is cold, the broccoli had no seasoning what so ever, and the rest was just OK at best. If your starving and everything is closed, this place might do the trick. But if your planning a trip to San Francisco, and your looking for a cool/great place to eat, well, this isn't it! I enjoyed my food at offthegridsf food trucks more then this place. Keep walking down Columbus and find another place to eat at!
author: Bri A.

description:
You will most likely find the owner standing on the sidewalk talking to people as they walk by.  He may offer you a complimentary glass of wine and a snack just for trying his food and the view of the park.  The ristorante is warm, friendly and serves very good food for the tourist corridor of the Italian district.  In fact, Michelangelo could take advantage of the tourists by service poor and overpriced food, but it is just the opposite.  He continues to focus on great service, good food and a warm handshake upon coming in and leaving.

Oh yeah, at the end of the meal they bring you gummy bears and those little Italian cookies that come in the red and yellow can -- on the house of course.  I was forced to have a cup of coffee with the cookies.
author: Gary J.

description: I've been going to this place since I was a kid, their gnocchi is fantastic and surely worth a try, if gnocchi are like little mattresses then theirs is surely a tempurpedic.
author: Ian B.

description: My family had dinner here last night.  Of the four entries, one was very good, the other three average.  The service was OK.  The waiter got my son's order wrong but did not seem to care.  The lasagna; penne with eggplant, mozarella, and basil; and the spaghetti with red clam sauce was OK but the spaghetti carbonara was very good.  Rich and creamy.  It helped that you get the red wine and bruschetta for free, but they were very average.
author: t d.

description:
A woman staying at the same hotel as us recommended Michelangelo's, we are glad she did.

We did not receive the free bruschetta or wine like a lot of the reviews are stating. We ordered a beer and a wine and were charged for it. Not sure if you have to ask for it or if our waiter just forgot.

We enjoyed their complimentary bread and olives. We ordered prosciutto and melon as our appetizer. It was delicious. The melon was fresh and sweet and the prosciutto was perfect.

We had Chicken Valdostana and Fettuccine Mari E Monti as our main courses. The serving sizes were perfect and the food was great.

We were too stuffed for dessert, but we did have some of the complimentary cookies and gummy bears (such a cool idea!)
author: Chrim K.

description: I wasn't expecting much from Michelangelo's, but I was pleasantly surprised.  My wife and I went here for a nice, relaxing meal and it turned out very enjoyable.  The mussels and clam appetizer was very well done.  I couldn't stop dipping the bread in the broth. And my lamb chops were prepared perfectly! Another nice Italian restaurant in North Beach.
author: Don G.

description:
Jack always says I am a low-reviewer. Well then. 
Fairer & I came here bc they had a ton of tables open during the North Beach Festival (umm, red light? yellow at least.) 
But, we Needed Sustenance. 
We both ordered the caprese salad, and it was fine. Nothing to rave about. Admittedly, the complimentary bread / balsamic was destroyed at our hands within minutes (I will devour anything with vinegar involved.) The further complimentary plate of olives had the same fate. 
The appetizer (calamari) we ordered came well after we were into our main dishes - so much so we both forgot about it. And it was soggy. Eww, soggy calamari. But, yeah, we ate it. The dipping sauce was heavy tomato. 
We had a hard time getting our bill, and I guess, to compensate, were treated with a plate full of umm, gummy bears. 
Yes. Gummy Bears.
author: Meg W.

description: Horrible. The food is maybe 2.5 stars for lame tourist Italian on Columbus but the loud techno Italian with the waiter singing karaoke was way too much and killed the date. Let the tourist flock here.
author: Marteen N.

description: Excellent food, great portions, wonderful service.  Thank you Tony.
author: Nicola M.

description: Used a Groupon. I guess you get what you pay for! Not bad, very polite, clearly rely on tourism and not return clientele. The food is bland and made with mediocre quality ingredients. 3 course meal and nothing memorable, tasteless. In this neighborhood, so near to many amazing Italian restaurants , I would expect more of an effort. At least use some fresh herbs and decent cheese....
author: Blue W.

description:
I got sucked into this place on a slow Wednesday night walking around, looking for food with the bf.  The owner Michelangelo seemed like a great business man, very nice, offered us a free glass of wine if we dine here.

When I heard this, the alcoholic in me took over and agreed to come in and eat here.  

Service: good service, it seems more mom and pop than professional, but definitely made you feel welcome.

Price: So you think location, you think italian and you see menu and you think the prices are acceptable.  But when your food and your "glass" of wine comes out, you think RIP OFF. Glass of wine was free, but I saw that it was $6.50 on the menu.  If you've ever had desert wine or port, you usually get it in a smaller than normal wine glass.  well this is what a "glass" is here.

on to the FOOD: I got Fettuccine with some scallops, shrimp in an orange cream sauce.  It was $17 and it looked and tasted like it should have been $10. My bf got one of their specials, spaghetti with bacon carbonara, and that looked and tasted really plain, and crappy.  It was basically spaghetti with some salt, and a spoon full of bacon bits and that was it.

Sorry Michelangelo, you're a nice guy and all, but your food does not match the price and the presentation was rather disturbing, Looks like someone threw up onto a plate.  

I'm giving this place 2.5 stars but rounding up because of the free wine and the nice owner, but other than that, the prices are ridiculous (for what you're getting) and the food tastes mediocre.
author: Zu W.

description:
We used to go out to this place when we were in college (at the turn of the century) and visiting friends in the area made this a very pleasant surprise ending to a nice visit. We truly missed this place. 

Sunday night is ladies night, so girls get a rose (it lived for about 2 weeks) and we all got a free glass of wine (very average taste, small glass). We were going there anyway, so this was just a bonus. 

It was Sunday evening (6ish) and the place was pretty empty, but there were expecting a 12er later on. I remember, this place always being packed. Recession!!!

Service: A+++ 
We were with a baby and when the kid dropped my wife's napkin on the floor, a waiter/bus boy out of nowhere swooped in with a fresh napkin before my wife could even pick up the old one. WOW! The host, waitress, and all were very nice. It took a bit while to get our meal, but I ordered something that would take me a long time to make at home, so it's ok. 

Food: B+ 
Olives (free) were nice. Bread was ok (yes like others, a nicer and warmer bread would be better)... and some vinegar with spices for dipping. 
Main course was excellent!!! I had Osso Busco that was a larger portion, flavorfull, tender and just yummy. My wife had a pasta dish with shrimp, chicken and veggies that was very nice. 

Dessert: A? 
The cookies (amazing) and gummy bears (standard) are free and a tradition. They used to have huge bowls of gummy bears that went from table to table, but I'm sure the health inspector had something to do with getting rid of communal bowls. We were too full for anything else. 

Price: B+ 
Most dishes were 15-19. Not too bad. 

Atmosphere: A 
If you like crazy, Italian grandma clutter collection. I like it cause it's different and fun. Think Bucca di Beppo... it's different. 

Would we go there again... OF COURSE, we have and we will.
author: A K.

description: Cool decor. The eggplant parmesan was excellent and ravioli decent. Drinks overpriced.  Gummy bears and cookies while settling bill were a surprise!
author: Tina D.

description: All I can say is WOW! And not in a good way! The service was terrible, it was over priced and I never got any gummy bears. I ordered a ceasar salad... How do u botch that up! It tasted like soaked fish. If it wasn't for the olives and bread , I wouldn't have had dinner. If u can call it that!
author: Christie R.

description:
I have been to this establishment twice, I liked the food well enough, but this review is mostly of the service aspect.

The first visit it was dinner hours, somewhat busier, and I was on a date. The decor is hilariously tacky, but as a local who was stuck hungry in a tourist spot, it seemed the least like highway robbery.

The owner must have been there-- because the man who pulled out my chair for me, consistently checked up on us, and served us a plate of treats with the bill was NOT my server/waiter. 

Then we have my second visit, maybe two weeks after the first. It was a slow lunch hour on a weekday and my dad was visiting me in SF.

There was one waiter for the three occupied tables, the word SNOTTY is etched into my mind. He was very quick with our orders, interrupted me while speaking three times, and then told me I could order a glass of wine since it came free with my entree. 

Not a fan of the drink, I asked my dad (big Wino) if he'd like it. I then asked what wines were available and it was met with a large exasperated sigh, eye roll, and somehow I should have magically KNOWN what was available.

I checked, the lunch menu has no mention of wines, other than "wine.....$6". There were no written signs or placards saying "Wine List", and when brought in, there was no mention by the staff of any wines, specials, etc.

All I got in edge wise was "red" before he sauntered off. 

TLDR; When the owner is there? Great service, decent food. When he's not? Avoid, Avoid, Avoid.
author: Adora S.

description:
Solid experience here at Michelangelo.  The 'owner' named 'Michelangelo' stopped my group as we were walking up Columbus looking for an Italian spot for dinner.  He won us over by offering us each a free glass of wine (which is sometimes all it takes).  And, at the end, hey! they give you gummy bears.

I had the cheese lasagna, which was amazing and very cheesy.  The other pasta dishes looked fine too, and the bread was aplenty.  So food wise, this place nailed it.

But...

Stainedglass lamps swarm the ceiling-- the insane decor of this spot is absolutely nuts.  Large sculptures peer at you while you eat.  Though I kind of like how much there was to discover while looking around, I feel like somebody spent 30 years robbing the houses of old Italian grandmas.

--

And now that I've found out that everybody gets a free glass of wine, as long as they mention Yelp, then my experience has lost a little bit of resonance.  Going to restaurants in the North End of Boston growing up, I've always loved Italian food the most.  The experience of eating great food when you go out with friends or family is always the goal.  You make the experience yourself, positive or negative, and that's totally true at this place where the hospitable service and food quality is spot-on.

This spot might not be some insane deal or bougy mecca, but it's everything you need when you're wandering North Beach looking for Italian food.
author: L J.

description: Sis and I went here a few hours ago. Busy interior and tight seating (we were next to window in the jailbox). Bread and olives were brought, but everything was so tight that service and access was annoying, I had to actually move the table to squeeze into the jailbox, which was a tiny 2'x3" tabletop with one small chair and what I call the jailbox, a box seat made of wood and almost immovable. I ordered Chicken Valdostana (or what I thought it was), and whatever it was was served with bits of rosemary and broccoli, in its own lake of watery light white sauce, probably due to the broccoli. The broccoli was so under-cooked I thought I was eating in a chinese restaurant, while the chicken slices while big were quite tasteless. Seeing others who ordered house white/red, I was for once happy I didn't as the glass was very small with a smaller quantity of wine within for $6.50 a glass! The restaurant is so disorganized that a couple sitting next to us next to the window had four waiters waiting on them with 10minutes! The host was dressed casually and sporting a week stubble and chewing gum!! A nice place to see the decoration within but I wouldn't return for the "service" nor the "flavor". They do not accept AMEX but VISA si. Street parking only. Did I mention dessert? While sis ordered an ice cream they brought out a small plate of gummy bears and coconut-flavor almond cookies!!! I've never seen that served in Italia!!!
author: Tony L.

description:
My fiancé and I came here for dinner while on vacation in late April. We were searching for an Italian place with bolognese and were surprised at the amount of places that didn't serve it. 

We were standing outside checking out the menu for Michelangelo's, when the owner (surprisingly named Michelangelo) came to us and offered a free appetizer and glass of wine. Who doesn't like free stuff! Plus, they had a bolognese, so we were in. The owner was very nice and pretty much hustled outside the rest of the night, but it's understandable as the restaurant seems to be in the midst of a ton of different places. 

The inside is a decent size, but the wall decor is a little overwhelming. My fiancé was seated next to a 3-D relief of Michelangelo's "The Creation of Adam" - right by Adam's wee-wee! :P  Thankfully, a table along the wall left and we were reseated, so it worked out. 

Our waitress was nice but she seemed extremely stressed out. It didn't look too busy when we entered, so maybe it was a precursor of what was to come that night. We got some bruschetta and olives after we were seated, which I guess was the free appetizer. We didn't end up getting the free glass of wine though. 

We did order a bottle of wine, but were sad that they didn't have our first 2 picks (Cabernet Sauvignon or Merlot). We were pleased with the Pinot we got and the price was good ($25).

In terms of food, I started with a white bean soup and my fiancé got the Cesar salad. Both were very good - the serving of soup was huge and the salad was very good as well. The dressing was very light and fresh, very flavorful without being overwhelming. 

I ordered the eggplant parmigiana as my entrée and my fiancé got his bolognese. We were also both pleased with our meals. The servings look small but are very filling and don't leave you feeling overly stuffed. The bolognese sauce didn't overpower the noodles, and the eggplant was actually a few pieces of thinly sliced eggplant (I think it was like 4 slices) stacked one on top of the other, so it wasn't a huge brick of eggplant like I've had at other Italian places. You also get vegetables and who doesn't love those, especially while on vacation!

The overall vibe of the place is family orientated and very friendly. It does seem like a tourist trap however, and by the time we left, it was pretty busy. Three really big parties (6+ people) had come in while we were there (one with some really excited kids), but we got out just in time.

Would recommend this place to someone visiting the area as the prices are reasonable and the food is good.
author: Beata P.

description:
Staff at the door is very welcoming, almost alarmingly so. I'm not used to having someone get my attention to come eat dinner someplace like that - a clever, nice change. The staff is friendly and helpful. The food was excellent. I had the Cioppinno, which was very good. I ate with my parents and my sister, and they all enjoyed their meals. We made sure to get dessert as well. The tiramisu was excellent. My family definitely enjoyed the fruit-based ice desserts as well.

Good location. Great food. Reasonable prices.
author: Neil B.

description:
Keep in my mind for my review, I'm 100% Italian and I love Italian food.  And as an Italian, this place was insulting to Italian food.  The only reason I did not give it 1 star was because the owner was pretty cool and I respected his hard sale skills to sell myself as well as my date on the place.  

He sold us by offering a free glass of wine to each of us.  My date fell for it, but I should have known better because the wine that was offered tasted like warm Welch's grape juice.   We ordered prosciutto and melon appetizer, and I ordered the minestrone soup for myself too.   The presentation was laughable for the prosciutto because they literally just piled some prosciutto on some cantaloupe as if we were at a bachelor pad.  The soup look like it had just spilled completely out of the bowl.  Both tasted very bland.

As for dinner my date ordered the spinach ravioli and I ordered the lasagna with a side of meatballs.   Now the meatballs came about 5 minutes before our dinner and right when we were finishing our appetizers which I thought was odd.  After we received our entree, I noticed they used the table next to me as a station for grated cheese and water which I thought created a lame vibe.   You use the table to seat guests?   Anyway, my lasagna was something right out of the microwave in a deep dish.  Mind numbingly hot and tasted like a soggy mess.  The spinach raviolis were a much better choice and I was jealous my date had them because I was stuck with this food that was allegedly called lasagna.  It was like placing lipstick on a pig - it's still a pig.  

When you are done, they give you a plateful of gummy bears and a plateful of sugar cookies.  I don't see the connection of gummy bears and Italian food but we did eat those.

Upon leaving, the friendly owner, or at least the gentleman claimed to be the owner, thanked us for coming and off we went.  If it was not for him, this would have been unbearable.   The worse part of the whole thing is that it was $50.00 with tip which I thought was expensive considering the quality and the atmosphere.  

So if you are looking for a descent italian meal, definitely move on and don't get baited by the wine.
author: Duchess B.

description: I first dined here in 1991 and it was love at first bite. It has been 10yrs since i last ate at Michelanglo"s and not much has changed. The olive's, whole mozzarella and brushetta that comes as a free appetizer was excellent as always. I always get the same things lobster ravioli, the seafood pasta with Scallops,clams, salmon, mussels and large prawn's or the salmon. we all ordered one of each and shared family style along with the Caesar salad. Each was as good if not better than i remembered. I highly recommend a visit. A little tight seating but well worth it. Did i mention the wine in the chicken pitcher?
author: Frank O.

description: My girlfriends and I were on a recent getaway and happened upon this place with the lure of a young gentleman standing outside soliciting customers. He was nice enough so we thought what the heck...we were tired of walking anyway. Turned out he was the owner's son. Anyway, free app, amaretto cookies and gummies, albeit a nice thought, did not make up for the mediocre, overly-priced food. But, the owner was so friendly that we didn't want to complain; we just won't be back. Too many better Italian restaurants in this area. I could tell you what we had, but it really doesn't matter as everything short of the carbonara was just so-so...which I would imagine everything else would be as well.
author: Tasanee D.

description:
You know, I'm absolutely flabbergasted by the bad reviews here. When three of my friends and I came here recently, our experience was wonderful. While exploring the stylish neighborhood of North Beach in San Francisco, we were looking for a notable place to have dinner, and the stylish Michelangelo's was the winning selection. Our table was situated right next to a large stone fresco of mythological creatures. The ceiling is heavily adorned with Tiffany colored lights. From fine art prints to pictures of palaces from Architectural Digest, not a space on the walls or tables is left naked, conjuring an eclectic feast for the eyes. And now on to the feast for the stomach: 

Red Table Wine - A glass of this (or white wine) was complimentary with our meal. Robust and graceful, I enjoyed it. 
Bruschetta - Also complimentary to our meal was a savory bruschetta. Quite tasty. 
Proscuttio and Melon - Fragile fragments of cantaloupe and paper-thin slices of proscuttio made for a vibrant addition to the meal. I could eat this all day.
