Pasta Carbonara - A creamy golden sauce containing fettuccine noodles and proscuttio. It reminded me why I love Italian cuisine. Not a single morsel was left on my plate. 
Gummi Bears - Another meritable compliment came at the end of the meal. A small platter with cookies and gummi bears was served to us. I was not impressed with the small cookies, but the gummi bears won my heart. I thought it was a really clever way to bring the meal to a close, like fortune cookies at Chinese restaurants. And it also took me back to my childhood. My favorites (then and now) are the red and orange gummi bears. 

We met the owner, who was very cordial. Our server was also really nice and attentive. Not sure on the parking situation, as we were all walking. I will be dining here the next time I'm in North Beach.
author: Shaun-Mathieu S.

description: We walked past four times on walking tours and during exploration of North Beach and each time a nice young lady greeted us with a smile and a hello.  My wife decided if she was nice again, we were stopping.  Persistence paid off and the fifth time was the charm.  Food was quite good.  Service and personal experience was better.  We were served by Sal, the owner, and he was great.  The door guy was friendly too without being pushy.  Having lived near NYC for years, we knew the Little Italy experience there and there's so much pushy upselling to get you in the door.  This was not the case at Michelangelo's.  We got all the goodies others have written about.  Complimentary bruschetta that my wife went nuts over.  Gummy bears and cookies at the end of the meal.  We were even treated to a complimentary tiramisu that was delicious.  Sal told us about the business, the ups and downs, the story behind the gummy bears, and we just felt like guests and not just another table. I'm sure there are other places with similar food in North Beach but we won't need to go further up the hill if and when we are back in San Fran.  Sal and the door man shook my hand on the way out and thanked us for the visit.  Wife had the veal, I had the pollo valdostana and we were both very happy with the quality and size of the plates.  Overall a great experience at Michelangelo's with great service and attention to detail.
author: Paul S.

description: I love the two appetizers--fried calamari and the mussels.  I always ordered those dishes and they were ALWAYS delicious.  However, their entrees were not very impressive.  I am still upset with the rosemary chicken dish.  That was one of the more expensive dish ($16.95), yet it was terrible.  The chicken itself was nothing but filled with rosemary scent.  It was tasteless.  I tried other pasta dishes too.  Those were ok.  They were like the kind we can all make at home or buy off from Costco or Trader Joe's.  I would definitely go back for the appetizers but not the main dishes.  They had good customer service and the place was clean and comfortable.
author: Tina L.

description:
the food here is decent.  i came hungry and actually ordered two entrees which made me look like a pig, but oh well.  i started with veal portobello and then ordered a full size portion of spaghetti.  After that, I finished my date's lobster ravioli.  

the places makes you feel like you're an old rich italian mafia guy (at least that was my alter ego for the night).  or as pauly d would say - an OG - original guido

marcos, if you're reading this before 8 am you should know this is the same night i got that hicky.
author: Hammer Time H.

description:
Ups: The service was good. Our waiter was friendly. Michelangelo is the owner and received us when we arrived. We complained about one of the meals and he prepared something different for us, and it wasn't in the menu. Portions are big.

Downs: food was not special at allllll. the decoration is terribly tacky.
author: Fabiana H.

description: Came for a late lunch.  Fantastic food.  My daughter had the gnocchi -light as heaven.  Son had cheese pizza- home made crust and wonderful mozzarella.   I had seafood pasta- wonderful noodles.  Highly recommend
author: Eric T.

description:
I had marched Jeremy P around North Beach and demanded that he pick the restaurant. Or so he thought:

Him: "How about here?"
Me: "Hmmm... I think these are just sandwiches and stuff. I'd like to have, like, a sit down meal, if that's ok with you."

"How about here?"
"Argentinian food? We're in North Beach, we should have Italian."

"The smells coming out of this place are fantastic."
"We had pizza for lunch, I want something different."

"This place looks good."
"Steps of Rome sucks, let's move along."

"Here?"
"Too expensive."

Then he threw me in front of a bus. Not really. But I wouldn't have blamed him. 

Eventually we ended up at Michelangelo. I was a little cautious of going to a restaurant right on Columbus on a Saturday night but Michelangelo's was a pleasant surprise. The food was good and the staff seemed to be surprised and delighted that we had stopped by. The table we sat at was right in the window so it felt a little bit like being on display. It's kind of weird t be eating dinner and have people walking by 2 inches from your face. 

The bread tasted a little stale but J thought the olives served with it were delicious. The proscuittio and melon we had as a starter was fantastic. I had the ciopinno (reasonably priced at $18) and it was delicious and chock-full of fresh seafood. Unfortunately the garlic bread served with it was hard and tasted like it had been reheated a couple times. My magically delicious arm candy had the salmon special and damn near licked the plate. 

There were a lot of tourists in here - a family from some red state who insisted the sauce for their pasta be served "on the side" and a couple who couldn't figure out what the olive oil was for and demanded butter instead. Um, why are you in North Beach? Not for the food, clearly. These are the same folks who go to Chevy's for the "Mexican" food. The stafff were really nice about it and obviously used to patrons coming from the world of Olive Garden and trying to destroy real Italian food. Yes, I'm a judgmental bitch. But I only judge people who DESERVE it.
author: Pumpkin K.

description: Very typical for North Beach. It's good, but doesnt stand out, just like a hundred other restaurants in the neighborhood. I'd try something new before I ate here again.
author: Trevor N.

description:
I had gnocchi.  good.  Also had lentil soup.  good. Server-dude splashed a bit on my shirt.  bummer.

The others had dishes that didn't look very interesting to me, but they seemed to like it.  (something seafoody)

The decor is kinda 'buca di beppo autentico', but the main dude (Michelangelo?) was nice.  Although the service overall wasn't that great.

Also there were very few people other than our party there on a Saturday night.

We didn't have dessert, but I remember there being something free and weird at the end of the meal -- gummy bears with something else?  Strange but an interesting end to our experience.

I think I wouldn't mind trying it again one day, but in no hurry.
author: Effie G.

description: A group of 4 of us decided upon this place after the pizza place our friends wanted to introduce us to was closed on Mondays.  We were all quite excited about it after looking at the menu but then it kind of went downhill.  The server was very friendly and helpful but the food just was not up to par.  Everyone agreed that all of the dishes were pretty bland and were lacking flavor.  I do not think I would go back here especially for the price.  Oh and the gummy bears at the end of the meal was just strange. LOL
author: Melissa B.

description:
Any place that gives you gummy bears for dessert ....Rocks!!

its very cozy place, the fixtures on the wall can be a little freaky and overkill but the food is great.

Ask for the meat lasagna, its not on the menu but they always have it. The tortelini is also very good, the alfredo sauce is creamy and absolutely yummy
author: Anna T.

description:
I've been here before, many years ago. I'm not really sure why I returned. Maybe because I was younger then and didn't really know what Italian food tastes like from a decent restaurant...or maybe it was because i was tempted by the thought that a Groupon would make it worth it. I know enough now to say this is place serves very poor quality food.  It's not worth going here even with a Groupon.  The food was barely edible and everything was way overpriced for the quality.  The best part of our meal were the olives...but of course they didn't cook those.  We had the shrimp cocktail to start.  The shrimp had a strange, almost musty, taste to them which began to worry me. I feared what was to come. I ordered the Veal Parmigiana.  It came with broccoli and potatoes. I had them include some pasta with it. The roasted potatoes were the most edible thing on the plate but were still bland. The broccoli might as well have been only for decoration because you wouldn't want to eat it. It was like cardboard.  And the Veal...I don't even want to go into it. It was gross. 

I must say, the dessert was good. We ordered something very similar to a creme brûlée.  It was tasty. 

The service was very mediocre. The waiter wasn't very pleasant. He would look out the window as he talked to us and seemed to be curt in his responses to questions. 

Oh, I almost forgot to mention....we were the ONLY people in the restaurant at the time which was a little awkward.  It was late (9:15pm), but this is San Francisco, not Rio Vista....people eat late here. That was a red flag for us, but we had a Groupon...we knew we would be eating there eventually, so we went for it....ugggh, never again!  Damn you Groupon!!
author: Justin H.

description: We wandered into this place around 3:45 pm and sat down.   At first I was hesitant as the place was empty, but then the owner (Salvatore?)  told us they don't actually open til 4:00 and they weren't quite ready.  But he still made us feel welcome and immediately asked if he could start us off with something while they prepared for opening.   We started with a yummy antipasti with olives,  caprese salad, salami, roasted veggies.  My only complaint was that the veggies had too much olive oil, but other than that, really good.   The garlic bread is DELICIOUS!   One of the best I've ever had!    For my main dish I ordered their salmon special.. it was moist and full of flavor with plenty of capers.  My dish normally came with potatoes, but I wanted to try their pasta so the owner gave me an extra complimentary order of pasta.   My boyfriend ordered New York steak which was also really tasty.   The service was excellent, and I loved the decor with lots of beautiful stained glass lamps everywhere.    As a little added perk the owner and his son were quite handsome ;).  Will definitely be back, and next time will try the gnocchi!
author: Elaine S.

description: Great food. Great service. Felt very welcome. Owner/chef was charming.
author: Tammy B.

description:
Mean waitress=not cool.  

Our food took over an hour to come.  The waitress told us the kitchen had skipped us over.  We didn't give her a hard time...we obligingly told her not to worry.  Though she kept trying to push wine on us while we waited.  Expensive wine we told her  three times we didn't want.

Then we finally got the check, and realized we'd have to put the bill on our various cards.  I know this is a cardinal sin in restaurant protocol, but we asked to split it *evenly* on three cards, and apologized profusely.  Considering the slow service and our patience, we didn't think it would be an issue.  

Instead the waitress marched back to our table and lectured us, "This is very poor etiquette.  I did it this time but in the future, it should be a minimum of $20.00 on a card, and only one card.  This was *very rude*."

Um, hi.  I'm an adult.  Pretty sure I grew out of parental lectures from my own parents about 10 years ago...and I certainly don't need them from an ill-tempered waitress my own age.  With a sea of other italian restaurants in North Beach I certainly won't be returning to Michelangelo.
author: Sarah J.

description:
Stumbled upon this well lit restaurant Saturday night after finding our previously decided upon restaurant was inexplicable closed. The host was nice and cute. He seated up promptly and gave us plenty of time to look at the menu before he came back and took our order.
As soon as we were seated our table was adorned with fresh bread, kalamata olives, and ice water. 
Our host was able to answer questions and offer suggestions which makes dining a breeze.
Dinner was delicious... more raviolis could have been plated but there was plenty of gnocchi  and their wine goblets are cute!
Loved the thank you treat on our way out... gummy bears and cookies!!!
If going for a B-day be ready for owner and hosts to sing to you.
author: Amalia O.

description: The food here is good. I had spaghetti and meatballs. The meatballs were yummy! My daughter ordered the tortellini, also yummy. My other daughter ordered a chicken panning. That looked like the best. But to tell you the truth we didn't come for the food. We were lured in by the very hot host. That's why this place gets 4 stars! I'd give 2 1/2 to 3 stars for the food. f you're in the mood for some candy...eye candy...this is your spot.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I would be vaguely horrified to go on a first date here.  Actually, I would only be horrified if the guy were a douche, and he was, like... trying to impress me or something.  Ok, what am I talking about - I haven't had a date since 2007, so I took my lovely BFFs to this uh... lovely restaurant.

The server told us some story about his grandmother getting groped in the bushes in Italy.  "Yeah," I thought, "PG-13, and we haven't even gotten the wine yet!"  I love Italians.

So, you get free bruschetta... and bread... and gummy bears!  Mm... gelatin.  Granted, someone's squalling offspring is going to be chewing at your ankles mid-meal, but a swift kick when the parents aren't looking, and you're good to go for the rest of the meal.  $24 for a nice bottle of Montepulciano too.

There was also some statue T&A going on.  Really, the inside of the place was pretty weird, but the food was good.  We also got free Limoncello.  

I think the server wanted to grope us in the bushes.  But hey, I'm willing to smile a little for the Limoncello.
author: Alissa K.

description: I purchased a deal for Michaelangelo Cafe through Groupon and my experience there was terrible. The owner could not care less when I told him his mushrooms in the veal dish were sour I was shocked when he told me that it was not his problem and maybe it was the sauce and didn't even offer an alternative. It was inedible and I usually eat everything. To add insult he loses our check when we ask for it and takes his time tending to other tables while my boyfriend and I waited patiently for 20 minutes. I can only imagine that his lack of concern for us was because we were the only non white customers there. I read the reviews on Yelp, sadly after I purchased the deal, hoping that the reviews may have been slightly exaggerated as to how terrible the food and customer service was unfortunately none of them were. Also the waiter/owner added and additonal $5.48 to the check which I have no idea where it came from I'm assuming it was a gratuity for himself as we ordered a glass of wine $8 and beer $4 which totals to $13.02 after tax but our bill came out to $18.50 after the Groupon discount and we still tipped him (well my bf told me we should because he's too nice). BUT that was absurd! Oh the tiramisu was actually good but that was it and the waiter acted like he forgot it as he set our bill down asking us if we wanted it. It was part of the DEAL! And they still use styrofoam which is a no no for SF restaurants now FYI.
author: J C.

description:
With all of the magnificient restaurants in North Beach, I am so embarrassed to say that this was the one I chose.  However I should have known that it wasn't going to be good since getting a reservation on a Friday night at 8:00 was so easy.   I did not Yelp before doing so, although there are mixed reviews regarding this place which leaves me perplexed.  What are  you people thinking?!?!?!
To start off, we waited a good 20minutes before anyone came over to us.   Our waiter was rude and in a rush.  He mixed up our appetizer order and then made out like we all of a sudden changed our minds.  The food was edible but I don't think Stouffers TV dinners would have been any different.  Shrimp cocktail was served with warm shrimp, bruschetta was simply bread topped with mushy tomatoes and we did not recieve any complimentary wine like others have said.   
Dinner entrees were PLAIN and SIMPLE.  I got gnocchi with pesto sause which might have been the best from my party.  Other entrees included Pasta Norma, where the sauce reminded me of Ragu and there were maybe three small pieces of eggplant mixed in and the Chicken and Sausage entree, which just looked unappetizing.
There complimentary dessert is gummi bears. Gummi Bears?????  
Being in the heart of North Beach, this was a very disappointing visit.  Silly of me for thinking that any italian restaurant in San Francisco's Little Italy would be a good choice.
author: Darlene W.

description:
Back in the 90's this use to be one of my favorite places to take a first date. Perfect location next to a plethora of coffee / pastries houses. Short romantic walk from the Cable Cars. Lighting and quiet setting and nice staff was always the norm. Also when the staff sees me with a different lady friend they always try to play me up. Very cool of them to do that. 

Now it seems to be slipping just a bit. The food just doesn't taste the same and the ambiance is more LOUD now rather than soft and romantic. The wine was just so so. Love the cheese, olives, bread with olive oil including the tiramisu. Always, always pass up the gummy bears to many germs. Price is average. Look at the past reviews, this place had more stars back in the days.
author: Simon L.

description: The food was absolutely awful. Don't be lured in by the free wine and appetizer because it's alll down hill from there.  You are better off starving or opening a can of spaghetti O's.
author: M W.

description: I don't usually eat at Italian restaurants because I think I can make good Italian pasta at home, but since my brother insisted we get Italian I said ok.  The food was good, but the portions are so small with what you have to pay.  I know that Italian cuisine is about getting the antipasto, primo, and secondo, but you definitely do not get more bang for your back at this restaurant.  I think I'll pass this one up next time.
author: Sally Q.

description: I have actually seen people lined up to get in this place, tho it was many years ago. We tried it on the fleet week weekend. North Beach was hoping, but not this place. Ordered a bottle of house red that was sub 2 buck chuck. Ordered a Caeser Salad. Maybe the worst I have ever seen. Completely wilted and sweet to the taste. Balsamic vinegar I guess. But the Cioppino was like something from a can. Tastless, boring. After the cookies and gummy bears were served (WTF?), the waitor said. "Anything else, like maybe a decent glass of wine?". If your House red is not decent, then why are you pouring it? This place is clearly nothing but a tourist rip off, run by people who really do not care and have no pride. I wonder if it was something else in the past?
author: k m.

description:
Went back to Michelangelo. Nice busy little restaurant. Great pasta dishes, lovely seafood all around the table. still miss that cheeseblock.  The wine was great.
Oh we scrambled around for cash because it's a cash only restaurant. but if you are ever in that situation go down towards chinatown/broadway ave. then you'll see all the major banks there.
The magic of the night was the fact we found parking less than 30 minutes on Saturday night prime dinner time in North Beach, so eat that bitches!
author: John L.

description: We went accidentally, having purchased a Groupon. It was wonderful. We had a very nice table by the window with a view of Washington Square and Columbus Street. The service was impeccable. The food was excellent. The bruchetta and dessert were terrific. We strongly reccommend this restaurant.
author: Jack C.

description:
This place has really gone down hill! It used to be very good but I went there this past Saturday  for a dinner around 8:30pm and it was far from what it used to be. The restaurant was almost empty--that should have been a sign. The server was with us shortly, took our order and the food came out fast. I had the chicken and by boyfriend had the gnocci. Whatever you do, DO NOT order the chicken. It was sliced very thin and thus was very dry. It was glistening (and not in a good way) from the oil that was sitting on top of it.  The gnocci were not much better, but at least they were edible. I would have gladly sent my food back, but our server did not come out to us a single time after that other than to bring the check.

Over all, bad food and bad service.
author: Alina O.

description: One more thing I left out!! My Dad ordered a bottle of the house Merlot - $25 a bottle.. It was 2 buck chuck, sold at Trader Joe's for $1.99!!! He of course told the waiter he was NUTZ.. LOL Go dad.. Shame Michaelangelo!!
author: Monica S.

description:
I agree with many of the reviews already here.  A group of us went for a friend's birthday and we were greeted by the owner upon our arrival...  Ushered directly to a table, treated to complimentary wine, free birthday appetizer and even a happy birthday shot for our Birthday Girl! 

Food is good - nothing spectacular, but not bad in any sense (especially loved the olives & bread brought out as we sat down).  Decor is eh, but the service was very Italian and friendly and most of all FUN!  They made sure we were taken care of.  They even let us stay long after they were closed as we finished our desert.  

**Note to salad lovers:  The side Caesar salad is TINY... and maybe NOT worth the $7.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
On the one hand, life is short, North Beach is far away and Italian food is overrated.  So will I ever eat a meal here?  I highly doubt it.

On the other hand, it was pouring rain after the John Oliver show, I needed to sober up before driving, and Mario's was packed.  So did we run across the street to grab cappuccinos and dessert here?  You bet.  

And whatever else I may say about Italian cuisine, they do know their coffee and ice cream.  That hit the spot, questionable faux-roman-statue decor notwithstanding.
author: Wes M.

description:
I am a sales person at heart and when a restaurant like Michelangelo Ristorante & Caffe took the time to sell me on a free glass of wine with my lunch... I liked that effort.  And who doesn't like a free drink?  

I was on my way down to Washington Square (Lovely park) when I was snagged for lunch.  New to the area, I was scoping out the park and decided that I would take a seat near the window so I could watch the people and dogs mingling.  Food was good.  I devoured a delicious Cesar salad with homemade dressing, and had some bread.  The wine was ok, but nothing too fantastic.

To get 4 stars --- I would have needed more regular water refills.  Instead of me asking for my water to be refilled, this should be something done a bit more pro-actively.  Also, I would have liked to log onto their wireless Internet so I could chat with my wife.  You see I was in the area looking for apartments and it would have been nice to give her the latest update, but they didn't have a wireless connection.  Most restaurants who call themselves a "caffe" should have a wireless Internet connection by now.

--Z
author: Zane W.

description:
When it came to celebrating my dad's birthday, we were in mood for some italian food. My friend recommened Michelangelo Cafe. I ordered the chicken marsala..actually it was the veal but I asked the waiter if I could switch to chicken and he said I could. The meal was really yummy and delicious.  I forgot what he ordered but i remembered he enjoyed his meal. :)

A drawback re: North Beach...it is difficult to find a parking space. The nearest parking garage is located in Chinatown...borderline between Chinatown and North Beach.
author: Melody S.

description:
I've eaten here a few times throughout the years... the last couple of times I got a coupon through Restaurant.com. That definitely helps pay the bill.

We ended up here instead of next door because I don't know why. It was my birthday and I know we ate next door last year. So we went inside Michelangleo's. The waitress looked scared and uneasy. We got the bread and spiced olives and free bruschetta. I can't seem to recall why but we ordered the calamari and it was not good. There was no seasoning to the breading and tasted very bland! We had to add the lemon and salt to it to make it edible. We also ordered the cabrese and it was the worst I've ever had. The tomatoes were nice a big cuts but tasted like nothing. There was little to no olive oil on the plate and barely any basil. Very disappointing.
I ordered the veal saltimbucca. When it came out there were four little pieces of potato and a few broccoli pieces. It seemed to be a very limited portion; however, after eating everything else and the veal was very good and tender, I was stuffed and didn't need any more potatoes.
As I mentioned it was my birthday; but we were so full nothing was said (I really don't need to eat a huge piece of wonderful tiramisu anyway). The waitress still wasn't very friendly and didn't bring us the cookies or gummy bears (which I think I still have some from last year! I don't eat those things) so not bringing them out was fine; but weird because everyone else go them... was it because of the coupon?
I don't care.

There's so many places to eat in North Beach, this is a hit or miss. Typically just good Italian food.
Remembering all aspects, I only gave 2 stars as there is no reason for the poor reviews.
author: Sandra R.

description:
A+ on the appetizers and salads.
D on the entree course.

The owner/host/street barker was very personable, very nice, and gave us each a free glass of wine.  

Easily a four-or-five stars on the bruschetta and caprese.  Actually, the best caprese I've ever had, hands down.  I would go to this restaurant in an instant for wine and appetizers.

But the main course?  Wow, meh.  The tomato cream sauce was so-so on the special lobster ravioli, and the pasta for it wasn't anywhere near homemade or restaurant-made; these came off a truck.

My dish (scallops, shrimp, farfalle, also tomato cream sauce) was incredibly lackluster.  The scallops were crunchy (from sand?) where they'd been improperly cleaned, and there was an enormous amount of pasta, but not enough other stuff to balance that.  The sauce was fishy from one of the two kinds of seafood in it.
author: Dean J.

description:
I came here for a friends bday. I really enjoy the statues on the walls. Including the two ASSES in my face the whole night. LOL.
But seriously this place is OK. Nothing seemed too out of the ordinary here. I had fettucini alfredo, it was OK. I just liked the cool experience of trying somewhere new. Most thing I remember was the bowl full of GUMMY BEARS, First reaction: OOoo gummy bears. Second reaction: Do Italians eat gummybears?? 

Doubt I'd come again.
author: Sarina I.

description:
Im so bored of this restaurant I don't even want to think of something cleaver to write.  I don't know, maybe I just don't like veal, but I know I have had veal that I liked.  This was not it.  I did like the giant bowl of gummy bears.  I should have just had that for dinner and an espresso.

Oh, and make sure you clearly specify that you want the house wine served in the roaster cause even though the more expensive wine was better, I really wanted to drink my wine out of a roaster.
author: Jennifer E.

description: I love this restaurant! It might not be a BS "Food as Art" type place but it's some really good, authentic Italian home cooking, especially the fresh seafood entres! Every time I come to SF I make it a point to dine here in North Beach. Not only is the food great but the venue is so "movie set" material not to mention the greatest place to people watch while dining. It's like a place you might find in Pisa or Napoli!
author: Frans S.

description: ZERO, ZERO, ZERO, ZERO, ZERO. I would never return. We went despite the fact that it was pretty empty. Our first mistake. Our server treated us like the building was burning down and he needed to serve everything as fast as possible to collect our dinner fee. We ordered multiple appetizers but were only served one. We assumed that they would at least take these expensive items off the bill but they brought us a very expensive bill for sub-par food. We had to have them correct the mistake. The calimari was hardly cooked and inedible. When one of our party asked to have her untouched pasta boxed up, the server instead threw it away! When 10 mins after we settled the bill, I still had not received the leftovers, I inquired as to where they were, the Manager insisted that he was very sorry and would make a whole new dish! We waited and waited AND WAITED for the dish. When it finally came it was literally 1/8 the size of the original pasta dish.  Terrible service, terrible food and very expensive.
author: Stephanie F.

description: At best, food was very mediocre; make believe Italian. The service was worse than the food. We were a party of four. Our waiter impatiently took our order. We had ordered salads before our meal, and had barely begun eating them when they brought the main entrees. We asked them not to bring our food so quickly, but they brought it anyway. I have had more leisurely meals at MacDonalds. Needless to say, I won't be returning, not even for gummy bears, hwhich I happen to love.
author: Linda K.

description:
Great Italian food and not over priced at all. The staff has been nothing but nice each time I visit this place.

I order their Mussels alla cozze, very terrific sauce!
author: Ericka A.

description:
I wish we could give half stars on Yelp, Michelangelo is a solid 3.5 stars.  We were walking around North Beach trying to find a delicious/not-so-touristy Italian place. We were actually headed somewhere else, when the owner (Michelangelo) came out to tell us about their specials. Michelangelo was so nice (and we had heard good things about the restaurant from friends), we couldn't resist.  

The atmosphere is ok, nothing special.  Michelangelo was very warm and hospitable.  The waiter was trying, but unfortunately, he wasn't that great...not bad, but not great.  Our water glasses were empty for most of the meal and he forgot to come back and ask us if we wanted dessert.  Additionally, he messed up our order slightly.  

The food was definitely a 4!  We had the veal parmigiana, which was amazing and the gnocchi was probably the best I have ever had.  The prices were also quite good.  Despite the weird service, we will be going back again, because the food was great.  I can't wait to try more things.
author: Marisol H.

description: My review of this place would be a combination of every 1 or 2 star review listed. Put me down for a 1.5. I got a soft spot for green gummie bears.
author: Michael C.

description: Been eating here since my wife and I first found it 17 years ago. Same great food. Same delicious gummy bears. Just a great all around restaurant.
author: T S.

description: I love this place and can't believe I haven't eaten here before. The owner is charming and lovely. It had an old-world feel, olives, bread and bruschetta served at each table. The prosciutto and melon appetizer was delicious; the proscuito was high quality, not too salty, the  melon was sweet. We shared a fettuccine with shrimp in a tomato cream sauce, which was perfectly cooked and so delicious, as was the veal portobello with an elegant marsala sauce. The tiramisu was light and beautiful. I was surprised there wasn't a crowd of people. I loved the Italian opera playing, a romantic dinner for me and my boyfriend.
author: Laurie U.

description:
Service was funny, but lacking.

food quality was VERY low. 

Key Lime Cheesecake was dry ($6) and tasted like nothing.
Chicken Milanesa ($15) was really boring. 
Olives on table tasted spoiled (I spit it out).  
Calamari ($7) was bland.  

I won't be back there when there are SO many other good Italian restaurants in town.
author: Matt V.

description:
The atmosphere is fun, the waitstaff are entertaining (and prompt) and the food is yummy!  One of my favs in North Beach.  Hopefully you won't have to wait too long (I actually went on a Saturday night recently and there wasn't one person waiting!  Amazing!) but its worth it if you do.  Not a huge menu but all the pasta is made onsite and the sauces are the best.  Down-to-earth basic Italian food.  Fun for groups or dates but don't expect whispered conversations.  The place can get loud.  The feaux stone carvings and Tiffany lights just add to the querkiness.

My recommendation - check it out.
author: Dawn S.

description:
This place is simply amazing!  I now have a favorite Italian restaurant in SF.  Michelangelo took very good care of us and made us feel welcome. We always request a specific special Italian dish when we go to Italian restaurants and hands down this restaurant does it better than any other in the country!  I can't wait to come back and have already told my family to plan on visiting here on my next visit.

One suggestion to invite more people in would be to create more mood lighting.  

All in all this is an amazing place!
author: rekha r.

description:
Started great, ended in a dismal failure.  The greeter was charming, the brochette came quickly, the waitress took our order in good time and the entrées were prompt and delicious. (Veal was exceptional).  Midway through our meal I enquired about the wine the greeter had offered to draw us in.  Once the wine was delivered, we never saw the smile of our waitress again.  She managed to completely seat, serve, and check out a table that arrived after our entrées  were delivered before returning to our table only after we had given up on her and I was getting my coat on to leave.  The owner was attentive to the Italian folks, but completely ignored the rest of the guest.  The bus-boy was more attentive to the guests until he dropped off the cookies and gummy bears (really???) then he disappeared.  We were never offered any other desert options (mind you the Italian folks had complete offerings of what looked like some awesome orange gelato... again, the owner was keeping an eye on them).  Finally a check arrived, we commented to the waitress that we were going to order desert, no apologies.
  If I wanted to be ignored, I would have gone to the French restaurant across the street from our hotel; at least I would have expected it!  
BTW, we didn't leave a tip, so here it is: Don't ignore your guests. What started off as five star food and service dwindled to a one star warning to others.
author: Michel P.

description: Well, this used to be a good, family option in North Beach -- not anymore, I am sad to say. The two last times I went the food ranged from just adequate to really, really bad. My salad was awful (both times)  -- oddly spread out lettuce, no taste tomatoes, boring dressing. We brought our niece in for her last dinner before heading back to Chicago. We all used to love Michelangelo's - it was tasty, fresh and authentic. But something has changed. We all were disappointed in our orders (mine was the least disappointing - cheese ravioli). But our poor visiting niece  could barely eat her carbonara. And the service was so odd - they kept frantically filling our water glasses, it just seemed slightly panicked. Odd. AND it was expensive. Never again. Sad but true.
author: Patricia C.

description:
So, several girlfriends and I went to this restaurant to load up on carbs before the Nike Women's Half Marathon.  We had reservations, but the host seemed unprepared for our arrival.  (I'm not sure they even keep track of reservations.)  He asked us to wait "5 Italian minutes" whatever that means, which was okay with us since one of our friends was still on her way.  He also comped us glasses of wine while we waited, so right away I was liking this place.

The menu is nothing fancy, but my penne with eggplant was super yummy.  Everyone else claimed their pastas were delicious.  After dinner, they brought us a two plates - one piled with gummy bears and the other with small amaretto cookies.  Only after we cleaned those plates, did the server ask about dessert.  Too late at that point!

Service was quite slow, but the place was packed.  Despite the line outside, it took us a long time to get our bill.  I would definitely go back and the pasta provided the right amount of fuel to get me through the race!
author: Jen G.

description:
First I'd like to say I rarely go to North Beach, and I have been to Michelangelo twice.  I like the place:  it has a "jolly" atmosphere with its big wall sculptures and triangular layout, waiters that talk like Luigi, and good food.   The presentation sort of goes with the place, big bowls of parmesean cheese and pasta in punch bowls and plate of gummi bears, etc.... unique, to say the least.  

 For about $15 a plate,  I'd say I have had better food in other Italian restaurants.  Nothing was to die for imo, though it is a good choice when when I'm in the area.   I wouldn't say it's worth finding the parking to go there specifically for the food.

So, dining experience I'd give it close to a 4, but with the added cost and difficulty of parking, it rounds back down to a 3.
author: Jane N.

description:
yummy lip smacking good italian food. salads, seafood, steaks, poultry, and pastas are ALL good here. and who doesn't love a gigantor bowl of assorted gummy bears and a plate of amaretti cookies after dinner? i personally like to pick out the clear gummy bears and sandwich them between 2 cookies.

sorry i have to take one star off due to the horrendous parking. be prepared to circle continuously around the block.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
I love this place. Seriously. I can't understand the low ratings, because it is the one dependable place in North Beach where I don't have to guess whether or not I'm wasting my time and money when I want Italian in San Francisco.

So I really only came upon this place quite haphazardly. My roommate and I were on Columbus on St. Patrick's day last year, and we are not the drinking types, so we were trying to avoid the overwhelming fratboyishness that was taking over the whole city. My roommate is big on Tiffany lamps, and what should be hanging all over this kitschy little restaurant but Tiffany lamps. So of course we had to go in. (They also have hilarious wall friezes and whatnot of ridiculous Italian scenes and sculptures. It's all beautifully tacky.)

What we didn't expect was that it was delicious. We shared a pasta dish (poor college students don't got much to splurge, y'know?) and it was unbelievable. I cannot for the life of me remember what it was, but it was amazing. It had a pink cream sauce, and I believe there was seafood in it. However, before the meal there was some fresh bruschetta, and a big piece of parmesan to gnaw on. I'm a fan. We only had water, but I hear the wine is lovely.

After the exemplary entree, instead of just being presented with the bill, there were amaretto cookies and gummy bears! Truly surprising. At no time did this place fail to impress and entertain. The decor, the waitstaff, the appetizers, and the finishing touches. It was so much fun.

The only cruel part: they were closed yesterday!
author: Mea H.

description:
After trolling the streets of North Beach for an hour looking for just the "right" place to eat after a long day, and actually walking out of a nearby restaurant (where we endured the most horrific service for about 2 minutes), we slowed to a creep in front of this place.  Eyes glazed in fatigue and mild disorientation, we came to as a bouncy host popped his head out the door and offered us a table, explaining in a thick (real?) Italian accent that we simply must come in and try the osso buco.  We were relieved to have the decision lifted, and happily entered the small, simple, but inviting space.  A few minutes later, with fresh wine, beer, bread, free bruschetta and olives, we were feeling pretty ducky.

We had lobster ravioli (tasty, but basic red cream sauce) and veal something (tender, simple, w/broccoli on the side).  Overall a satisfying meal, but nothing spectacular.

...loving it!  More freebies after we declined dessert/coffee.  A big bowl of gummy bears and another of tiny amaretto cookies!  Okay, so it's not that I didn't WANT dessert, I just was saving room for gelato across the street.

The server was ever as exuberant through the meal, and incredibly accomodating.  I'd probably go back, but only if I was indecisive and lost again in North Beach.
author: Katie C.

description:
Fine versions of Italian standards.  I had the gnocchi with tomato sauce.  Shared a salad to start.  Enjoyed the complementary bruschetta to begin and the amaretto cookies at the end (the gummy bears were cute but I'm just not into gummy bears).

Found this place as we were looking for a restaurant that could seat us before a concert nearby.  They had pasta which we wanted and had a booth for us right away.  I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but would go back if in the neighborhood.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Small cute restaurant with ornate decorations all over the walls. It's a simple menu, but my pasta with vongole was perfect. My friend's pasta with seafood was also very top notch. We were satisfied and happy. 

And they are all about the free stuff! Free bruschetta for an appetizer and at the end of the meal, they bring out 2 small plates, one with almond cookies (really sweet and sugary) and one with gummy bears free of charge! 

Good food and great service!
author: Gladys C.

description:
I tried this restaurant for the 1st time last Saturday evening and I thoroughly enjoyed the experience!

Its a place where you feel like family. Where you know about their special things like "chicken juice" and the complimentary dessert. Where they're willing to make special dishes to accommodate your palate - nice!

The "chicken juice" is their light, fruity house red wine that's served in a large (heavy) chicken pitcher - the wine pours out of the chicken's beak. Kinda' eerie, but I couldn't help but stare at the beak every time I poured!

My friend's pasta seafood combo in red sauce was delicious! A large bowl with generous portions of calamari, fish, scallops, clams, and mussels (he requested they hold the shrimp).
My gnocchi was absolutely DEE-LISH-US! I asked for pesto sauce instead of tomato and they were happy to comply - that creamy yummy pesto sauce was so good I wanted to drink it! And I cleaned my plate because the gnocchi was perfect! Tender and chewy! Mmmmm!!!

The service was great. They were very attentive. I felt so comfortable and welcome there!

4.5 stars, that's my final answer! I would have given it 5 stars if the complimentary dessert hadn't been funky - the gummy bears were fine, but the almond cookies were so strange tasting. Almost like they were fermented? A very sharp bitter and slightly alcohol-like taste to them. Hm. Maybe that batch was off.
author: Sharon W.

description: This place was great in 2000 and steadily declined until around 2009 when it came under new ownership. Things have gotten back to the old standard and perhaps surpassed it. The food has been upgraded substantially.  If you want a casual fun Italian place to take guests from out of town to in North Beach this is the spot.  One of the few spots in the city where it is easy to take your small kids
author: micah g.

description:
We ordered our food to be picked up for dinner. They open at 5pm for dinner but we arrived 10 minutes to 5, and they were great about welcoming us in and getting our food to us ASAP.  The fact that the owner, his friend, and the waitress were all speaking to each other in Italian is a good sign.

They sent us off with piping hot ravioli that was phenomenal - fresh cheese filling inside spinich pasta with what tasted like a sweet potato/pumpkin spiced cream sauce.  I could eat a full bowl of it and not feel guilty at all, it was so good.

The seafood pasta was fresh and had a great combination of mussels, fish, and squid in a red sauce.   They gave us chewy bread, olives and freshly grated parmesan cheese to go as well.  

Good prices always help too, so yay for good prices here!

Definitely would go back again to try their wine and famous gummy bear bowl!
author: Alina S.

description:
Michelangelo Cafe Haiku Review

Tasty noodles make
a soft bed in your tummy
for gummi bears!
author: Karen F.

description:
As of right now, Michelangelo deserves a 3-star rating from this darling Yelper. Let me add that this could easily change. 

I first visited this restaurant on a whim a couple years ago on a trip with some friends here to the city. It's a great memory for me -- I remember friendly staff, good food and an eclectic little nook of a restaurant. 

Tonight a friend and I decided to take on North Beach for dinner, coffee and cannoli *drool*, and I suggested Michelangelo's. Despite the abundance of free stuff (ie: marinated olives, bruschetta, cookies and gummy bears -- woo!), I was pretty underwhelmed. 

The staff were "brief," bordering on uninterested in helping us; the food was mediocre: the gnocchi was good, the eggplant parmesan was NOT. We even decided to do our dessert elsewhere. 

Oh, and for all you OCDers: the gummy bears come on plates now, yeesh. And they do in fact take credit cards... if not, then I just got a free meal.

I would go back to MC for one final try, after all, maybe the third time's a charm? Or is it three strikes you're out? We'll see. Possible edit coming soon.

PS: Irrelevant, but God bless cannoli, and that little hole in the wall we got it from :)
author: Megan B.

description: Lovely little place! Wonderful owner. I had the delicious lobster ravioli, perfectly portioned. Bruchetta was very good, and with the bill came yummy petite biscotti-like cookies and gummy bears! I sat by the window to people-watch and I will be back for the food, ambience, and friendly staff!
author: Sarah W.

description: Flavorless. The place was cute and they give you gummy bears for dessert. But i wouldn't go back.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I'd give this a 4 1/2 if it were available. 
We were taken here by a friend who's a local and had a great experience from the second we walked in the door! Greeted immediately and while it took just a few minutes to get a table, we were all given a free glass of wine! The free bread with balsamic/vinegar was tasty and disappeared very quickly as it was very good. I ordered the Fettuccine Mari E Monti which was the most amazing pasta I'd had in years. I was full, but couldn't stop eating it - it was THAT good. We had the Exotic Bomba for desert which we again devoured. The best part is the bowl of gummy bears that come with the check! We were told about this by our friend before the meal but it would have seemed a bit odd if we weren't expecting it! The staff was a bit distant but it didn't matter - the owner was checking in on us and made us feel welcome. All this along with drinking our wine out of goblets and the wall decor all made for a cozy, fun night out. We are heading back to San Francisco in a few weeks and will be coming back in for another round for sure. See you soon Michelangelo's!
author: Jess R.

description:
Small Italian Restaurant--like any other small Italian Restaurant with a few fake sculptures on the wall.  Analogous with their gummy bear desserts, you can only have so much before the same-ness saturates you.  A nice place to visit once in a while.

And it's cash only, as a foodie I hate it when people go to a cash only place and complain--after they've ate--that it's cash only.  What.  The.  F**k?  Have a little respect for the establishment.  Ignorance is no defense for being rude and stupid.

Atmosphere
The Restaurant may be eye pleasing for the neonate or tourist, but gets old if you go there often enough.  The menu is fairly static.  The place can get cramped.

Food
When I originally found this gem of a restaurant years and years ago, the food was mouth watering.  At one time, the seafood pasta was well worth the price with lots of jumbo shrimp, crab meat, salmon, clams, etc etc etc--you get one jumbo shrimp with the seafood pasta now.  I can remember exactly when the cost cutting began--roughly four years ago around December.  The food is still okay, just no longer great.

Wine list is also moderately priced and average.  Like the food, the wine selection is okay.  If you want good wine, bring your own.

Staff
Friendly but average, sometimes they forget to get stuff.
author: Billy C.

description: During the weekdays when it is slower, they try to lure you in w/a free glass of cheap wine. Parking seems impossible on the weekends, so allow for extra time and be prepared for a wait. Friendly staff, however, the owner seems preoccupied, frenzied and a bit stressed during my past couple visits. I recommend the seafood linguine (big portions of fresh seafood; much better than that place next door and worth the extra cost). Not impressed with the small lasagna that was too sweet and runny. Free gummy bears and cookies at meals' end are a nice treat. They also accept restaurant dotkom coupons.
author: Nancy F.

description:
I'm guessing the guy standing out the door was the owner, because my grandma and I were trying to look at the menu outside. And somehow he convinced us to come in for dinner and he offered us a complimentary wine (of our choice) and free bruschetta. He got me on free wine (hha) We ordered some noodles with bits and piece of bacon's (odd dish..never had it and never i would order it again) The noodles weren't fully cooked either. It also came with bread (which I love dipping with vinegar and oil--yum!). After we were done eating the waiter came with some cookies and gummy bears-if you have a grandma like mine she took everything that were free, because she wasn't satisfy with the main course (hha). 
One decor was odd and I took a picture of it. The waiter we had that day was not very nice he didn't have a smile or anything he was like "here you go..finish? okay-clean up" it was like he in a hurry or something. Didn't feel welcome I guess you can say it like that. 

The bill was $15 for our bacon noodles.
author: Lina L.

description: Don't eat there. Save your money. The owner is so greedy and the ingredients are very cheap. The food at Denny's is better. Lol
author: Robin S.

description: We were picking my son up from the airport at 10pm so we decided to stop in North Beach for Italian food.  Recently I had been to Volare Trattoria during Americas Cup and it was great.  We decided to try something different, Michelangelos.  The faux wall statues are interesting and the waiter greated us with "Buena Serra".  The basket of bread was stale. The free bruchetta was very good.   I ordered the fetucini with scallops and prawns also a class of chianti.  The dish arrived and looked good, 2 large scallops and 2 jumbo prawns, mushrooms, peas in a nice cream red sauce over fetucini.  The sauce was great, seafood good, pasta ok, mushrooms had a strange metallic taste. The chianti was ok but not worth $8.00 My husband ordered the pasta with meat sauce and loved it!  I thought he was going to lick the plate :).  I would say the service was very good, no problem with the owner or waiters, but that may be because we did NOT have a coupon.  I would try something else next time but my husband would eat here again.
author: Lorrie P.

description: I am still salivating  a year later. The gnocci and bolognese sauce were incredible. This restaurant was a gem of a find. I am from Virginia and was traveling with a friend when we had taken the restaurants business card. We circled around the neighborhood and decided we wanted to try the place. Again what am amazing restaurant,chef and owner.  Long after the food digested the hospitality we were given continues to  linger on. Me and my friend have passed the business cards to friends traveling to San Francisco and all have been equally pleased!
author: Sharon C.

description:
I can't say enough good things about the owner. My sister, her roommate and I were heading over the North Beach area for drinks later so we decided to grab dinner there as well. We wandered up and down the street looking for a place and passed on Michelangelo's originally because of the sort of tacky decor. However, we changed our minds and came back. And good thing we did.

I had been to Italy the summer before and had learned some basic Italian before my trip. When the waiter came over and greeted us in Italian, I automatically responded back in Italian. Well, this must have won him over. He chatted with us for awhile about various parts of Italy while we waited for our order. Several courses and a couple of bottles of wine later, we were one of the last two tables still there in the restaurant. The owner came over and pulled up a chair. He brought with him a bottle of wine. "On the house" he said "for the bellas." With the wine he also insisted on treating us to dessert. We spoke about his hometown in Italy and his trip to San Francisco. Francis Ford Coppola hired him to come over from Sicily to cook for him. Random!

The place is so great! I will definitely go back there again!
author: Jillian S.

description:
So good. So... so very good. I was introduced to this place by a guy who loves Italian food and has been all over the world-- he says this was the only place he'd found that does the proscuitto appetizer right. The tortellini is amazing. I'm no expert maybe, but this remains my favorite restaurant ever. Period.

(...And as for all of you squeamish people bitching about the gummi bears-- they are now serving them on individual plates instead of the communal bowl thing, so you can calm down.)
author: Leah C.

description:
I am surprised at the bad reviews! We thought it was great! We came to the city to see Beach Blanket Babylon and wandered the surrounding streets for a place to eat afterwards. We were offered the free glass of wine but kept walking the first time, then after seeing how crowded the other places were, we went back. We were seated right away by a friendly hostess and were immediately greeted by the wine and bruschetta - which was delicious! We ate there the same night as Ben B. but had a completely different experience. I, too, ordered the Spaghetti Carbonara and it was delicious. Everyone does it differently, cut them some slack. It tasted great and just based on that alone I'd be back! My husband got the veal stuffed with gargonzola and it was delicious as well and cooked exactly to his specifications. The gummy bears and cookies at the end are a little quirky but in this day and age and in this particular area, you have to stand out and I thought it was unique and charming. Our waiter - Antonio - was excellent! Very attentive but not overbearing. The only down side was the TV playing - it was a little distracting and seemed more fitting in a bar or family style restaurant. The noise level was quite high as well, I don't think the faux statues do enough to absorb the sound!
Overall it was a great experience and we can't wait to go back!
author: Karen C.

description:
This place serves up average italian dishes and excelled at their appetizers.  The melon and proscuitto was great as well as the calamari.  The calamari was not overcooked and was surprisingly tender.  Accompanying red sauce was nothing special.  My dining partners chose pasta dishes which they didn't find exciting nor disappointing.  Previous visits by another dining partner said similar about the pasta dishes.

The house wines come in entertaining rooster pitchers.  Service is average and nothing to remember.  They have some nice window seats for great people watching.
author: Simon Y.

description:
Came in here for dessert.  Enjoyed the atmosphere and the plaster statues on the walls. The chocolate fondant cake was tasty, but unmemorable.

The mysterious plate full of gummy bears (yes...a heaping plate) came with our check.  That's right, this place gives you dessert even after dessert.
author: Mel B.

description: Went here on a recommendation from a native San Franciscan.  This is a smaller, old school, family owned restaurant. The food is fantastic and very reasonable prices. It's no-kidding fresh homemade pasta. Can't wait to go again!
author: Heidi L.

description: Amazing!!! Manager was very welcoming and gracious. Offered us complimentary glasses of wine and free appetizer. The food tasted great! Best lasagna I've had in a very long time! The portions were just right! Just the right amount to leave you happy full. All in all a very enjoyable and delicious dinner!! A++! 5*
author: Andrew H.

description:
Stopped here because Mom and Dad were lured in by the hustling owner....the food was good, portions were just below average (but that is a good thing!- you can eat, eat, and eat in this city!), and the employees were nice.

Nothing special, but the food was good, well priced, and lunch for 3 was $55 with no alcohol.

I would recommend for a fast lunch.
author: KG G.

description:
Living in the city, I tend to avoid the North Beach area, considering it a great source of tourist tax revenue but not much of an attraction to an unemployed local who basically lives off pasta anyway. Maybe you people with incomes don't realize this, but pasta is cheap. Canned tomatoes too. I can only imagine the profit margin when you buy these in bulk and sell them to tourists.
Anyway, my friend was visiting and wanted to see the tourist hot spots, so off we went. She wanted gnocci and I wanted to spend less than $12. We wandered hopelessly up Columbus, past taquerias, pho shops, and an enormous fusion restaurant serving Indian curry and German beer. We almost gave up, when Michelangelo himself stopped us on the street.
"Lovely ladies! May I offer you a free glass of wine?"
Normally, such a question from a middle-aged man with chest hair curling out of his collar makes me cringe, but he had the good sense to follow it with the ever-endearing,
"You're both over 21, no?"
And with that, Michelangelo, you won me over. We were ushered to a seat by the window, further encouraged by offers of free appetizers (and a description of the cheapest menu items.)
Luckily, my friend isn't as terrified of service people as I am, and reminded the waiter about our promised freebies.
I had the lasagna, which was impressive. Then again, I generally only eat boxed frozen lasagna which requires a solid 12 minutes of microwaving and who has that kind of patience? I had forgotten how tasty lasagna can be when it doesn't have a solid core of lasagnacicle.
At the end of our meal, the waiter brought a dish of cookies and gummy bears. My dining companion wanted the cookies, so I grabbed a handful of gummies and off we went. Michelangelo stopped us as we were leaving, and offered us his card, which had a coupon for free wine and appetizers on the back. There went all my delusions of being so devastatingly gorgeous that he was forced to ply me with gifts so he could have me in his window. I quickly transferred my sticky handful of melting gummies so I could shake his hand, and went to lie in the sunshine of Washington Park.
All in all, I would recommend it. If you want authentic Italian, go to Italy. If you're in North Beach and want some cute ambiance, this is the place.
author: Claire C.

description: Amazing wine and dinner. Everyhig fresh and home made. The pasta tasted like it was made fresh that day and the service and atmosphere was calm and relaxing for dinner. I loved the cookies and gummi bears for dessert
author: Emerald A.

description:
came here for lunch with coworkers the other day.  i'd say it's decent food with a great location.  

seated by the window we had a prime view of washington square park, and opening the window meant we could enjoy the warmth of late spring that is finally coming to san francisco.  

our waiter was rude and brusque (seems to be a popular mentality at some of these restaurants along columbus), but the woman refilling our bread and water was very nice.  

so the food.  3 of us ordered the lobster ravioli.  the other two ravioli eaters seemed really happy with their pasta, so that's good.  i certainly liked it, but it seemed generic to me.  the vodka tomato sauce didn't taste homemade (it was good, it just seemed like it came out of a sauce packet or really good can).  the raviolis thankfully had obviously real lobster in them, and had a good flavor, again, though, i highly doubt they were made fresh on site.  so it was a good meal, it just seems like something i could easily make from home with a box of frozen ravioli and a jar of vodka sauce.  

free wine offered by the owner got us in the door, but i wasn't planning on ordering wine, so it didn't really add much to my meal.  all in all, good, basic food, but i think i'll keep walking down columbus next time.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
We've eaten here several times over the past two years. The first time was fantastic... perfectly prepared salmon and gnocchi, a romantic dinner for two at North Beach. We have returned 4 times since then and I think tonight was our last night there. 

A Tuesday night at 8pm and there was only one other customer in the place... 

1. appetizer: tomatoes, basil, mozzarella and olive oil. The cheese was just like the balls from Safeway and the tomatoes were a bit under ripe and were mealy - definitely not heirloom or anything special. 
2. pasta: pumpkin ravioli with a vegetable sauce... actually pretty good 
3. main course: chicken dish for boyfriend (he eats anything so he was happy), salmon for me. I asked for very light on the sauce (specified no sauce on potatoes or broccoli because I knew that the chef was heavy-handed and I expected the fish to be delicious without it). Fish was undercooked and entire plate was swimming in sauce. Waitress took it back and second fish was a bit tough and still too much sauce.  And the chef/owner glared at me a few times while he prepared it.

Did get the free wine and bruschetta, cookies and gummi bears. 

Note to wait staff: if you are going to serve commercial cookies, at least make sure they are plated nicely - upside down cookies look like you don't even care. And yes, the house wine is really cheap. We have had better bruschetta, too. The bread was extra crunchy this time and not enough garlic and basil, mostly watery tomatoes. 

Note to young man hawking the place: do not stand out front with your hands locked on your head. Showing your underarms to potential customers is most unappetizing.

I do have to say that every time my boyfriend has gotten the large bowl of seafood soup/pasta, he has been quite pleased.  However, how hard can it be to poach salmon?  I have also noted the price fluctuations over time.  This time the fish was $2 more than the place next door and the pasta was $2-$3 more.

As you can see by recent reviews here, the food and service are hit-or-miss and tonight was a miss for us.
author: MF L.

description:
I was out with my sister and cousin that were visiting and was walking down Columbus st when we walked by the restaurant and the owner Michelangelo approached us.  We came back later after Beach Blanket Babylon .  The food was great and staff took care of us with no rush
Defiantly will be going back.
author: Michael K.

description:
The place is way too expensive for mediocre food. 

The service was mediocre also.

I over all was not impressed.

I would only go back if I was dead, starving, and or dying.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Not wild about this one for a number of reasons. Firstly, the food is decidedly mediocre and, secondly, they have some seriously weird ideas about presentation: my husband was served his spaghetti in a big plastic punch bowl! Thirdly, the management is not very friendly: I do a lot of volunteering - specifically in event planning - and recently went to ask, very politely, for a small gift certificate for a fundraiser. Now, I don't expect everyone I ask to give, but the manager rudely chased me out the door and wouldn't even let me leave my letter! I didn't get that treatment anywhere else. 

On the positive side, the food is pretty cheap and I do like the big block of parmesan they bring around every now and then. The gummy bears thing is odd, though, as another reviewer has commented (although I don't have the same concerns about germs!). In summary, I'd say it's your typical North Beach tourist trap - reasonably priced, but uninteresting, badly presented food and not the nicest people in the world running it. You can do better, but you can also do worse - you can certainly be ripped off more.
author: Ellen H.

description:
Salva Mi!

Oh Salvatore your restaurant is divine. Shlocked or not it's an all around gut-bustin Wunder-licious carb factory! YUM! Family-style long tables under faux tiffany, surrounded by larger-than-life nudes.. and there is no cover!  Be prepared for the tourists and the subsequent delays due to their knuckle-whitening requests for butter etc., and hey, bring the kids!
author: Genevra P.

description:
5 stars for service
3.5 stars for food

I like bringing visiting friends here as it 'feels Italian" even tho' it is owned by a Portuguese guy. It has that European "Take your time, enjoy, eat, drink, talk to your neighbor." feel.

I don't eat the cookies or gummy bears, tho'  too many hands have been in those bowls -YUCK!
author: Me Y.

description: I ate at Michelangelo for the first time when visiting San Francisco in 2000, and I've been there on every visit to the city since then.  Reading the negative reviews gave me pause, thinking that an old favorite had gone downhill, but my girlfriend and I went on a recent visit to the city.  I don't know what the issue is with the negative reviewers, but Michelangelo Ristorante & Caffe is just as great as it always has been.  We started by splitting the antipasto and having a couple of glasses of wine.  The waiter brought bruschetta and comped us the rest of the bottle (half a bottle).  We then had the Ciopinno and the Spaghetti Carbonara.  The Ciopinno was interesting...it contained pasta and the broth was slightly weak, but it was loaded with seafood.  The Spaghetti Carbonara was the best I've ever had.  The portions were very generous.  This is a great restaurant...we will be back!!
author: Steven G.

description: Interesting decor, reasonably priced, pretty good food.
author: Scott R. D.

description: Iffy place, pizza made my tummy hurt. The owner actually asked a passer by to bring him a slice of pizza from another restaurant...that says it all.
author: Cynthia T.

description: You will enjoy the people and the decor, you are back among the arts of Italy and the owner and staff extend the warm traditional hospitality of Italy. Buon Apetito!
author: Katherine W.

description:
This is the worst Italian restaurant, wait scratch that, this is worst restaurant I have ever eaten in my life. I don't write reviews, but I thought I should warn people of the risk that they might be taken before eating here. My boyfriend literally vomited in the bushes not more than a block away after eating there. And I know what you're thinking he was probably drunk but he in fact he doesn't drink at all. It's just that the food was that bad.  I have been suffering from an upset stomach as well. 

The food was not only bad it lack flavor and style. The caprese salad was bland. The prosciuttos if you want to even call it that was also bland.  It might as well have come out a zip lock bag labeled deli meat. I do have to say that the melon that came with it was sweet and fresh. The Chippino was so fishy that I barley touched it. I ate a few clams and asked for the rest to go. The veal Parmesan was as flat as a pancake and it had a hunk of melted cheese that covered that whole thing.  Cheese was probably trying to mask the fact that one it didn't taste good, and two it wasn't real meat. I'm sorry but I use to live in North Beach and 10 years ago I loved this place I am so disappointed! And the price was like $75.00! I felt so ripped off. I wish I had said something right then and there and refuse to pay for my meal. I really hope they get a clue and change their ways. I can't see them managing to stay open much longer; then again there will always be tourist who will think there getting a real authentic Italian meal. I've been to Italy four times and the spaghetti factory would be more authentic than this place.
author: kristie l.

description:
Went there for lunch on a Sunday to celebrate a friend's birthday.  Staff was very accommodating.  We asked them to put a candle on a cake we bought at a bakery and to come out with it right before dessert, and they actually sang Happy Birthday in Italian for my friend when they did.  Which was unexpected, but nice.  

We ordered a dessert from their dessert menu and it was very good.  Would highly recommend their desserts.  As for their entrees, I'd recommend the pasta dishes and stay away from the meat dishes.  We ordered the tortellini, the veal, and the salmon.  The first was good, but the other two were only mediocre.  We did get the free bread and olives in the beginning though.  

We also got free roses when we left.  As we were walking out, we saw that they were offering roses and a free glass of wine on Sundays.  We didn't get the glass of wine, but that might have been only for dinner.
author: Ria H.

description: Well, call this place an italian restaurant is a little bit exaggerated...food is ok but not authentic. there are other better options in North Beach, don't leave your money here
author: Marco D.

description: Michelangelo's is an absolutely wonderful place to take a  guest, especially an out of state guest. My husband and I took my Vermont sister to Michelangelo's and, boy, did we have a great time. We were looking for an Italian North Beach experience and we got it. The decor is intimate and the wall statues make you feel like you are in Italy. Our waiter was the restaurant's owner, a real Italian born with genuine accent. He was filling in for an absent waiter and he was tons of fun and gave us superior service. He spent lots of time talking and joking with us. When I switched my order from spaghetti and meat balls to eggplant parmigiana, he brought me a big side of the spaghetti and meat balls anyway, for no charge. They were the best meatballs! My sister's and husband's dinners were also excellent. After olives and bread, a large delicious antipasto, entrees+, dessert and the tasty house chianti, we had to take the finale gummy bears to go. We used a Groupon coupon, but it was well worth it without the coupon. We will return to this fun and delicious find!
author: K B.

description: Walked up and down Columbus and was drawn into Michelangelo's by the owner.  We had been there a few times but not for 5 years or so.  I have only good things to say about our dinner.  The bread was fresh crusty iItalian bread, great for dipping into the balsamic vinegar and olive oil as well as the marinara in the entrees.  I recommend both the gnochi and the eggplant parmesian.   The seafood with pasta was not as good as the other entress but still enjoyable.  The service was excellent especially when they played an Italian version of happy birthday with the lights dimming and flashing on and off for my son's celebration.  The tiramasu was a perfect ending!  I'll be back.
author: Rob T.

description: Terrible!  The service was slow, the food was bad, very disappointed.  When we sat down we waited for 10 minutes for menu, bread and had to ask for water.   I ordered a Cesar salad and pasta with meatballs.  The salad was warm and the lettuce was wilted.  The pasta was nothing special.  Too bad as we've been going there for years, but seems to have gone down hill.  There was only two waiters for the whole place.  When we mentioned to one waitress that they were short handed tonight, she replied, "they like it that way."  Oh my...we need to find another Italian place.  Goodbye Michelangelo!
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description: my feelings are that you'll totally hate or love this place.  if you're looking for something super posh, you'll hate it.  it's got kinda cheesy decor.  it reminds me of when i lived in spain, and ate at restaurants that weren't super posh in spain, so i loved it.  family owned.  someone in the reviews was complaining about mexican cooks?  i don't know, i didn't see any.  but stop being racist on yelp, jerk!  i heard two men speaking italian, fwiw.  it seemed like a pretty legit father/son operation when we were there.  some old guy hangin' out on his laptop playing his mix of italian pop tunes whilst serving us.  +1 for some odd heartland rock in italian that sounded like an italian version of bruce springsteen (i know bruce springsteen is technically italian american, but you know what i mean!!!)  i got the special.  risotto with asparagus and some amazing mushrooms mixed in.  i more or less rolled out, very pleased.  waiter was super nice.  it was kinda divey in a perfect way.  i'm a fan.  i'd totally come back here, and would be pleased that i hadn't forked over piles of money.  i'm not sure that tourists would waste money on this place because we picked it because it looked cheap and open.  it definitely feels like home cooked food, which is what makes this place a gem.
author: maria f.

description:
I hate food snobs. I really do. But there is one area where I allow myself to be snobby, and that is when it comes to Italian food. Growing up with my grandma's Italian cooking, living with an Italian family for four months and dining in restaurants from Milan to Amalfi has given me an acute sense of what makes good Italian food. 

It's amazing to me that North Beach is so populated with cheesy, overpriced Italian joints with blah food. Where are all the authentic, delicious places? Please tell me.

All of that to say, Michelangelo is highly mediocre. Starting with the bread, that was dry, flavorless and left much to be desired, and ending with the crappy service, I would not go back. I got gnocchi, which was decent, a bit starchy in a way that's hard to avoid with gnocchi, and in a red sauce that was definitely edible, but tasted like I could have gotten in boxed at Trader Joes.

Our waiter neglected to refill bread and water until he was asked twice. And all around us people had plates of gummy bears and cookies, which is apparently their cheesy fun thing they do, but we didn't get a plate, even when we asked for one. So instead of leaving with the taste of manufactured fruit in my mouth, I instead left with a taste of boring red sauce and bitterness.
author: Sara R.

description: My boyfriend and I found this adorably tacky restaurant late one night craving Italian food (and where better to go but North Beach?), and ended up having a really delicious meal. They bring you out warm, fresh bruschetta which is pretty incredible in my book, and after your meal they bring out gummy bears and amaretto cookies- so odd but, cute. The food is all pretty standard but pretty good. Minus one star for the weird building/table arrangement. There's this really sharp corner where they try to fit about 5 tables and it's just awkward.
author: Lauren S.

description: A group of our friends and I had  lost our reservation at another restaurant nearby. As we passed Michelangelo's the owner was outside and stopped us, offered a complimentary glass of wine while we waitd. We were on a tight time schedule since we had tickets to a concert. They were very quick with our order, very pleasant and considerate of our time. The food was great. My friend and I shared the shrimp cocktail and the tortellini. Very yummy!!!!! While we were there for the span of about an hour their were 3 different birthdays going on. They sing happy birthday in italian and dimmed the lights to set the mood. It is totally cute family owned restaurant. Loved it!!!
author: Shawntae T.

description:
i arrived a bit early (escaping a bad blind date down the street) to meet my party for dinner, and the very friendly owner demanded that i have a glass of wine to keep me warm while i waited (there is not room inside to wait, nor is there a bar) this glass of wine was filled at least 3 times before i was seated, and i never saw the bill.

i was a bit tossed, but i vaguely remember the raviolis rocking my world.
author: Jessi B.

description:
Michelangelo Ristorante & Caffe is a very small cafe in the heart of North Beach. I've been here 2 times in the past few years.
The first time it was an amazing and unforgettable experience. There was a birthday in the restaurant and the waiters all turned off the lights as they sang happy birthday and presented a big cake to the birthday guy.
The last time I went there I noticed that the restaurant was very, very hot. You should not sweat in the middle of February in a restaurant. The gnocchi that I ordered was really good. It was nice to get an free basket of bread with garlic and tomatoes. Dessert is always on the house - gummy bears and almond cookies. Yummy.
This is a nice and quaint place to pass the time. Be prepared to feel a little boxed in. Other than that, just judging the food and the service - I give it  4 stars. I am taking off 1 star for the size of the place and the temperature in the cafe.
author: guess w.

description: Food taste/quality is a "2" on a scale of 1-10...don't get hooked in by the complimentary wine and appetizer!  VERY DISAPPOINTING!!!!
author: Darren A.

description: This place really isn't as bad as the negative reviews would make you think. We had very friendly and efficient service and the calamari, tiramisu and espresso were especially good. The main dishes weren't anything special and were unnecessarily rich, so I'd stick to simple stuff like pastas. If you have a coupon and go in with minimal expectations this place is fine!
author: Geoffrey U.

description: We went here for a friend's birthday in February, and with the prices on the menu we thought the food would be really something special. We could only afford to order three dishes, and the waiter raised his eyebrow at that. The dishes came out quickly and were all warm, but not hot. The gnocchis tasted like they had been frozen, then microwaved. The raviolis were not fresh, either, they definitely tasted like they had been frozen. They were soggy and flavorless. The red sauce for both of those dishes tasted like it came from a can--very bland and uninteresting. The atmosphere is cute and in a good place in the city. The service was friendly, good wine, and the gummi bears at the end are cute, but a little tacky.
author: lizzie r.

description: I just had such a disapointing experience at an old favorite restaurant. The ownership may have changed, as I have not been in quite awhile.
