The waiter could have cared less about serving us. We waited almost an hour for our food, which turned out to be truly underwhelming. When the waiter finally came by to ask how everything was and I said "so so" he literally walked away laughing. Maybe it is the economy, maybe they just don't care, but they stopped serving at 8:00 on a Wednesday night    ( just because the waiter wanted to get off and flirt with girls at a table), but they turned away at least 4 tables while we sat there. Actually, those people were lucky. I hope I don't get food poisining! It is sad, this truly used to be one my favorite restaurants, now I will never go back. Oh well, everyhthing changes!
author: anne s.

description: Never had the food here, but the Tirimisu was hands down the best my wife an I have every had (including in Italy).  Skip all the cafes in North Beach and desert here!
author: Barry m.

description: Having been a long time North Beach resident and patron of Michelangelo, I was surprised to see no line on a Saturday night, so we went in for dinner.    Times must have changed there, because they treated us as rudely as any tourists they never expect to see again, and served plates of slop that makes Tommy's Joynt look like Gary Danko.   Sadly the owner/mananger no longer takes in pride their food, as they served us un-cooked Salmon (not sushi) and host of other bland gruel.  The forgetable meal was capped with an unapologetic staff, so I'll never go there again and feel like I've been robbed.
author: X. D.

description: The food was fantastic and the service was great. We had a great time at this cute little restaurant. The "margarita pizza" was amazing. I only wish I had this restaurant near my home in San Diego.
author: Charles G.

description: I had my birthday dinner with my family here tonight there was eight of us they were more than welcoming and the food was great service was excellent!! Prices were great.. Worm homely Italian restaurant beautiful atmosphere.. Could not ask for a better place to go.. Thank you will be back soon
author: Courtney P.

description: I really liked coming here during my college years. The food was great, affordable and the staff are friendly.  Being back again nothing has really changed other than now you get a free glass of house wine as you wait. I had the cioppino and it was great and the prices are still  reasonable. The staff is still super friendly and hilarious. They even came around the tables with chunks of parmesan cheese to pass around. I liked it back then and i still do. Will defiantly be back.
author: Eve L.

description: Took some clients and needed a table for 8.  They seated us right away and took care of us well. Food OK, but it beats waiting an hour for a table when you are with a group. Would go again the a group.
author: Tim S.

description: Mediocre pasta with marinara sauce, horrible pizza, really bad service.  The best part was dessert.  The food used to be good but it has gone downhill.  I will not return.
author: Stacie M.

description:
I am beyond disappointed in Michelangelo's, having just eaten here today, and having looked forward SO much to my meal here. I first started going to Michelangelo's back in the 1990s. Back then, the lines would often stretch 20+ people out the door - and that was on a week night. I used to get the Tortellini Michelangelo, and my husband would get their trademark Cioppino. After one of my meals, I even told our waiter, "I want to marry the chef!" The food was knee-crumpling delicious, and the place packed with people. 

So my husband and I drove down from Lake Tahoe to meet a friend there for lunch on a Saturday (today). I seriously wondered if we'd get a table! Now I know why it was no problem. Only two other tables were occupied during the 2 hours we were there. 

First of all, it bugged me that the lunch menu is different from their dinner menu. There was no mention of this on their website at all. So the entree I had picked out in advance wasn't even on the menu. 

Second, the food was beyond blah! It was actually a crushing disappointment. I was embarrassed to have recommended the place to my friend. Our entrees were delivered: 1.) Cioppino, thick, tasteless but fishy tomato sauce utterly lacking in any fresh herb or seasoning, rubbery seafood and shellfish, served with yesterday's stale garlic bread that had been nuked in a microwave so it was tough, chewy and stale. 2.) gnocchi with Bolognese sauce. I could just envision the chef having returned from CostCo with a giant sack of potato gnocchi, huge jar of Italian tomato sauce and 20-lbs of ground beef. The dish was served lukewarm with barely a spec of indistinguishable meat in a gloppy, tasteless sauce. 3.) farmed salmon (yes, farmed! And we only found that out because my friend specifically asked) 4.) penne pasta with a pale, gloppy pinkish tomato sauce. Ye gads. On top of which, when I asked our waitress if we could have some grated Parmesan cheese, she brings over a huge salad bowl of pre-grated crap - again, visions of an oil drum filled with grated cheese rolled right off the truck from CostCo.

Sadly, even our carafe of red wine was utterly without character as if it was half water, half wine. And for this, lunch came to $75. I can make better food at home - and that's after I've bought the ingredients at CostCo myself! 

C'mon guys, what's happened here? The food tastes like the chef (or microwave man) has utterly lost all passion for cooking. I would not only NEVER return to this place again, but I took time tonight to write this review so that others don't make the same mistake. You will save money if you buy a jar of Paul Newman's sauce, slop it onto your own pasta, and serve it with fresh bread and your own bottle of wine! 

And now I'm going to post the same review at Michelangelo's website (assuming their link "Post Your Comments" is not broken).
author: Tahoe Q.

description: Very nice host and wait staff, tasty good food, and I loved the décor. Try the specials.
author: Jade P.

description:
north beach is a serious pain in the ass.  i mean, i love it, love all the little restaurants, the fresh pastries and gelatos and the great cafe's...but still it's a pain in the ass. parking sucks and i hate the throngs of tourist...but this place is worth the trek.

consistently great homestyle italian food, and lots of it for small prices!
there is always a line of people waiting for a table (they don't take reservations).  chisel off a piece of parmesan from the block while you're waiting for your table...have a glass of house wine, you can't beat it.  fresh homemade pastas, rich cioppinos and friendly service, what more could you ask for?  hmmm...let's see, how about those great almond cookies and some gummy bears for dessert...so random, but cute and FREE!

the place is small, but i go nowhere without my posse of and we've hit this place on a friday night.  i thought it would be impossible to get a table for 10, but they managed to pull it all together, in just under an hour.  absolutely amazing!

4 stars for great food and 1 for super service.
author: Jennifer G.

description: I call this place "poo bears".  I'm not talking cute, cuddly Winnie the Pooh.  I'm talking about the gigantic, community bowl of gummy bears that they give you at the end of your meal and all the poo particles on the hands of the people before you who don't wash their hands after being in the bathroom.  Gross!  And what kind of nice Italian meal should be followed with gummy bears anyways?!  The bears say so much about the place.  You have so many other, better choices in the area!
author: Squirrel L.

description: Mixed reviews for this one... the first time we went the place was FUN FUN FUN!!! Waiters dancing on the tables, lots of singing and the huge cheese wheel that they have was being passed around freely.  It was such a great atmosphere.  Plus the big bowl of gummy bears at the end of the night was a little fun addition to the meal.   I couldnt wait to go back.  The second time i went the place was SO QUIET (despite being full)...quiet to the point that I realized the food was just so-so (which i didnt notice the first time cause it was so fun).  I guess if you go, I cant tell you what to expect!
author: Cathleya G.

description: This place was great and the service was exceptional. My friend ordered the tiramasu just for himself and he ate every last bite.   The waitstaff was working hard to keep up on a busy night but deserves credit for their excellent service.
author: Sonny D.

description: We walked here from Pier 39 after going on the Blue & Gold Fleet.  Not a quick and easy walk with a 4.5 year-old and a baby in a stroller, but not too long.  We ordered the lasagna ($12) and some breaded chicken with lemon sauce ($14).  They were both excellent, as was all the bread and butter for our kid.  The service was prompt and polite, and they even brought our daughter some gummie bears and cookies on the house.  Just a great place, perfectly located in North Beach, with a beautiful view of Coit Tower.
author: Brent T.

description: "Frutti di Mare is good. Cash only or they laugh at you (if you try to whip out your card). Lines used to be Much longer...not too bad anymore.....hmmmm"
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Was in San Francisco for a vacation and brought a groupon for dinner.  Was excited to try the place after reading some of the reviews. Unfortunately it was a HUGE dissapointment.   Our waiter didnt seemed too thrilled we had a groupon and then when I told him I had a dairy allergy, he was not accomodating to my situation. He was basically throwing up his hands and had no sugesstions.  When  I suggested  plain pasta with chicken and the red marinara on the side he got upset and said he couldnt do it cause the meat had to be cooked in the sauce.  Ok. I conceded but wanted the sauce and chicken on the side in case I didnt like it...having just come  off a stomach flu, I wasnt sure how it would settle on my stomach...at least I would have plain pasta to eat.  My husbands Caesar salad was  adequate but nothing special.    When the food came out all my food was cooked together. When I asked if my order wasnt possible (the marinarsa sauce literally tasted like tomato sauce)....which was very acidic.... The waiter grabbed my plates and huffed off and completely ignored us until the new food was done 15 mins later. Out he comes with 3 separate plates which he  put on the table and then walked off.  Very rude the rest of the nite.  My husband had tortelini which was good but small portion with no presentation. His teramasu was good too but no presentation. We left a small tip and left. If you eat here, dont have high expectations, dont have a food allergy and make sure you order directly off the menu. Any variations are not appreciated.
author: Dana B.

description: I actually don't have much to say about the food, but hello, they walk around with a huge bowl of chunks of parmesan cheese for you to partake in.  What else do you need?  And, if that were not enough, giant bowl of gummy bears!!  And almond cookies.  And, they serve the wine in pretty jugs.
author: L C.

description: Gotta love the giant bowl of gummi bears they give at the end.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Probably one of the most colorful dining experiences in the Bay area due to the Tiffany-esque lighting (there are at least a dozen of those lamps). And I am so into the huge bowl of Parmesan that is served up; I have never seen that large of a Parmesan cheese wheel in my life. I recommend it for going out with friends.
author: Evelyn B.

description: It's another ho hum dinner here close to Washington Square in North Beach.  For a Tuesday night, it was busy and me thinks that a few locals trudged up the street because Yuet Lee on Broadway was closed.  Service was efficient and quick.  The food was so-so, and I had the over-sauced tortellini.  It was a bit over cooked.  It seemed that since this place was packed, there was only one server, and he moved quickly.  Free bruschetta and after the meal, you get a plate full of Gummi Bears and almond cookies.  It is a nice touch.  It's been years since I returned and maybe a few more when I come back.
author: Tony L.

description: 4 stars not because it is a 4 star restaurant necessarily---I have given plenty of restaurants 4 stars that beat the pants off this place.  Michelangelo gets 4 stars because in a neighborhood with tons of tourist laden Italian restaurants, Michelangelo Cafe stands out.  The food is more than good though it is not an "experience," however I have always completely enjoyed my meal.  The staff is friendly, the wine is cheap and tasty--I think you get my point.  Not amazing, but a fun and good option in North Beach.  Good with a group, good for a fun night out, and great for people from out of town who want to eat near Washington Square.
author: Blake W.

description: Great little North Beach Italian restaurant. Fresh pasta hard to beat and prices are resonable. It is REALLY great when tourist season is over. Cozy atmosphere.
author: Barb B.

description: I love the pictures, the sculptures, the friendly waitstaff, the prices, and the selection of great food.  What can I say, it's overwhelming and I like that it's overwhelming.  You're packed in, but that's the way it's supposed to be.  The fantastic rooster pitchers that they serve the house wine in seal the whole deal.  Or wait, maybe the fabulous olives seal the deal.  The prices seem to be better than other places around, but this comes at another price - time.  Get there early or you'll be lining up.
author: Ange F.

description: Loved the food & wine. The service was good- not excellent- but definitely good. The place was a little cramped, but worth it.
author: N A.

description: This place was decent considering the plethora of restaurants in the North Beach Area. Cheaper and more laid back than most and a great "Are we or are we not on a date?" restaurant. By far, the gummy bear idea is pretty great for someone wanting to give their "date/not date" dinner and dessert. The last time I went on one of these outings at the this place we argued over what flavor the clear gummy bears are. By the way, it wasn't a date.
author: Niki M.

description: Best Italian food in the city.  Not super expensive and great service.  Highly recommended!!!
author: Nick L.

description: We ate here after a long Bay to Breakers Sunday. We were sold when the new owner offered us a free glass of wine and a rose for the lady (just realized I forgot the rose). The food is good and the prices are great. The hospitality was great and the reason I will go back.
author: Jessica R.

description: Had an early dinner here this past weekend. I had not been here in quite a few years, and since we were in North Beach, we decided to stop in. The atmosphere was still the same, a weird cornucopia of all things kitschy Italian. I especially love the chandeliers! Started with the calamari, it was fricken awesome! Lightly battered, not tough at all, incredibly light for a fried dish, loved the marinara that accompanied it. Went on and had the veal parmigiana (natch..) and my partner had lasagna. The veal was very good, another dish that was fried, but still light enough to almost finish both cutlets that were served. Tomato sauce that it was marinated in was fantastic! One of the better veal dishes that I've had, not as good as Casa Orinda, but I've never seen a restaurant that was able to duplicate that. Partner's lasagna was perfect! The marinara, the ricotta, the meat, OMG! next time I am definitely having that dish, so good... Our server was Italian through, and through, he was always there when we needed him, and engaged us in quite a lively conversation. We really enjoyed him! Finally after all that food, we were served complimentary gummi bears, and cookies. I thought that was a cute gesture. We will definitely be back! Four Stars!
author: Anthony K.

description: So good.  This a great place to come on a date or with friends.  The interior is simple and beautiful and the food is fantastic.  I think I've had almost every type of pasta they have with every sauce.  I have to say the ravioli is my favorite along with the gnocchi.  They are fairly inexpensive and at the end of the meal they bring you a bowl of gummy bears and yummy little amaretti cookies.  Don't forget to bring cash!
author: Julia E.

description: This place used to be a favorite of my family's. The food and the service were the best ever, but the last time we went (April 2008) the food had sadly gone downhill. We loved the cioppino, which was the best we'd ever had, but nowadays everything is different. The sauce, the amount and quality of the seafood- it's really too bad when a beloved place goes downhill.
author: Catie A.

description:
Went their last night with a friend in a wheelchair. It was fantastic. They moved furniture all over the place so she could get to the bathroom. They were charming and delightful. Lots of wonderful food. Loved the salmon. Great mango sorbet (free). Really nice lentil soup. We took home a huge amount of food and with a really big tip it was only $60. And the decor is amazing! 
The restaurant is definitely wheelchair accessible (obviously) but the bathrooms really aren't.
author: Mark B.

description: My favorite of the ubiquitous Italian eateries in North Beach.  Every time I'm in the neighborhood (I house sit at least twice a year) I eat there at least once.  Great old school/east coast style Italian food.  Classics like chicken parm, penne alfredo and lasagna boulanese dot the menu (the chicken parm, one of my all time faves, is the city's best).  The staff is soo sweet and the wine selection quite good for a medium priced joint.  THIS is the eatery of choice for that style of food in the city  Maybe not as evolved as Delfina or as gourmet as L'Osteria but my absolute favorite for North Beach kitsch.
author: Matt D.

description: The monk fish is delicious and there are lots of it on the plate, I got what my money's worth. the place is small and intimate.
author: Turtle F.

description: The hospitality at this place is amazing!!  The owner Salvatore has such passion for Italy, italian food, and his business.   The food was very yummy!  The decor tacky but interesting  and fun!   He told us great stories about Italy.    Prices great, overall a great time!
author: Vande B.

description:
I went through a phase where I came her almost once a week. 

Like others have said, the atmosphere is super fun. I adore the waiters--they're very energetic and attentive. This spot works well for a date or a large group.

The food is consistently good. Try the pesto pasta.

Yay for a bowl of gummy bears!! And cheese wheel!!

A wonderful North Beach pick!!
author: Nicole R.

description: I went to this restaurant for the first time a month ago and recently brought my family there.  If you are looking for a friendly fun place that has good (not great) food and a free glass of wine to start things off, this is your place.  The fish dishes are very good, the service attentive and more than makes up for any problems (late dish, musty bottle of wine).  They try, try, try to make your experience a good one.  How many other places have you been to lately where that's the case?  I will keep going back because now I feel like family.
author: Christine L.

description: Went here last night for dinner with some friends. Other than the complimentary bruschetta at the beginning, our food was pretty blend (it wasn't exactly cheap, either). I had the eggplant pasta and felt like I was eating cafeteria food except with fresh mozzarella sloppily dropped on there. The gummy bear and cookies at the end didn't really make up for much for me. Kind of a cute place, but the food doesn't even come close. Don't see much value here.
author: Margaret H.

description: I think I understand some of the bad reviews here, although I disagree with them.  I walked past Michelangelo 's with work colleagues, but the owner's offer of free wine and bruschetta freaked them out so we went to a much more expensive restaurant.  I returned the next night with a friend and was so glad I did!  The service was very attentive and the food was very good.  The tortellini was fresh and delicious as was the seafood.  The food was better than the much more expensive place down the street.   That said - the place is a bit quirky.  The décor is eclectic and yes, they give you gummy bears and cookies at the end of your meal.  Odd?  Yes.  But definitely delicious and entirely Italian.  Go visit!
author: Mark T.

description: Excellent service! Personally greeted by the owner,  complimentary glasses of wine while waiting, food is authentic, fabulous, and reasonably priced. Very family friendly. My kids loved it! Even my pickiest eater.
author: M. Jing R.

description: Second time I have been to this restaurant, last time was about 1 year ago and we were really impressed the first time.  This time I was a little dissapointed, the food was very inconsistent.  I and another ordered the lamb chops which were cooked perfectly, but the sauce on my plate tasted different than the sauce on the other order.  Way to much rosemary on his plate.  Wife ordered lobster ravioli's came out looking like a plate of pink mess.  So much sauce you couldn't even tell there were raviolis on the plate. Another ordered crab canneloni and same problem here. Just a bunch of pink sauce on the plate.  Very unappetizing to the eyes, really no other color on the plate.  The taste was just ok, nothing to really want to order again.  All in all the service was the best part of the night, he was great.  Service 4 stars, Food 2.5 stars and dessert 2.5 stars. Kinda dissapointing when the bill $180.00.
author: Ray M.

description: We had a wonderful dinner here last night.  After reading many of the bad reviews, I was a bit worried about trying this place, but I had purchased a Groupon for dinner for 4, so we decided to go anyway.  I called to make a reservation and woman on the phone was very friendly and helpful.  We arrived on time and were seated immediately.  The server was nice, and he and the kitchen staff were sensitive to our allergies and made accommodations by allowing us to have different sauces than what was listed on the menu and making half an order of caprese salad without tomatoes.  We had the gnocchi (with 2 different sauces), spinach cheese ravioli and a chicken dish as well as 2 appetizers and 2 desserts - tiramisu and custard (both FABULOUS!).  Everything was tasty, and the portions were large.  The wait staff were extremely busy since the restaurant was packed the whole time we were there, but they did their best to serve us in a timely way and respond to our requests.  The plates of gummi bears and almond cookies (as additional desserts) were an extra treat, and the bread, olives, olive oil and vinegar at the beginning of the meal were also delicious.  I'm so glad we went!
author: Flora K.

description: East Bay domiciled, the other eve, we wrapped up errands in SF by 5, and we we HUNGRY ... and remembered Michelangelo .. we were warmly greeted and attended by Stefan, and seated ourselves in the window ( early dinn = no wait, amen! ) It was sumptuous and delicious,again. I cannot remember a time when i didn't look forward to dinner there, but honestly, the food and atmosphere seem to get richer and deeperr with each visit, albeit far between, given our East Bay digs these lat 10 + years. I was beside myself, antipasti,  Ceasar, Cioppino, bruscetta, chianti and do try a Moretti Rossa. I left the table to greet a relentless alluring hula hooper across the street Washington Square Park ... charming and unforgettable all around. Michelangelo gots LOV, is in fine traditional hands, what more to say, besides respect ! and grazie maestros   ... BRAVISIMO!
author: corey m.

description: Would not recommend. I mean we're in Little Italy here, come on. I've eaten better Italian dinners on an airplane. Lesson learned here is.... you should never eat at a place that is giving items away for free. I asked for meat sauce with my lasagna, and i think it was chili.....with carrots in it.
author: Larry B.

description: The Eggplant Rollatiini was lighter than a runway model, the pasta was truly al dente and the marinara sauce had red dried  pepper that gave it a subtle hint of heat.
author: Louis F.

description: After spending approx. 3 hours in the car (much of it in traffic) to get back home today, I was craving a good bowl of pasta.  Husband and I hopped the bus to North Beach with the intention of hitting up a place we went a few months back with my parents, but then the "host" of Michelangelo's grabbed us on the street and talked us into a free glass of wine and some lunch.  We went for the prosciutto and melon app. and a bowl of gnocchi.  The appetizer came out looking like a heap of nothing more than prosciutto, so I actually asked the waiter if he planned to bring us the melon as well.  Silly me, it was hiding under a pile of meat.  Wierd...maybe, but we got our money's worth for sure.  The gnocchi came out a while later covered in a thick red tomato sauce.  A few were under cooked but most of them were just right, quite tasty and definitely one of the better gnocchi's I've had in North Beach (and I am above all else, picky about my gnocchi).  The sauce was nice and clean, appropriately flavored and piping hot.  So far, so good.  My only complaint was the service.  They had one poor girl helping a restaurant full of customer's which means we never got checked on and actually had to ask for our bill.  Not her fault, but still something to consider, head in if you're feeling like taking it easy and not in any kind of rush.  All-in-all I'd give it a solid 3.5 stars, it falls nicely  in the upper-middle of my North Beach dining experiences.
author: Chrys W.

description: Michelangelo and his staff of Italian Stallions serve up the best home made Italian we've eaten in San Fran. The Lasagne is just like our Mum's make it, and the Penne alla Norma is to die for. We were too full to try the home made tiramisu, but it looked amazing. Cheap prices, great quality ingredients and the flirty conversations with owner Michelangelo made this a great start to our night out.
author: Sarah V.

description: So, My fiance and I are aiming out culinary sights on Soto Mare for some crazy out of this world cioppino (9 out of 10 stars, if they added larger shrimp it would be a 10),,,I digress. Soto is closed on Sundays so we resort to Rose Pistola to try theirs, they (and I can respect this) are not offering it as they ran out of fresh crab and the chef didn't want to use frozen. We are walking along Columbus and this guy from Michelangelo's starts his sales pitch (as seen on other reviews here) about the free wine etc.. I'm like OK, how's your cioppino? Better than Soto or Tadich? He's all,,,oh yes...it's way better (red flag). OK,,should have known. The people are nice, very nice and I , after eating there, feel sorry for them. So this $19.00 plastic bowl, yes I said plastic bowl of bit's and pieces of clams, mussels, a few squid, and calamari (still chewing these) come out in a watery broth of redness. By the time I'm 1/2 way through this minimal offering it is all cold. Don't need to elaborate any more.
author: Terrance H.

description: I was really craving chicken parmigiana which was not on the lunch menu so I asked the owner if they can make some.  The owner was very nice and made sure I got my chicken parmigiana.  I'm from Jersey and I've eaten at a lot of the high rated, fancy Italian restaurants in SF and have been dining here for years. Michelangelo's chicken parmigiana was really good and I have a hard time believing that some yelpers claim they can make better at home. I would give an extra star if the quality of wine was better even though it was free. I recommend that they don't offer it at all because it does not compliment the food.  The rose was very pretty.  I'm still in search for the perfect pizza in SF that is comparable to the pizza we have in Jersey/NY.  Good location for people watching!
author: Ashley K.

description: hurray for jolly waiters and good italien food. the tomato and mozzerella was fresh and juicy.
author: Janelle H.

description: yes, like every other place in North Beach it's a bit overrun by tourists... but it's a solid choice if you like seafood pasta, particularly shellfish.  the big bowl of gummi bears is fun, even though the cleanliness of it all will certainly give you pause.
author: Nat K.

description: I don't know the woman's name (or at least I never remember) but she is friendly and very tolerant.  Most of my visits there are after a number of drinks, so.....however, the bread, the olive oil, the olives and the chunk o'cheese (if they don't give it, ASK) are enuf to send me home at that point.  I usually bring in my own wine or get the house red, not bad, not great.  The house salad is a nice size and tasty, but this time there was a caprese salad for five on the house which made it taste excellent.  The pastas are all good, not great, but the prices are what steps the taste up slightly.  I get the penne with clams and mussels, and you know what, it is fucking tasty, always.  Oh, yeah, the gummis and the cookies are a decent touch, like anyone needs 'em.
author: AJ L.

description:
I've been coming to Michelangelo's for several years now, and last week's visit made me wonder why we hadn't been back sooner. From the second you  walk in the door your treated like family.  We ordered the fried calamari   fallowed by a huge lamb shank and the salmon. The fresh sauces are always the highlights for me, a rich mushroom sauce on the lamb, a complex but light lemon caper sauce for the salmon, and anything served with the tomato cream or red sauce is always amazing.  The house Chianti is nice and solid, but a very reasonable wine list is worth a look.  We shared a delicious tiramisu, and as our glasses emptied we were met  by the owner pouring us port on the house. 
We ended up sitting another hour and a half, ordering coffee, eatting gummi bears and enjoying the atmosphere.
While it can get loud resulting in the service less personal, I've always felt very at home and welcome, and on slower nights it's never failed to be a nice intimate spot for a long dinner and good conversation.
author: ali s.

description: It was always a treat to come to this North Beach destination spot but the food has gone down hill. I had dinner there Sunday night September 16 2008 and it was mediocre at best.
author: Rico S.

description: Great casual, but fun/quirky atmosphere, and love the sculptures. Nice service.   Food was just ok though.  Flavors overdone and my chicken was pretty oily.  Not bad, but not good.
author: D H.

description: i love this restaurant the decor is beautiful i love chicken fettachini and although it wasn't on the menu they were more than happy to make it and my compliments to the chef it was tasty the food is authentic the shrimp are huge the prices are amazing the service is great and it is a great place for a first date or just dinner with friends.
author: emily c.
